reviewText:
In all honesty, this game should be renamed to Orc Slaying Simulator or something similar.
Shadow of Mordor is a very interesting take on the events that occur between the Hobbit and the Lord of the Rings, and I enjoy how the story fits in with Tolkien's world. However, the story itself was somewhat short for my liking, maybe only taking 10 hours or so of my total gameplay; the rest as I before mentioned, orc slaying. The story follows, Talion, a ranger living with his family and others in Mordor, who are overrun by Sauron's forces, leaving Talion on a quest to fight back against Sauron. The story then follows Talion and a Wraith who he is paired with as they quest across mordor in seek of answers and salvation. Like I said, an interesting story, yet a little short for my liking.
The gameplay is excellent, and there are many things to do in the game: kill Orcs, ride beasts, kill Orcs, find collectables, kill Orcs, etc. And even though I keep talking about the game simple being about Orc slaying, it's still very enjoyable in the many ways you can kill Orcs, and even use Orcs to kill other Orcs. My only issue was I found the controls a bit clunky (I use a keyboard and mouse), but when playing with a controller that problem was removed; therefore, if you have a controller, use it.
There are only two other issues I have with the game, one being that it's too easy (in my opinion anyway), and the other being that the fact you can choose your character somewhat ruins the game. The hardest part of the game I have to say is taking on high power orc warchiefs who are immune to ranged and stealth attacks, making fighting them in the field the only way to kill them, however even then, I can simply manipulate all the other Orcs into fighting him, and basically get all them to do the work instead. This may be a bit picky of me, as you could say I could just not use the other Orcs, and yes that would certainly make it harder, but even in the strongholds, I can easily escape a fight without dying. I'd just like to see the game being a bit more challenging that's all.
The other problem is the character selector the game has, in which I can choose to play as one of the female characters who appears in the late game, which just sort of breaks the game when you're doing missions with her, as there are two of her then. It also sort of ruins the cutscenes, as you're Talion in the cutscenes but then this girl in the game. Maybe again I'm being too picky, but it just seems like a completly unecessary feature.
Anyhow, I certainly enjoy the main game, and I'm looking forward to the DLC. I recommend all of you RPG, Stealth, Slasher, and Tolkien fans out there buy this game up.
Peace.

reviewText:
As many have before me, I cannot reiterate how Shadow of Mordor combines the best of two great fanchises, Assassin's Creed and Batman's Arkham series. Stunning graphics, fun gameplay, great controls, the fact it's open world, and the new nemesis system all make this game fantastic. This game is far from perfect however, as the gameplay can get repetetive after a while, and the lack of a difficulty setting makes the game harder to replay.

The nemesis system works great on paper, but in practice, it is rarely utilized. I remember when I was first starting out, I managed to die to a random no name Uruk while trying to bush assassinate him, promoting him to captain and making him far stronger than any foe I had previously faced. While great and all, I finally was able to kill him after realizing he died instantly from stealth finishers... The problem however, is that it is fairly hard to die. The only real reason I actually died to my former nemesis in the first place was because I was new to the game and didn't fully understand the last chance system where when brought to fatal health, you are given what seems to be at least 3 or 4 seconds to move your mouse into a circle and press the shown button. First of all, there is a rune (modification for your weapon) that gives you a second last chance, and second of all, you are given way to much time to execute this action, and once completed you regenerate around maybe half your health? Usually in these situations, I would simply run away and collect an herb (health kit basically) to regenerate to full.

The game also goes from being a challenge to being fairly easy midway through the story which isn't too bad. That brings up the main story, which to me, seems a bit short (around 16 hours to complete for me) based on the nature of this game. Of course the length really depends on how much exploration or side quests (which there are plenty of) you do. However, this opinion may be somewhat biased as I am currently playing through Arkham Origins and Skyrim. This is not that bad however, as the DLC included in the GOTY edition adds much more unique content (I am guilty of not actually playing this content, so I can't fully review it). By the end of the main story, I still had at least 8 or so abilities not yet leveled and many upgrades not yet purchased. The many side quests ultimately are not necessary for completing the main story.

The story itself however, was very interesting to me (a semi avid Lord of the Rings fan). This game in fact, taught me the difference between skipping cutscenes and not. The voice acting, sound effects and AI overall are just amazing.

After all those negative remarks you may be doubting this purchase. That however is not what I meant to convey. Though not perfect (as no game is) this game was a blast and is definitely worth your while. One of the best games I have played so far, and I would definitely reccomend this game to others. There are definitely things the game could have improved upon, but overall, I would rate this game 8.5/10

To put this in perspective, if a harder difficulty were introduced, this would probably be a 9.5/10

reviewText:
One of the best games i have played to this day, and i have played many.

I was first sceptical to buying the game as i have seen plenty of other similar sequels to big series, but after watching different gameplay videos, i decided to buy it on PC.

As it was controller supported, i managed to convert my PS3 controller into a Xbox Controller playing the game with Xbox Buttons but it was still fun.

Reading some reviews they talk about newer Assasins Creed and Batman games where a lot of combat and if i can say parkour system is taken from, as i have not played Assasins Creed for many years from Assasin's Creed 2, and i have never played Batman games, i really enjoyed the gameplay.

I initially made a save slot and played for roughly ten hours, during this gameplay a lot of time went to try to eliminate all orc Captain's, which in fact the system is brilliant, as you challenge different orc leaders or captain's, when they die someone else take their place, as well with a lot of frustration from getting killed on my first try, it also introduces something completely new to me the nemesis system which is awesome.

If you get killed in the game, the time advances and you can see Captain's challenge eachother and take higher positions, you feel the game progresses by the actions you do. As for other gameplay aspects i really enjoyed the jumping, climbing and combat which took me back several years when i enjoyed the Assasin's Creed Series. Stealth killing orcs from ledges, awesome combat with cool combat finishers really made the game cool.

I started a 2nd save with more of a serious gameplay where i wanted to collect everything, and now after playing trough the whole game, i have around 17 hours on my save two, where i now have 100%, just collecting, roaming trough and killing orcs, doing side-missions, unlock abilities and upgrades just made the game complete. Exept the final boss-fight, i really enjoyed the game, and i would recommend it to others, buy it. It's worth its money.

9/10

reviewText:
I bought this game on sale with little expectations. I had played previous LOTR games and was mildly amused by them. Buying this game, I expected the same mild amusement.... until I played it.

This game turned out to be far more amazing then I expected it to be. The fighting in the game is easy to just hack and slash your way around, but difficult to truly master - with effective and rewarding bonuses when you master your timing. Many of the negative views I've read complain about how easy the fighting is, but those folks apparently didn't take the time to try to master it, or invest in the bonuses. It was extremely fun.

What makes this game truly great is how it adds to the story line. I am one of the sad, unfortunate souls who has never taken the time to read all the Tolkein books - I've only seen the extended releases of all the LOTR and Hobbit movies multiple times because I enjoy them so much. This game adds to those stories, by giving you insight into the great war, the black gate, and other known points of interest in the movies.

The mission system is easy to use and understand, the various 'generals' in the orc amies and all the various collectiables give you lots of variety - there is always something to do. The missions also employ different play styles. You can be ranged DPS with your bow, mele dps with your sword, or stealth with your bow and dagger - with great bonuses for all styles that you could invest your experience into.

I read another negative review complaining that the black gate area was too small, but it should be noted that there are 2 other 'lands' that you get to progress to. So, if you get board in the first area (the black gate area), do the gold missions, and progress the story to visit the new lands. The story is quite good and progressing it gives you access to new, exceptionally fun powers (mind control anyone?) as well as new missions and mission types.

10/10 for a job extremely well done. Thank you!

reviewText:
The combat system is fluid and great to behold (being based on the same system as Batman) and the options for tackling the open world are huge; from brainwashing an ork captain to attack his superior to teleport-executing a sentry from 100s feet away.

Viceral, solid entertainment and the kind of game I pick up not to make further progress or level up, but simply because it's fun. I can spend ages just hunting for large groups of orks to jump into the middle of and dispatch without taking a hit; lobbing one through a camp fire, skewering another through the throat, leaping over another to stun them before making their head explode - all the while effortlessly parrying and ducking.

Great fun and an excellent title to show off your graphics processor!

reviewText:
Finally a AAA game that feels like a budget well spent! On top of the gameplay being fun and fresh, everything feels perfectly polished.

It plays a lot like the recent Batman games with a mix of stealth and melee combos. Over time you gain super powers which allow you to scrap with large hordes of enemies. Moment-to-moment the game is fun whether you’re sneaking, fighting, or running to your next objective of choice. The side quests sometimes feel grindy, but a for the most part fun challenges that can get you to try out a different play style.

The innovative system that constructs unique bosses that build a history with the player is a Holy Grail that game designers have been chasing for decades and now it’s finally working! In the coming years you’re going to see this idea stolen all over the place. Between the randomized strengths/weaknesses, shuffled cosmetics, and huge array of vocal responses they become personal and interesting enemies.

I’m not usually a fan of cut scenes, but these are quick, well written, and beautiful. I don’t know the historic difference between the words ‘orc’ and ‘uruk’, but I know that uruk is annoying to say and not recognized by spellchecker. The writing and acting in the chatter/barks has a great sense of humor. You can still hear a little of old Monolith’s No One Live’s Forever in the dialog.

The only gripe I have is that the many systems and upgrade paths feel overly complex at first. I wish they were introduced one at a time, but eventually it comes together and makes sense. The arc of the story feel like it falls short of being epic, but I’m not huge on Tolkien so most of the backstory is lost on me. Or maybe it will get bigger in the upcoming DLCs. Either way I’m excited for more.

reviewText:
Open world third-person action-adventure game.
The game is mostly about parkouring through Middle-Earth slaughtering orcs. Game has some RPG elements, but more wouldn't hurt. Usually I don't like games that I can't save when I want, but in this case dying isn't that bad and is handled very well.
I recommend this game if you like action-adventure games and Batman like combat style (as that's what you are going to do a lot).

Pros:
- Nemesis system.
- Stunning looking.
- Combat system (Batman in Middle-Earth).
- Stealth is an option.
- Voice acting.

Cons:
- Not that challenging (except the challenges them self).
- Bit lacking in RPG elements.
- Repetitiveness, you are fighting orcs from start to end.

Recommend DLC's: Lord of the Hunt & The Bright Lord the rest are really not needed. You can play these DLC's after you have finished the main story and they have no effects to it.

reviewText: Amazingly varied and fluid Arkham-like combat system with the stealth and movement of AssCreed, horde brawl melee, powerful ranged attacks, mind control and mountable beasts, and surprise environmental traps such as bait that draws Carragors who devour every Orc in sight. Too easy? Don't get any health upgrades and turn combat indicators off. The innovative Nemesis System crafts  foes worth killing, some Uruk Captains surviving your battles with scars, some ending up as heads on pikes, some growing in power and deadliness after killing you (you are reborn with a thirst for revenge each time you die) and some secretly serving you, waiting for your signal to stab their War Chief in the back as you shoot out their eye with a ghostly arrow from the front. I went in expecting a shallow rip off and instead emerged on the other side from a shallow grave as the legendary Gravewalker, cleansing fire of all Orc-kind. A fun, quick-paced, pretty romp that tries new things instead of playing it safe all the time. 9/10

reviewText:
This definitely is the best game set in Lord of the Rings universe. I played Return of the King on PS2 and that was really fun at the time, and War in the North was an ok game but certainly lacking in many areas. So being the best LotR game isn't exactly a hard thing to do, though Shadow of Mordor is actually a very good game.

A lot of people have compared this to Assassin's Creed but I'd say this is much closer to Batman Arkham games, though all these games do share a lot of similarities but still are very unique and do what they do really well.
What SoM does extremely well is the Arkham style sneaking and combat, and at parts even better thanks to nemesis system and how it changes the game. You counter with Y(played on controller) like in Arkham, and you also can do instant takedowns once hit streak is high enough. Talion also has a cool bow that later on gets the ability to teleport to the target and kill the orc instantly, this is really fun to do. Stealth also works like in AC, you can climb stuff, take down enemies etc.

Nemesis system is the innovative part of the game. Orcs have kind of this hierarchy with chiefs at the top. Later on when you get all the powers at your disposal, you can really start taking down this hierarchy and through branding, taking over enemy orcs, you can infiltrate the enemy and build your own army. This is really interesting as every encounter is different, I was genuinely surprised how much variation there is, as in no repetition at all as every orc I encountered was different, had different skills and the way to approach them was different. You can also buff the enemies up by issuing death threat through one of the orcs, the orc you death threat powers up significantly but also gives chance to drop a epic rune that you can fit in your bow, sword and dagger to power them up with different perks.

There is a lot more to the nemesis system and how it works, it's really something that has to be experienced as it's different from anything else, some true innovation and something other devs most likely will be taking note of, at least I hope so.

SoM is solid game and I do recommend playing it just for the nemesis system and combat/stealth elements. But the story, world, characters etc. just left me disappointed, I didn't really care for anything happening and the interactions between characters were awkward and not well build. I wanted so much more from this as this is set in Lord of the Rings universe. There was so much more they could've done and made something much bigger, but I just feel like they played it way too safely.

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor is what you get when you cross Batman Arkham with Assassin's Creed and wrap it up in the Lord of the Rings universe.  While lore purists may scoff at the prospect, the game actually does a very good job incorporating existing lore while paving its own way forward.  You play as a wraith-posessed ranger out to take revenge on the Black Hand while learning about the wraith's past.  It's a bit of an odd situation but it adds a lot of gameplay variety.

The game takes place on 2 reasonably-sized maps which you have free reign of.  There is never any shortage or orcs to kill since they respawn extremely quickly, sometimes visibly on your minimap before an area is out of range.  Even considering this, the map rarely feels cluttered but there is still plenty to do with a wide range of missions, side missions, collectibles, and challenges.

Shadow of Mordor uses a freeflow combat system very similar to the Batman Arkham games and pulls it off quite well.  While it does not have quite as much variety due to a lack of combat gadgets, the combat feels great especially thanks to some impressive animation work and responsive controls.  Overall the combat is pretty easy especially after obtaining a few upgrades, though the game makes it quite difficult to defend against ranged attacks due to only vague indicators of the attack.  Controls are very responsive except for the dodge, which will not interrupt attacks like countering does making enemies with uncounterable attacks difficult to deal with.  Orc captains, however, can be very dangerous especially with ranged attacks.

The main strength of the game is the Nemesis system, which surprised me since going in I was expecting it to be one of the weaker aspects of the game.  This system procedurally generates the leadership of the orc army giving each captain and warchief a name, strengths, weaknesses, and dynamic conflicts between them that you can interfere with as missions.  Any orc who kills you will also receive a name and be promoted to a captain.  While I was expecting this system to quickly become repetitive, it actually produces a lot of variety.  Each named orc will taunt or boast at you when you encounter them and I did not have a single line repeated through the entire game.  While the conflict missions themselves are fairly limited, they are mostly optional.

Graphically, Shdaow of Mordor is a bit of a mixed bag.  While the animation work is very impressive and there is a large variety of orc appearances that removes the common hey I've seen that enemy before" feeling that most games have
date: texture quality is not very good and it requires 3 GB of VRAM to run on high textures.  There is also an ultra texture pack that requires 6 GB but it apparently hardly changes anything.  Thankfully the game runs extremely smoothly and performs quite well.  The only other open world-type game I can remember running this smoothly is Tomb Raider.\n\nThe only big problem I had with the game is the mouse support.  Mouse control is very inconsistent with some mouse smoothing applied and the mouse sensitivity varying wildly in different situations.  Thankfully this is not a shooter so it doesn't interfere with gameplay much.  The one place where this really would interfere is when you are aiming with the bow
recommended: though the mouse seems to behave itself there.\n\nI highly recommend Shadow of Mordor.  It is definitely one of the best games to come out in 2014 and probably the best Lord of the Rings game to date even though WB is trying to separate it from canon by not using "Lord of the Rings" in its name.  Now

reviewText:
This Open World Title is absolutly amazing to say the least.... Shadow of Mordor is a continued story based on where the Lord of the Rings finnished off.

The story is really good and being a fan of the Lord of the Rings, Shadow of Mordor really made sense stroy wise and I really enjoyed the new characters that were introduced and how they refer back to old characters from Lord of the Rings. Overall 10/10 for the story line.

The action and combat system is unreal and I felt at home just after a little while playing. The combos are insane and you can really rank your abilities to draw one mean ♥♥♥ combo that will destroy an entire Uruk army!

The ranking system is broken into two sections which require different tasks to rank them up and unlock new abilities. How to unlock new abilities is really straight forward to understand and really fun to do.

The side quests are really enjoyable and take some time to complete which in my book is great because if you want to take a slight break from the story then you can try out some challenging side quests before carrying on with the main stroy. Some of the side quests are hard so prepare yourself and hold on to your paitence levels.

The maps are great and there is a lot of exploring to do and the layout allows you to use the enviroment to your advantage during combat which I really liked a lot. The creatures that dwell around are amazing too and really add a great impact to the general map feel.

Overall the game felt like a 10/10 for me and I am really looking forward to the follow up on the Shadow of Mordor in the Future.

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor (SoM) is, hands-down, my game of 2014 so far; I loved every minute of it!

SoM is a sandbox game of combat & stealth, infiltration, manipulation and assassination, set in J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-Earth. It's been described as Assassin's Creed with the combat of the Batman series, but it has some original and innovative features. It's an AAA game so the graphics are as good as you'd expect and they don't seem to have forgotten about the PC; we have enough video options to push our most powerful graphical cards to the brink.


My favourite aspects:True Sandbox: finally, a sandbox game that actually really lets you do your own thing all the time! The missions are instanced but even the scripted storyline missions never try to rein you in; you're always allowed to do it your way! As a bonus, instead of having entire missions dedicated to force you to learn how to use this or that minor new trick, those types of things are usually set as occasional (and fully optional) secondary objectives that you can achieve without deviating much from the approach you really feel like taking.

Difficulty, part 1: SoM hits my sweet spot. A single enemy mook is easy to kill, sure, but an entire crowd can quickly become overwhelming. Some enemies are easier to fight than others so things stay pretty challenging because there's always a mix of opponents around. Unlike other games, SoM doesn't cheat" by magically levelling-up the enemies at the same time you do
date: so you actually feel like you're getting more and more powerful. Things do become easier bit by bit as you get more practice at playing and gain more powers and options to take down your enemies
recommended: but death can still come quickly and swiftly if you don't stay on your toes.\n\nDifficulty

reviewText:
This game is like the FarCry in Middle Earth. Some aspects are similar, but with better feature like Nemesis system.

1. Gameplay, action rpg. Slash, stab, thrust. You can counter enemy attacks with RMB and evade unblockable attacks with Space. If you have played Sleeping Dogs or Batman Arkham series, you will get used to it in no time, similar but not same. There is skill system that you get when lv up, cool skills like riding a caragour or maybe warg, execution skill (very brutal and AWESOME). Skills has 5 tiers which you can unlcok by gaining power point, finish side missions or kill captains or warchiefs to get power point. Each map has a tower you need to forge to reveal the surrounding things (Far Cry), and there are survival challenge and hunting challenge, reminds me of Red Dead Redemption. Survival challenge is gathering herbs scattered around Middle Earth, while hunting is killing pests, bugs and aviary (spiders, rats, bats). You get money for completing those, sorry I forgot what the local currency called. Collectibles you has runes and artifacts.

2. Story, still about Sauron and the Uruks & co. I dont really care for the story actually, the gameplay is awesome. I spend most of the game messing with the uruks, its much more fun than the story. Besides story mission, you also has side missions such as weapon missions, local warfare missions such as duel, recruitment, ambush, etc. The uruks are at war each other.

3. Nemesis system, this is an interesting system. Since you character cant exactly die (why?play the game. say no to spoiler), the uruk who killed you will be promoted to a higher rank, captain, liutenant (maybe), sergeant (perhaps) and the last warchief. And when you got killed by an uruk, he will mock you, go find him and he will boast, and if he kill you again, you know the rest. Imagine got killed by the same uruk 3-4 times, I did (i am suck), I hunted this son of a frog and when I finally killed him, damn that was good feeling. Every warchief or captain has a weakness, you can find an intel by finding certain uruk symbolized by a green square thingy on the map, interrogate him and pick any captain or warchief you want to find out what his weaknesses are.

Cons:
I cant find any, but I know there are some cons, but I dont find any.

reviewText: Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor   Field  Rating  Review    Graphics  8  Shadow of Mordor isn't the prettiest game out there, and the HD texture pack makes almost no difference. But, that being said, the graphics overall are very well done, with nothing jarring sticking out. But it's certainly no Crysis.    Gameplay  9  This game almost shines flawlessly. You can spend countless hours killing orcs, and every moment is satisfying. The only downfall of the gamplay is the lack of mission diversity, and the fact that eventually, if you want to get an orc promoted, you're going to just have to stand there and do nothing. Because frankly you get a bit too powerful, and captains/warchiefs really pose no threat to you anymore, even in groups. Other than that, you will not find a better, more fluid combat game out there. The diversity of skills and abilities is fantastic, allowing you to fight the way you want to fight.    Story  5  This game has a pretty mediocre story. It's not terrible, but it really isn't good. It's just...there. It takes a backseat to all the killing and joy you will find in the game. Shadow of Mordor attempts to bridge the gap between the events of The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings." It seems like a silly grab-all

recommended: in my opinion.    Replayability  8.5  As fun as it is

reviewText:
Pros/cons at the bottom of review.


Beat the game in about 20 hours and got to say it was a solid experience for the most part. In terms of my play time I did a very hefty portion of the side missions/challenges, I wouldn't be surprised if you could beat this game in 5/10 hours if not less but hey the batman games have been the same even skyrim's main quest line so i guess this isn't too out of the norm.  The combat in my opinion surpasses the batman games in smoothness and obviously brutality which is a nice switch up from the fist fighting batarang wielding hero i've loved for the past three games.  The brutality of this game is probs one of my favorite things it had to offer. The lord of the rings movies have always been violent but this game takes it to a whole new level i've always wanted to see. Another great feature that I didn't really expect was the ability to mount the monsters in the game and unleash chaos on your enemies, graugs destroy everything and I love picking up a brave orc commander and biting his head off.... good stuff. One thing that did get me (and i was expecting to see this the whole game) is that none of the orcs manage to mount these beasts especially the caragor which is kinda weird because on more than a few occasions I thought i heard them talking/boasting about mounting these things, guess none of them actually have the balls that our boy talion does.

What this game really lacks, something that they should have taken from the batman games, is a line up of real bosses. Yes the nemesis system is cool as well as the lineup of orc commanders but in my opinion most of these guys are like mini bosses at best, unless three or more of these commanders jump you at once they don't really pose that much of a threat especially if you go the extra mile and get the intel on them or mind control a few of his boys. You get one of these commanders in a one on one situation and no matter how strong they are you can take them down with a little planning and common sense (yes this is a rare situation but it happened to me more than a few times in my play through).  The games actual bosses go really south after the first of the black hand you face in mordor, even him I beat on the first try, but the other guy and then sauron are just complete jokes....This game had some alright characters and a good story but the moment you fight the second boss of the black hand I feel like the story goes south and is abit rushed to the conclusion. The game does offer two areas to explore and while they are different in layout I can't help but feel the second area is a grassy reskin of alot of the areas in Mordor, especially how everything is setup in the same plato layout.

Pros

-runs real smooth (I had no issues with graphic setup or game crashing)
-amazing combat system
-lots of brutality
-solid graphics
-runes/upgrade system (abit too easy to get ability points and such but still a good system)
-pretty good characters (especially tallion)
-caragors and graugs!
-good story (until the end)
-smooth stealth/climbing
-warchiefs /nemesis (even if they are abit too easy I thought this was a very innovative idea)

Cons
-too easy/lacks difficulty settings
-abit too short
-lack of real" bosses
-story is "rushed" near the end (in my opinion)
-first area and second area feel very similar
-some characters are really underdeveloped (again my opnion)
-once you gain the abilities to cause fear in orcs through your brutality moves (as cool as they may be) the game becomes drastically easier
-lots of quick time events ( I personally dont mind them and rarely found any challenging but I know most people dont care for them)

My verdict 8/10

All in all I think this games a fun experience and worth playing
date: I don't really know about the 50$ price tag for 20 hours I got out of it so I would recommend waiting for a sale but its still a great game worth playing through."

reviewText:
Let me get the negative out of the way.  The portrayal of women in this game is beyond terrible.  It is, across the board, the worst representation of women in games I have ever seen.  Developers need to do so much better than this.

Now, that aside, this is the best action game I have ever played.

The dynamic enemy hierarchies are brilliant, as are their randomly generated strengths, weaknesses, and personalities.  The first time an Uruk I thought I had killed came back with an appropriately changed visual and a burning desire for revenge was amazing.  I think the ability to manipulate the enemies came too late in the game, but it definitely changed how I played the game.

The combat system is the best fluid-combo system I have ever seen.  Finally a system where countering takes precedence over everything else, so you aren't constantly getting cheap-shotted in the middle of an animation.  This system is clever, builds well upon itself, and is a tremendous joy to use.  I never got tired of the many various ways I had to murder orcs, and all the ways to use the environment in support of your battle was very good.

Story-wise, asides from the portrayal of women, I found the game to be very solid.  I enjoyed the story, I found it interesting and I genuinely wanted to learn more about what was happening.

I highly recommend this game, and it is the metric by which I will be comparing all future action games.

reviewText:
(ภาษาไทย ด้านล่าง)
One Dead man to Rule them All. Overwhelm Sauron's Army with the power of Wraith.
Plus a bit of stories from Middle-Earth.

Arkham Style Combat, the Animations, the Sounds and Graphics are very very good.
These make fighting very fun and satisfying. And you'll be fighting A LOT.

The Nemesis System is Outstanding and very interesting. It keeps me looking for new enemy to fight without getting bored. (at least not yet at 40-ish hrs-in)

The Pre-Rendered Cinematic Cutscenes looks fine. But i'd prefer more in-game cinematic cutscenes.
There's No Difficulty Options in the game but There are ways to make the game more Challanging. (but still quite easy)

The Controls are pretty good. But the Multi-purpose Buttons sometimes do what you did not intended to do.
It would be great to have options to bind them seperately. Sadly there isn't at the moment.

About the game It's an Open-World Action game. So get in there and have fun.

And I'm surely having so much fun out of it.

-Recommended-

reviewText: The best thing about playing Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is that it makes me feel over-the-top powerful without sacrificing the fear of defeat. It’s got great free-flowing combat and a good-sized, good-looking open world full of Lord of the Rings lore to find, but what makes it special is what’s going on in the background: an intriguing hierarchy of enemies that gives every victory and defeat extra meaning.

reviewText:
Really decent game. If you're a LotR's fan, it'll definitely draw you in a lot more. It's essentially an Orc genocide simulator... you kill orcs, then kill some more orcs... and kill orcs who think they're tougher than the other orcs... all the while finding collectible artifacts and pruning and eating flowers and mushrooms.

It's very much a hybrid of those Batman Arkham games + Assassin's Creed style game play. Half the game is stealthing around the other half is brutally long combat sequences that require you to plan and strategize the final kills. The game isn't as simple as kill everything... There's a gimmick of holding an orc and draining their mind for intel on other orc chiefs so you can exploit their weaknesses and make the fights easier.

It's a very repetitive game but incredibly simple over all. The game has a scaling difficulty, so the further you get in to the story, the harder it becomes. However, your arsenal of special moves becomes much wider so it balances itself out... If you start to feel underpowered, then it's time to start grinding out XP on side missions and unlocking some more of the advanced special moves. By the end of the game, you're just an orc killing machine and nothing can really stop you unless you make mistakes in the fights.

The animations are incredibly fluent and I've never really felt the impact of killing something like I have in this game... There's just something great about rolling over the back of an orc only to slice their head off in one swift motion. :)

The game looks really good as well (playing on Ultra) and I haven't experienced any frame drops, so the optimization is really well executed for higher end machines. I'm running a GTX 970, i7 @950 if that gives you an idication of what you need to make the game run smooth.

If you're tired of Batman games or Assassin's Creed, I'd steer clear of this game because that's essentially all it is. only more refined and a lot more casual...

The climbing system is incredibly easy which makes stealth kills easy to execute as well... I'd say about 90% of the walls in this game are scalable... just hold A and press forward and chances are, you will just start climbing stuff automatically... no thought involved, which was nice. :)

As with most WB games, it's a very cinematic experience, high production values, low substance and not very challenging but still interesting enough to justify playing.

I'd rate this a 7.5 / 10... it's a decent experience, nothing you haven't seen or played before, but it's fun.

I would try to get it on sale, anywhere  in the 20 to 30 dollar range, no more... try to get all the DLC as well as it adds more game play modes to the over all experience.

For achievement hunters: There aren't any missible achievements either, so just enjoy the experience and play... You'll eventually get all the really convoluted achievements just playing through the main story line. Don't go out of your way for anything that sounds ridiculous until you're finished the story line.

reviewText: This game is intricate, complex, and all around really fun. Its a great experience. The gameplay is lots of fun, really exciting, and it doesnt get boring. On the outside it may seem repetetive, but it never feels that way. Every fight you get into, and just any action in general always feels like you are fighting for something. Its like you have a greater purpose and every ork you kill or brand or interrogate is all going towards your cause to liberate Mordor. The story isn't very complex, its simple. This is good though, because its just simple enough to still be very interesting and engaging without taking away from the rest of the game. I just played Assassin's Creed Unity and I found its story to be very lacking, making it hard to enjoy the game because the whoe time I didn't know what was going on. This is not the case in Mordor. On that same note, this has been accused of being an Assassin's Creed clone, it is not in any way. It may look similar due to the parkour and assassination style missions, but after playing ACU and every single other Assassin's Creed I can confidently say these games are all diverse and different.\nBottom Line: This game is worth your money and your time, it is a fun, interesting, and fresh experience. I loved every moment of it.

reviewText:
This game has very smooth combat encounters and enjoyable boss fights. There are lots of objectives you can do in addition to the main missions. You can hunt animals and sneak kill some uruks in stealth missions, for example. So the gameplay is pretty good in this game.

It can be irritating to fight some bosses when there are many other bosses nearby. I tried to encounter one captain and suddenly there were 2-3 other captains and enormous horde of minions all around me. That can be a good thing if you are looking for challenge (like me).

The plot in this one left a lot to be desired. I wasn't impressed by the first cutscene and did pretty much skip the rest. And the main missions' objectives were not that interesting.

All in all I would recommend this game because the lack of top notch storyline isn't that much of a problem when you have many hours of very enjoyable gameplay ahead of you.

reviewText:
Ash nazg durbatulûk
Ash nazg gimbatul
Ash nazg thrakatulûk
Agh burzum-ishi krimpatul !

I have mixed feelings about this. From one hand we have unlimited potential of Lord of the Rings excellent universe. From another, this potential remained unrealized.

I should say the plot is more emotional in comparison to the last Hobbit movie. And by the way this story is interesting. The gameplay process just like in Batman franchise from Rocksteady. A player exploring two regions of Mordor and solving every issue through slaying uruks.

So it isn't difficult, you can beat this without any upgrade to your weapons or personal abilities. But gameplay process with these upgrades is more funny.

The Nemesis system, a fresh blood in industry looks fine. An overage uruk becomes a captain after killing a player. And can be promoted to warchief by himself or with your interference. And it's the best part of this system. You can brand captains, build your own army of uruks, give them orders, and use the situation in Sauron's army to your personal purposes.

But this system is great only in plot because out of it, it has no meaning due to unlimited spawn of uruks and lack of interesting events. You will get tired of spawning uruks with the same names, abilities, vulberabilities and phrases.

And it's very very very annoying. Because you can't skip this useless boring annoying speech which lasts from five to eight seconds. Those who completed Ring and Wild trials will understand me.

And few words about seaon pass. This season pass is very strange. You probably won't need these runes, maybe except flaming rune. Because runes from original game are enough to kill a lot of uruks without any problem. And it's really doubt that you will want to try trials. So the only reason to buy it in beating the game on 100%

The Lord of the Hunt is funny enough, right before you will try the test of wild trial. It's strangely hard in comparison to the whole game. I don't know who the author of this idea, but it's obviously that he is very very sick person.
But in this DLC you can ride the graug which can puke on everything around, and ride a flaming caragath. It's really funny for the first-second hour.

The Bright Lord was strange due to Tolkien legacy. A player will play as Celebrimbor, his abilities oriented on branding uruks, but he is not so strenght as Thalion, and can stuck in textures by the way :(
A player should brand his army and try to defeat Sauron using the One ring abilities (unlimited punishments, slow motion, invisibility).

But this DLC has some rude mistakes: The Black Gates were build after defeating Sauron. Ingame movies show us the massive battlefield between uruks and elves, but it's not what you see in this DLC (You will fight in southern stronghold). These inaccuracies are very dissapointing. The first region of Mordor looks absolutely the same in the second (Bright Lord) and in third (Thalion's campaign) epochs.

The Laziness in working on Lord of the Rings universe is not forgiven, Monolith. Especially on such price.

If you like Batman from Rocksteady and Lord of the Rings universe, you will enjoy this game. But don't try to beat 100% achievements, otherwise you will regret it.

As for me, I don't think I will buy next game from Monolith.

reviewText: This game is very derivative. And I mean that in the BEST KIND OF WAY POSSIBLE. The developers (Monolith) shamelessly borrowed successful mechanics from other high-profile video games, and combined them into some kind of amazing all-star supergame. In this case, they took: The exploration and movement system of Assassin's Creed; the combat of Batman; and the enemy design of Warhammer 40K: Space Marine. Brew that all together, add in a pinch of Sleeping Dogs and Far Cry 3, and you have one of the most ridiculously good open-world action games ever made. Ridiculously fun. I can't recommend this enough.

reviewText:
Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is an excellent game which takes place in the Lord of the Rings universe. It is set before the events of Lord of the Rings but after the events of the Hobbit.

You play as a Ranger who was killed by Sauron's Black Hand, but was denied death. Your body is also host to a Wraith as you go looking for revenge.

What I like the most is the nemesis system the game uses, which allows non-playable characters to remember the death of the game's protagonist and react accordingly. There's nothing quite like an Uruk captain or war chief taunting you about how he's going to kill you yet again. And Uruks that kill you get more powerful for having done so. And killing the war chiefs doesn't mean the enemy runs out of them, others will get promoted in the killed war chief's place. You can also set the Uruks up against eachother, issue death threats against them or poison their grog barrels and watch them turn on one another.

The main story consists of 20 or so missions, but there are also tons of side missions. If you have all the DLC you get side missions with Gollum, finding out about the past and the forging of the rings. You get to ride magnificent beasts and stealth kill or simply mass-murder Orcs and Uruks. There are also side missions to build the legends of your sword, knife and bow. Some of those missions are easy, others are tremendously difficult. I also had fun helping a sniveling coward Orc named Ratbag become war chief (he did not survive in the end).

Don't get frustrated if you get killed a lot early in the game. Build up your Ranger and Wraith skills and you will be fine in the end. I don't always play 100% of the main and side missions in every game, but in this one I did, and that says it all. This game is great, get it if you can. I got it on discount from a well known and legal Bundle site, including all its DLC. But even at its full price I would consider it worth it.

10/10 will manipulate Uruks into killing eachother again

My final thoughts on this game is that I love Celebrimbor (as a Wraith too)

reviewText:
Nan iChîr Gelair Mordor!

This game is remarkable. It does so many things well. It's a half-step towards bringing life to AAA games.

Half, since I wish perhaps that it relied more on the strategic layer more than the story progression. I've heard DLC's do exactly that (much like State of Decay's then) and were it so, I would like to get back to them.

But the story is good too. It almost makes sense within the broader canon, which isn't a small thing. There are timeline issues and other ones; yet it can be seen as a legend from expanded and retold mythology like Tolkien wished (?) ...
Well at least Black Speech dialogues are top-notch. :)

reviewText:
Aside from a few glitches I throughly enjoyed my time with this game.

The combat is nice and once you've grow accustomed to the combos it's very satisfying to mow down entire garrisons of orcs by tackling them head on or slaughering them from the shadows. Over time the game throws more advanced enemies in your path giving your a feeling of power as well as challenge.

The nemesis system is rather clever - letting you play Vendettas and Klingon politics among the ranks of orcs.

The progression system is good enough for a game like this. I've not found it tedious to hunt down the artifacts and experience points to unlock pretty much everything.

The only gripes I have with the game are the controls which sometimes glitch out. I've found it very difficult to use bite attacks on any mount and my attempts to block an attack often put me into ranged mode instead. A handful of times I had my character get stuck on some ledge or something and once I was unable to finish a mission. Finally I found the story a bit hard to follow since there's often much time between snippets of story and the format of disjointed flashbacks doesn't help either.

But over all I'm still very much glad I played this game. The closest two games I can compare it with are Assassins Creed and Far Cry 3, both of which I consider significantly inferior games to Shadow of Mordor.

reviewText: This Review contains minor spoilers about the final scenes of the game, read at your own risk.\nShadow of Mordor is a game about killing orcs. It it also known as a mix of the Arkham Series and Assassin's Creed. Many people call this a ripoff, but it is in many ways better than both of these games, but it still has it's own small problems. The Story is quite good and has a few twists and turns. It has many references to the Lord of the Rings series and it's lore is very accurate. The game plays and looks amazing. The combat is hard when you start off,  but further down the line you will only lose fights in unbeatable odds. It has a lot more variety than the Arkham series, but it is quite easy when you get some of the higher tier powers. The stealth system is nothing unusual, but it is not emphasised enough on. You crouch and take your opponents out. With the Arkham games you have many different foes and you have the ability to approach nearly every situation in your own way, but Shadow of Mordor dosen't have that, and it is not a bad thing. It is it's own game, and it does what it does well. It is better than Assassin's Creed though because it actually has a crouch button. The climbing is exactly like Assassin's Creed but it is much faster and you can climb up almost anything in a few grabs. The game also offers many side quests and the amazing nemesis system. I have literally not seen anything like it before. It is unique and it feels like what the orcs would be trying to accomplish with their power struggles. It has a high risk reward system with the runes that can make you overpowered as hell. The mounts in the game, while limited, offer a nice form of travel compared to simple fast travelling and can be used to kill orcs as well. However, there is one thing this game did not execute well; The ending. The first battle brought back your worst nemesis and it was awesome. Then the next battle was a easy stealth section where you had to stealth attack your opponent 3 times, then hold a button to finish him off. Then it picks up with a fast pace battle near the Black Gate. You charge through with a Caragor and kill 5 captains with the help of your branded orcs. Then the final part is a 5 button QTE. This was just lazy and I expected a lot more. However, the rest of the game is amazing. I am looking forward to the content in the Season Pass and I hope Monolith do not do that to the ending of a game again. Overall: 9.5/10

reviewText:
The good, the bad and the ugly.

The good...

Combat mechanics. A perfect blend of some of the best fighting elements borrowed from recent Batman games flavoured with a decent amount of Assasin’s Creed parkour. Slashing, bashing and trashing, its all there in a perfect Uruk discrimination package filled with disemboweling, cutting off limbs, bone crushing and of course tons and tons of whatever stuff runs though orc veines. Need some tutoring on how many ways there are to kill an orc? Look no further. This game will provide you with more than enough insight on that particular topic. The combat is generally very responsive, it feels right no matter what type of controls you are using, gamepad or mouse/keyboard combo. Whatever you do, combat will probably never be the reason for any of the problems you might experience in the game.

Ingame cinematics. Oh boy… Some of the cinematics made for this game are pretty much movie theater material, going on par with LotR movies themselves. They are also the main source of the game’s narrative so it would be pretty unwise to skip them unless you are only after some orc blood.

The bad…
If you are after some decent story from the expanded LotR universe you will probably be heavily disappointed. Yes there are some interesting plot twists which fit nicely with the original LotR lore but the buildup and the anticlimactic conclusion leave much to desire. There is also a huge amount of pointless story missions which pretty much only serve to add some effective game time and bore the player to death in the process. Poisoning Uruks with grog and destroying Mordor’s cultural heritage as main storyline quests!? Cmon! Give me a break.

“Though you shall have no meaningful UI” was probably what the publisher said prior to releasing this game for PC. Having to leave the game and open up the main menu every time there is need to adjust weapon runes or simply pick up an orc target in the Uruk hierarchy is pretty time consuming and frustrating.

Environmental interaction. As much as the controls themselves are fine, for both gamepads and keyboard/mouse combos, interaction with the environment can be often pretty frustrating. Picking up a perfect path to reach a fleeing boos often ends in a total disaster just because the main character likes to stick to every damn thing that comes even remotely close to his path. This effectively means that instead of jumping off from a high vantage point in order to pin down a boss to the ground you will find yourself suddenly hanging from a wooden beam which just happened to be near the jump path halfway through the jump. There are also some problems with the controls which change their behavior depending on the situation. The best example would probably be “drop down” which is usually reserved for “E”, however if you are on a ledge or a line of rope it suddenly changes to down (“S”) which can often lead to situations where players don’t actually know which “down” they should use.

The skill progression system. Its not that skill progression is bad. Its simply that some of the most interesting skills are unlocked almost at the very end of the main story line. Branding, chained mass executions, caragorn mounting… Those are all skills that greatly add to the experience but require access to top skill tiers which on the other hand require a lot of side mission grinding. Players will probably feel unnecessarily locked out of stuff that they should have been able to use from a more reasonable moment in the game.

The ugly…
The graphics. It would probably be unfair to call the game ugly but its surprisingly shocking to see how little effort was put into creating imaginative levels which even remotely represent the quality we got used to from other LotR games or even movies. The map feels bland with repetitive sections which feel like a simple copy/paste from the terrain seen just a minute before. It doesn’t help that it got divided into two distinctive parts because the second part also feels like the first one just with added vegetation. There is simply no diversity and no “wow” effect we got used to for anything LotR related. In all honesty I haven’t been able to test any of the graphics modes which require more than 2GB VRAM but I highly doubt that any texture pack could resolve the problem of bad level design and lack of imagination while creating the map for this game.

The overall lack of gameplay diversity. Aside from the main story, a couple of types of challenge missions and some collectables there is actually nothing to do in the game. Challenge missions are picked from a poll of three or four mission types which seem to repeat endlessly. Simply put, if hacking and slashing orcs for hours isn’t something you get easily entertained with then chances are you will get bored to death in Shadow of Mordor.

Would I recommend this game? Yes I would. But its important to make a note about the target audience which will enjoy it. Players which expect some deep meaningful LotR experience with huge amount of RPG elements will be disappointed. On the other hand players that don’t mind killing orcs for hours in a GTA mission style oriented game will probably enjoy it.

If there wasn’t for an interesting combat system the lack of any meaningful story and bad level design would have probably made me rate this game 6/10. However, short-term enjoyment of the combat system earns this game a 8/10 from me.

reviewText:
I played this game through doing all the main game quest, meaning all of the main quest, Outcast rescues, Ithildin collection and artifact collection. I also did all the survival challenges and nearly every hunting challenge. I used some time to grind a few specific achievements. All of this took me about 26 hours.

The game seems pretty well optimised, with the FPS staying confidently at and over 60 on my GTX 960 and high settings (if I remember right). The game looks great and the animations are smooth and they vary enough to instill gasps of delight even after many hours of playing. At least with me the game didn't crash at any point and I did not encounter any bugs or glitches whatsoever.

Even though I am somewhat sceptical about open world games these days (open world seems to be an excuse to put soulless collection-/busywork-ish sidequests without any other real thought process what makes open world interesting) I think it worked out pretty well with Shadow of Mordor. The world (= the two main quest areas) are large enough so that you don't have to look at the same valleys and mountains all the time, but it's small enough so that empty travel does not take too much time. Eventually when you unlock all the necessary skills the world is full of exciting stuff to sink your time in. You can stalk orcs, listen to their jammering, then drop a fly nest on their heads and go gut the lot. You can interfere in the internal politics via simple automatically generated quests that show you the everyday life of an evil guy warhost commander. These mechanics also play a big part in the actual main quest, which I find was executed pretty nicely. In a way it might seem at times unnecessarily grindy and repetitive, but more often than not it is interesting to raise an interesting and cool orc captain. Help him rise through the ranks to eventually become a warchief, then arrange a fight to the death with this thing that is practically your own child by now. In the long run the system starts to shift in to the dull side. The training of captains isn't really necessary for other things besides your own enjoyment and the main quest (you also get more powerful runes if you kill high level captains, but at least I found the runes to be nice and helpful bonuses, but not something that need to be farmed in order to get through the game).

Orc captain/warchief system is adequately large enough so that you probably won't encounter two similar boss-orcs during one play through. The somewhat-emergent gameplay system helps you to form a kind of personal connection with the enemies and they actually seem to have a personality every now and then. All the different names and outfits the orcs wear are not probably too canon, but they make for a good game.

The story in Shadow of Mordor is a let down. It is a basic vengeance quest with the protagonist avenging the death of his family and trying to save the world in the meantime. Whereas the orcs you encounter might occasionally have an interesting personality, the supporting friendly characters are pretty soulless and uninteresting, the only possible exception being a certain hunter dwarf. Boss fights seem a bit forced and are too simple considering how fun and engaging the captain system is. Especially the main boss was a let down in many senses, ranging from the story to the execution.

There is no question that Shadow of Mordor is a wonderful game with unique gameplay systems, awesome visuals and enough gameplay to keep you engaged but not too much that one would get bored. In the long run the nemesis system starts to lose its edge and might become a chore, but you will probably finish the game before that happens. Only real downside is the lackluster story, which fortunately is not too large a focus. It seems that in many ways this game has managed to dodge several pitfalls: you can see that the potential of crappiness is there, but it has been artfully averted with right design decisions and systems that far outweigh the downfalls.

reviewText:
This game feels like one huge quicktime event, or a slightly interactive movie.

The combat consists of mashing one button and watching the fight resolve itself in nicely done choreography.

If you want to expedite things a bit, or add some moves to the choreography, you may spice up your button mashing with additional keys, as suggested by screen prompts (parry, dodge, etc.). It doesn't actually feel necessary though.

The camera is annoying, the controls feel spongy and weird (no strafing, sneak is faster than walk) and the cutscenes are extremely frequent and feel interruptive. Also, this thing calls itself an RPG, but there is no loot, no alternate weapons/armor, no inventory, no character customization whatsoever.

I regret this purchase, sale or no.

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Few words about the game

Shadow of Mordor is quite good adventure-action game and, let's face it, if you want to freeroam a bit in LOTR universe, it's one of a kind game for now. Gameplay is not best one around, yet alot of games could learn thing or two from this game about its mechanics. As a LOTR devotee, with all those simple and old or LEGO games placed in this universe, i had to play it. Personally, I recommend it to everyone who finds tons of orks somehow sexy and finds enjoyment in running around behind enemy lines where everyone wants You dead.

Advantages
Graphics really amazed and surpriced me, I really wasn't expecting that many details to be polished
Sounds in games are pretty good with variety of snarls, mumbles and roars, although voicing of characters could be done a little bit better
Story in game is good and well told, somewhat short but still good
Pretty good combination of stealth and action with really nicely done mechanics of movement
Disadvantages
Gameplay quite disappointed me. It was fun for the first 2-3 hours where you get to know with what was going on etc. but after that you can clearly see that it's REALLY repetetive but you know, personal preferences here, most people probably would enjoy that after all.
Combat system is simillar or even same as in Batman: Arkham Origins. Enemies are slow, attack you one by one and it's really, really easy to dodge / counter them.
Gets annoyingly repetitive after few hours of fighting hordes of Uruks
If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

reviewText:
Welcome to my first review in a long time! During this review  I will be addressing the games elements which include: Gameplay, Graphics, Sound/Music, Story, along with the things that make it unique. I will also along give my thoughts and feelings on the game. Be warned there are VERY MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD!

Gameplay: 9/10 When I started this game the first two games I thought of (and many others agree) were Assassin's Creed and the recent Batman Arkham games. The game takes the parkour and stealth system of Assassin's Creed and combines it with the timed button pressing combat of Batman. While many will say this is a complete rip-off of the two, it simply is far from it. It takes the elements from these games tosses them into a polisher to polish the mechanics and refines them so that it can flow almost seamlessly. Each mission uses different elements of these mechanics by utilizing different challenges in each mission such as getting stealth kills, executions, and others which give you bonus points for abilities and so on.

The reason why I did not give this a 10 was due to the slight lag in the counter system. It was not as fluid as Arkhams system but it is damn close to it!

Graphics: 8/10 I can’t really say much about the graphics as I only played it on PC. They are nice enough to get you immersed into the game. However where it really shines is on the 4k resolution. Sadly you need at least a 4GB card for this to happen. From what I have seen from the PS4/Xbox One versions they barely push the systems to their limits. I will update this section when I know more about the PS3/360 versions. Sorry Wii U fans no version for you unfortunately. I will say that the ambient effect are nice like getting soaked in water or mud and the wind mechanics and adds more realism to the games. There isn’t really anything EYEPOPPING here at the moment.


Sound/Music 10/10: I CAN PERSONALLY SAY THAT ONE THING OF THE BEST THINGS ABOUT THIS GAME IS THE MUSIC! Though there aren’t any tracks recognizable from the Lord of The Rings/Hobbit Movies. The musical score is fantastic and very well done in my opinion. The sounds of swords clanking off metal armor, shields cracking, and the voice acting is fantastic. I can't praise it any more.

Story 6/10: The story is pretty simple. Your character and the games protagonist Talion is killed, along with his wife and son, by servants of Sauron called the Black Hand. You are then possessed by a wraith who is also seeking revenge on the Armies of Mordor which makes you become an undying Ranger to claim your revenge. And that's all that's all that is explained to you to start. I won't spoil any more. Though the story has some weak points the interaction between the characters is enough to keep you wondering what’s next even though the story is rather one dimensional when it comes to the main subject of it (Revenge!)

Unique Elements 8/10: One thing I can say about the game is that it has quite a few unique features that have kept other players and myself engaged. The leveling system is slightly different from others where as you gain XP, you learn new abilities to make your character better at combat, stealth and bow attacks. You can also learn new finishing moves, and combos which will help you in battle. There are also side missions that can be done to acquire a currency which is then spent on upgrading your total health, ammo, and slow motion focus time.

The most engaging part of the game is the Nemesis System." As you play through the game
hoursPlayed: and chiefs in Sauron's Army willA look at the nemesis systemA look at the nemesis system by battling each other for power within the army. Most of the time can be to your advantage but can also be your downfall. One instance can be they will be dueling each other for positions of power while moving about in the ranks on their own. However
voteText: let's say you attempt to kill off one of these Captains. If you defeat him
helpfulPercent: his position will be left over in the army for a new enemy to fill the space. If you are slain in battle
votesHelpful: the enemy who killed you will gain reputation
votesTotal: called power
votesFunny: and be promoted to Captain
commentsCount: gaining special abilities and weaknesses. The game does not hold your hand as it punishes failure
column16:
which is something we haven't seen in a lot in recent games at all which also makes it more rewarding.


In conclusion
column17: that Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a great game to pick up; even if you aren't a fan of Lord of the Rings it has a lot to offer a gamer who is looking for something new. I think that is part of the reason why the decided to not use the Lord of the Rings trademark name. They wanted to make this game a game that anyone could pick up and enjoy without knowing the lore if they wanted to. However for fans of the lore there are plenty of references to the books and films within the achievements/trophies

reviewText:
Do you like the Batman Arkham games?  It uses a fork of the engine.

Do you like Assassin's Creed games?  It has some of that feel without the stupid sci-fi memory crap.

If your answers are yes, you'll like Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor.  Stealthing, parkouring, slashy-stabby Orc goodness.  Enjoy it as far as your budget allows (buy now/sale later/etc).

All signs point to competent with this game, but now that I've reached 100% completion the nit-picky problems are obvious:

- Aside from the very hard working artists that slaved creating the proverbial bucket of Lord of the Rings paint to pour all over this Batman Arkham Mordor clone, what has been innovated?

- The story is one part meandering, one part clipped, and one part rushed, with a result that feels wholly incomplete, and I highly suspect it is (buy the Season Pass for more! -Publisher)

- The story missions are decent but they still seem to be in tutorial mode almost to the end.  You only get Brand and Dominate at Missions 16 and 17 out of 20!  These are essential tools for tinkering" with the greatly-advertised Nemesis system
date: and yet they are doled out in the very late game.\n\n-The Outcast side missions are fun as far as you find the gameplay itself is fun
recommended: but carry little substance of their own.  Find Outcast intel
hoursPlayed: go to Outcast mission
voteText: do what it takes to cut Outcasts off their wooden posts.  Rinse
helpfulPercent:
repeat.

- The Weapon Legend missions are more entertaining and much better side missions because they dictate some restrictions to the usual affair in how you complete your mission.  Enjoyable!  I just wish achieving those 5th and 10th Legend missions actually *meant* something besides shiny weapon texture changes.  More rune slots?  Special bonuses beyond rune slots?  Something?

- Some of the answers to my concerns regarding innovation will be the Nemesis system.  It is certainly the game feature that stands apart from the game's (Arkham) origins.  Having played 25 hours and reached 100% completion
votesHelpful: do I feel like the Nemesis system stands on its own?  Is it innovative enough that I want to play some more Shadow of Mordor purely for the joy of playing Puppetmaster with the Orc Meritocracy?\n\nThe honest answer is no.  While the Nemesis system is neat

reviewText:
This is an excellent open world action adventure game with a smooth and responsive combat system.

The visuals in this game are very solid, but the Uruk are what really stand out, and they did an outstanding job with all of the detail, especially in the facial animations. The world feels slightly barren at times, and there isn't a whole lot to look at in amazement, but then again it is a war-torn world which they did a good job at creating. There are two zones in the game, with the first being more barren and gloomy than the second zone you enter, which actually has a lot more plants, grass, and of course more Caragors.

The one thing that stands out the most in this game, is obviously the combat. It's basically a hybrid between the Batman: Arkham series, and Assassin's Creed. It's very responsive, and you have a few abilities that you're able to use. You have a main attack, a stun, a dodge and you can also slow down time while using your bow to pull off a couple easy headshots which can thin out the Uruk's. You can also counter-attack, which is extremely important while fighting large groups and helps significantly. There are also times when you can use your dagger to silently take out enemies from behind, or you can sneak behind them and brutalize them which can scare off 1-2 Uruk's which is always funny.

The rune system is also a great addition. Being able to add specific benefits to your sword, bow and dagger can give you offensive, defensive and just overall improvements to your character which you'll definitely need when fighting more powerful enemies. You also get a type of currency that's earned when completing side missions which you can use to upgrade characters health, how many arrows you can carry etc.

There's also a system called Power, that you can earn by doing the missions where you're sent to kill a specific Uruk, usually a captain. After getting enough Power, you can choose an ability to unlock, which is basically like a talent tree system that unlocks new abilities as you get further down the tier which give you some of the most powerful abilities in the game. Since you'll be killing massive amounts of Uruk's, you should have no shortage of Power. Also, expect to die, at least earlier on in the game. If you get overwhelmed, and there's a captain, or sometimes 3 in the mix, things can get bad very quickly. Also rage inducing, but still funny when you're killed and get taunted by said Uruk, and then seeing him get promoted just makes you want revenge all that much more. However, branding Uruk's, which allows you to basically control them allows you to cause a lot of mischief and cause infighting which is always a great advantage to have.

The story in this game is fairly good. I wasn't blown away by it, but it kept my interest. If you find all the collectibles in the game, they add more lore to check out. The main characters are pretty decent, but I though they could've been fleshed out a little more. I did find the only Dwarf character Torvin to be funny though, but it seems like they always are in most games.

Overall, if you're into this style of game I highly recommend it. It incorporates straight up combat, mixed with stealth elements very well.

More twist but story lacks depth

Cons:

Lord of Hunt:

3. Looks like original developer concept only released as DLC

reviewText:
This game was something I admittedly didn't think would be very good, but after playing it through 100%, I can honestly say it was worth the time.

The combat alone was worth the price to play, and even though there are side quests and things to do, they tend to get a little tedious, so the combat helps to keep it fresh.

The game plays like Assassin's Creed and the Batman Arkham games. There's bonuses given for freeflowing moves (there's only one attack button for melee) but this means simply not getting hit and stunning your enemies to keep the combo meter counting. As you unlock abilities, you get to spend points on abilities that allow you to perform special moves every time you get 8 uninterrupted hits (5 with an upgrade). The combat is just hard enough to keep you on your toes, but not so hard that you want to quit. Every now and then you get hit with a QTE that takes you by surprise, but there's nothing crazy (like God of War or Casltevania Lords of Shadow).

The ability system is two-fold, and veterans to any series that puts RPG elements with hack-n-slash knows that the primary system for becoming stronger is to spend some sort of currency. In this game, there's both. A currency system is used to buy health and focus upgrades, carry more arrows, add slots to your weapons for runes, etc. While an XP system is used to unlock various abilities. The abilities will generally unlock over the course of the game, but there's also incentive to go off and maul orcs on your own... the higher tiers are unlocked as you earn Power. Power is earned by killing orc captains and warchiefs, settling power struggles, or even avenging the death of your friends. As you complete these missions you will gain access to stronger abilities that don't outright OP your character, but make battles where you are clearly outnumbered a little easier.

The ranking system for Sauron's army is a little tedious and repetetive, but it's so in a very pleasing way. As you progress, you will gain access to intel" which allows you to get information about the captains in Sauron's army
date: as well as their strengths and weaknesses. Killing captains will affect the state of the army and allow you access to some of the more powerful warchiefs
recommended: each which drop their own special prizes. As you progress
hoursPlayed: you can even command your own orcs and have them battle each other. When an orc kills you
voteText: he gets promoted and is identified in the army so you can exact your revenge. The possibilities are endless... literall
helpfulPercent: as the army can never be fully wiped out.\n\nThere's much more to say
votesHelpful: and I've said a lot already
votesTotal: so you should just go play the game already!"

reviewText:
Shadow or Mordor is simply a fun and well-made action game. You will fight, slash, stab, shoot, throw. Sometimes you will devour while mounted on a beast. Other times you will mind control. Some other times again you will mind control a captain to kill another captain.  The game ultimately ends up as a sandbox experience, an uruk-manipulation-simulator where you have tons of fun trying to come up with new ways to mess with and kill these silly not very smart, yet tough creatures.

Best part of the game is the personal touch it gets when an orc kills you and mocks you afterwards. He gets a name, a promotion, a mental and physical personality, and you can seek him out for revenge. If you don’t succeed, you will be farther mocked an insulted, which feels great!

The game succeeds in letting you feel as an ultimate bad-♥♥♥, especially as your skills grow during the game. You end up so insanely overpowered after a while, that only a few enemies remain a challenge. But at this point the game is still very fun to play, as you will be toying around with the above mentioned uruk-manipulation. The fighting looks and feels really great (played with a controller), and the amount of graphic detail is outstanding.

The open world offers lots of content, and I especially enjoyed collecting all the artifacts as they provided smaller stories, related to the lore of Lord of The Rings itself. I even liked collecting all the mushrooms and flowers. Cozy.
It amazes me however that the main story of this game is so shallow, when everything else is pretty great. The cinematics of the game are top notch and really fun to watch. The voice acting is superb. Certain smaller sub-quests aren’t that bad either, while the main story simply isn’t very interesting and appears unengaging and below average. It’s strange, when the game otherwise shines, developers obviously knew what they were doing regarding everything else in the game.

Despite the unmotivating main story, I still highly recommend this game for its great action and the orc manipulation system. The latter is something entirely new in the modern world of gaming.

reviewText:
TL;dr? This is effectively Batman, Arkham Asylum set in the Lord of the Rings 'verse.

This isn't something bad. This is, to be honest, quite fantastic as the combat mechanics from the Batman games (Barring the latest one) is fantastic. The combat may not be perfect (there are peices of the terrain that will abruptly stop you from moving when the majority of other structures makes you parkour around like a man on speed and crack.

For those of you who are mechanically gifted, as in you can keep all your keys in your head and not get confused with what buttons do what, you near literally can not be stopped. The captains are a nice mechanic to fight and them being able to level up is a fascinating mechanic that is fun to fight against. even if you fail and they finish you off, they come back stronger, giving you more rewards if you kill them. Leading to an interesting dynamic of letting them kill you to make yourself more powerful. If they kill people from your friends list, you can even avenge their deaths. Everything about them gears you up to becoming more powerful and dangerous.

The last stand mechanic, letting you recover yourself even if you ♥♥♥♥ up or miss-press a button, is nicely difficult without being overly stressful and damaging your enjoyment of the game over soemthing cheap seeming. This game continuously aims to reward you if you can pull yourself out of a bad situation.

Coupled with an excellent feat/abililty system that empowers you without giving you an 'I win button', instead making you stronger while expecting you to still use skill or finesse.

I again seriously can't recommend this game enough.
