reviewText:
All right, yes this, even with all the things i have to say about it is a positive review. You should get Shadow of Mordor. IF IT GOES ON SALE!!!
This game, is really fun. They have a great engine, its Lord of the Rings related so thats a plus, they have awesome features like their famous 'Nemesis System', and everything. I Have no complaints about what they put into this game.
My complaint is that they did not put in enough. They only made two small maps, only a total of 20 story missions, limited real side missions. I feel that the y could have easily created extra minor storylines or other things which gave it a more in depth feel.
Bottom line: Get this game when it goes on sale, so you get what you pay for.
If you get it, get it along with the season pass, you will get bored without those DLC's

reviewText:
It's like Assassins Creed in the world of Lord of the Rings. The game mechanics are amazing and so fun, it's such an addictive game at the start, I didn't even bother with the story when I got the game, but eventually I thought it was time to play the main story, and I started disliking what I saw. The story given to the game is poor and short, it merely takes half a day to complete the entire game if you just played the story non-stop. Other than the story being completely off road from what Tolkien wrote, if you are a fan of Lord of the Rings or the Hobbit, you will hate this story with all your heart.

Gameplay Mechanics : 10/10, simply outstanding.
Storyline and Quests : 3/10, repetitive, boring and misleading.
Graphics and Ambiance : 9/10 beautiful.

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor is a hybrid Batman/Assassins Creed game set in the LoTR universe. It looks lovely, plays wonderful and is very addictive. Fans of any of these would probably like it.

The combat is very similar to the Batman games. bar some key mapping changes I would go as far as to say it's almost an exact copy infact, so anyone familiar with the system will be right at home here. It's smooth, engaging and rewarding. A button-masher this IS NOT. Stealth works nicely alongside this system to give you several options for taking down the enemy. You even get some ranged weapons in the form of your elven counter-part's bow - using Elf Shot".

The story seems fairly well devised and sits nicely within the LoTR universe. it oozes Tolkien from the get-go and it's wonderful to be playing a LoTR game that is actually good. Voice acting is also top-notch

reviewText: A cautious recommendation. So-So story which only appeals to major LOTR followers and fans. Riding mechanics seem a little bit choppy. Other than that, the game is a solid entry to the LOTR game universe, probably being the best LOTR video game to date. A great blend of Assassin's Creed and Batman Arkham, giving an excellent, responsive, and badass combat system. Nemesis system is a revolutionary mechanic that makes this game stand out. Two medium-sized open world areas, filled with stuff to do and orcs to slay. Plenty of fun.

reviewText:
Sunder Sauron's army as Talion, the wraith-possessed ranger of the Black Gate embarked upon a quest of vengeance.

PROS:

+ the nemesis system(brutal powerplay between elite uruks; you can assist/slay orc officers as they attempt to rise to the rank of warchief)
+ free roaming(similar to AC series)
+ combat(similar to Batman Arkham series)
+ various methods of completing mission objectives
+ well-used source material

CONS:

- the beast riding is rather tedious and feels like a chore

I loved every minute spent in the game(except for those few beast riding moments).
Even though I'm usually no completionist, I found completing side missions and finding collectibles fun and rewarding. The overall quality of the game surprised me, since most LotR universe games which I had experience with so far were mediocre at best.
Until the Shadow has been cast over Mordor.

reviewText:
A really fun game, gameplay is similar to the assassin's creed series, but it just seems more fun than that. The enemy captain / nemesis system is amazing and adds depth and flavour to the game (♥♥♥♥ The Poet).

There's a lot of lore and backstory in the game, and even if some of it isn't canon, it's still a treat for any LoTR fan.

Main campaign is about 25 to 30 hours long and there's 2 other shorter campaigns you can play. 2 NPC's and the uruk captains stand out, every other character is kinda forgettable. Overall a good game that's worth getting on a sale.

reviewText:
Highly enjoyable, if a bit short.

PROS

- Very good, modern graphics.
- Fun combat, similar to batman (combo and parry) but much smoother.
- Fun exploration / sandboxing, similar to assassin creed but more natural and less repetitive.
- Kinda original with the nemesis system. (Dynamic orc captains with varied modifiers.)
- Nice dialogs. Never heard anyone repeat the same line twice, which is quite the feat.
- Nice achievements, fun to pursue, all doable in reasonable time. None of those usual kill a gazillion zombies" kind of mindless grind achievements.
- Really nice polish and attention to details. The developers know what they are doing.


CONS

- Only about 30 hours

reviewText:
Well, i had been looking forward to this game for quite a long time, it looked like it would be a mixture of assassins creed and the lord of the rings, which was always good.. The scenery looks amazing, the music is nice, and the story keeps you interested...
However that said, the story is very, very short... and then when finished, it does feel like you have only played about half of the game, DLC from the season pass should come out soon, but it does still leave you wanting more.
So after i finished the game after about 6 hours, i decided i would try and get the achievements, which are your standard, collect so many of this and kill so many of that, with the odd tricky one thrown in, freeing slaves is boring after the first island, as it is literally just going in and doing the same thing over and over again.
The nemesis system is all very well, and yes it is cool that if you are killed by an orc they become a captain and can then become a war chief, and still remember you and insult you like everyone else in the game, but the novelty soon wears off, and can be a bit of a pain if wanting a specific captain to go to a certain position, which you need to do on more than one occasion.
I do think that it is a very good game, if short, and DLC should extend the fun, it's just the landscape is all a bit samey, and it can seem a bit repetitive after a while.

reviewText:
Even if you're not a fan of Lord Of The Rings, you can still enjoy this game. A man on a mission to avenge his family by slaying Orcs in various ways! Whats not to love?
People have compared the combat to Assassins Creed but it's not quite the same, if the enemies start to gang up on you, you're done for unless you can escape and hide. Put simply, its less forgiving that AC games.

The game also manages to cater for different play styles, you can charge in with your sword, fight enemies from range with the bow, take the stealthy approach, picking them off 1 by 1 or combine all 3! If slicing, stabbing and shooting isnt enough for you, you can use the environment as well! Mounting beasts, releasing animals from cages, poisoning barrels of booze.... the list goes on!

The map is also fairly big which makes exploring fun, which is good because the game looks awesome! Slaying Orcs never looked so good!

reviewText:
Okay, since everyone compares this to Assassin's Creed / The Arkham games, I'll get the comparison out of the way first.

I DESPISE the Assassin's Creed games.  I've bought several of them for PC.  With each one, I'll play for a few moments, get completely tired of the movement and non-responsiveness of controls, and quit.  I've got like 20 minutes max in each AC game.

This game is not that.  The controls are exceptionally responsive.  The Nemesis system is going to change a LOT of games in the future.  The gameplay is fluid.  There's not much of a story, but there doesn't have to be.  You're dropped into an open-world arena full of orcs, basically, and you're expected to kill them.  Enjoy it.

I don't like AAA Titles very often, and I certainly don't like the 50-70$ price tag that comes with some of them, with on-release DLC.  DEFINTELY pick this game up if it's on sale.   And it's probably a solid buy at full price, too - I'm just a cheapo :P

Check it out.  It's interesting.  It's fun.  It has mechanics you've never seen in any other game before.  It's responsive.  It plays amazingly on keyboard and mouse OR on a gamepad.  It's a rare gem.  Period.

reviewText:
At the time of writing this review, I am 27+ hours into this game, with 18/20 story missions completed, all character upgrades attained, one army almost entirely decimated, another fully under my control, all collectibles found, and a handful of slave liberation missions completed.

If you enjoy high-octane action and adventure games that manage to hold up a good story, introduce innovative gameplay ideas, has amazing grapics, and performs well on the PC, then Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor is the game for you.

I have never been a massive fan of the LoTR series, so the story of this game was fresh to me (I knew not much more than the basics of the lore before playing) and strayed far enough away from the central plot of the books/movies while still including some major characters in the game. The story was not this game's strongest point, but it was still very good and kept me entertained until the game's conclusion.

You've probably heard of the Nemesis system if you have done any research on this game, and it deserves the hype. It genuinely adds to the gameplay experience, and offers fun and interesting twists to the gameplay. Captains who kill you in battle will grow in strength, gain followers, lose weaknesses, and get promoted. Fighting them but letting them escape will make their actual battle wounds prevalent in your next encounter, as well as unique contextualized dialogue between you and the captain. Sometimes, just like Talion (main character), a captain that you have killed will come hunt you down and challenge you to a rematch."

The most amazing thing about the nemesis system is how it creates real digital enemies who you will grow to hate (or admire if you dominate them). Very early into my play through

reviewText:
This game is amazing, if you're a big LOTR fan you'll love every tiny detail of it.
Pros:
+ Great combat inspired by the Batman Arkham games
+ Immersive
+ Huge map
+ TONS of side-missions and collectables

Cons:
- Although it has a great combat, it can be sometimes frustrating as ♥♥♥♥. You get stuck in the middle of animations and get hit. Sometimes you get combo-ed to death.
- Story is average and predictable
Speaking of the story: The ending... WHAT THE ACTUAL ♥♥♥♥? It looks like they cut the story in half and will deliver the rest via DLCs
- Pathetic last boss fight

Overall, this game is great, it's fun and beheading Uruks never gets old. You'll spend a lot of time searching orc packs just to fight them for fun. Planning attacks/betrayals/initiations is interesting and rewarding. Nemesis system is what makes this game stand out so much from the rest, it works well but it can be improved (and hopefully it will) a lot. It made me really angry at specific Uruks and killing them was really enjoyable. I'd give this game a 9/10, but after beating it and seeing that ending, I will give it a 7.5/10. Still, I think everyone should get this game.

reviewText:
Hello everyone. Time for me to go into another review!

(This part might hold some minor beginning story spoilers.)Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is an open world RPG style game in which you play as the Gondorian Ranger Talion, one of the only remaining soldiers to guard the Black Gate. The beginning story is a little sharded and fragmented as the game needs to hold true to canon, but hey that's what you get for having a game with an already pre-determined lore, right?
Anyway, the Black Hand of Sauron sacrifices Talion and his entire family as a sort of curse for reasons I don't really understand...I mean he sacrificed you and your family to become one with the wraith himself but instead it went inside you, and now you have all of the skills that this king had in life. Why exactly did it go to you and not him? That's not explained, but whatever, the rest of the story's still good.
Your job now is to, as an undying super soldier of Gondor, hunt down Uruk and Orc captains/warchiefs and use some super magic mind reader magic to find out what they know about other captains and warchiefs and the Black Hand, so you can find him and make him undo the curse so you can find rest.


Now how's the controls and gameplay in the game? Honestly, I want to say good, but I feel they could've used A LOT of work! The controls are choppy and hard to manage, and require quite a bit of controller finesse in order to get you through a simple doorway. Considering how fast paced and merciless this game's combat is, I'd like to have some very polished, crisp controls to at least not make my controller be a handicap. That'd be great!
Sometimes your character will also decide to just do his own thing; Lets say an enemy Orc is to your right on the screen, and there's another to the left. Let's say you want to attack the one on the right first. So you push the control stick to the right and push X. 8/10 the character will go for the right...But 2/10 he'll go up down or left...Now that might not be such a big deal, but when the aforementioned enemy on the right is charging up for an attack with you having only enough HP for 1 more hit, and your character doesn't stop him? That has made me throw my controller on occassion. It's a death,  which shouldn't have happened. Hardware should never be a wall between you and game progress.

Your character also seems very fond of walls...There's a sneak feature(Really cool btw, I LOVE the Stealth in this game), which lets you slink around corners and stuff, and pull off some pretty impressive Neener nee you didn't see me! *Sticks tongue out!*" moments

reviewText:
I will say right off the bat, that I mostly play MMOs. Not many single player games can pull me in. The other day I sat down, turned on this game, and for 6 hours I could not exit. I didn't want to get off. I figured I should sleep so I did. I don't play it every day, but when I do I can't put it down. The Arkham series was my all time favorite single player game, but this one has taken that over. I am crappy at reviews but here ya go:

First off, I heard the last boss fight sucks, that its to easy. I haven't got that far yet as of typing up this review. But honestly,  I don't really care. The game is extremely enjoyable, the amount of content for a single player game is awesome. The story seems to be fairly short as there is only 20 missions in it, but if you do all the side stuff, its very lengthy. Would I recommend this game to someone that only wants to do the main story and none of the side stuff? I would say No. This game really feeds off doing side missions, messing with the nemesis system  and whatnot. Building up your weapons, purchasing abilities, etc.. Its just all around a great game to get lost in.

Speaking of purchasing abilities, the system is good and all, but almost 14 hours in I think and I almost have all the abilities purchased that is available. The only reason I bring this up, is because I think that its bad. It reduces customization options. What I mean is, it don't really matter where you put the points cause you will end up having them all anyway. Know what I mean? At this point I just slap a point in, see what I got and go on my way. I just love deep customization, but that won't knock points off from me.

All around its an amazing game. Would I change anything? Honestly no. I do hate stealth and am TERRIBLE at it (terrible hardly explains it) but in this game its rather easy so far. It may get more difficult, I don't know, but its not a hard system in this game. Its very simple and straight forward. At this point, the Arkham series had harder stealth areas than this game does and I managed that one fine.

Ok ending this here. Hope it helps out some, probably not :D

reviewText:
Clunky and awkward keyboard and mouse controls combine with hyper twitch happy fighting gameplay. That said, the game looks amazing, and the is incredibly engaging. My first foray went 6hrs, of which I should have been asleep 4 lol. The story and gameplay engage you right off the bat and you pretty much immediately fall into a 'just let me get this one more thing done' mindset.

The fighting mechanisms are pretty impossible to master, unless you take enough speed to dilate time, but at the same time, are simple manage to be simple enough to allow you to succeed in most combat situations.

The nemesis system is easily the most interesting and frustrating aspect of the game. Letting an Uruk kill you two or three times can make them nearly unkillable, combine that with their frustrating ability to mob you with 3 or 4 of these captains all at once and it can get really obnoxious. Even captains that aren't anywhere near your fight seem to magically teleport to you. That said, it really helps to engage you and add to the satisfaction of finally putting them down hard.

As icing on this rather delicious cake, we get to explore an area and time frame previously never expanded upon in Tolkien lore. In this the game offers several methods to increase the immersion factor, finding artifacts with memories bound to them, NPCs, even the wraith you're bound to. The player is constantly hit with in game conversation, and information.

All in all this is one seriously damned fine game and can be equally fun and infuriating. DEFINITELY a worthy buy on a decent sale price.(I'm cheap I wont spend $50 on a digital copy of a game for anyone)

This is a really fun game. I was quite pleasently surprised. Of course it helps, if you really like the world of Middle-earth. The game is basically a playground to mess with orcs. Seriously, I spent quite a lot of time just messing with the captains and orcs, instead of doing quests.

It was funny and awesome at the same time. SPOILER: Plus he became on of the bosses at the end, which was like a high school reunion. Hey, you're that guy I kept shoving in the locker. Good times!! END SPOILER.

I think that if you enjoy the LOTR movies, you'll also enjoy this.

Edit: Ok, update on the difficulty of the game. Play the Bright Lord dlc, the game gets hard. Sure it's lowered if you use the One ring power, but when it's gone. And all those berserkers and defenders. I really suck at dodging..... Ugh. Great game.

reviewText:
I am happily surprised with how satisfied i am with this game. I'm not a Lord of the Rings fan at all, but just bought this game on a whim. It was the hype game of the month and i said why the hell not, and took a leap of faith, and it paid off ten-fold. I love it when i by a masterpiece on accident.

The game's story isn't really what keeps me engaged, but it is compelling enough not to want to skip. The voice acting by Talion is spot on. The game plays like Batman Arkham City meets Assassin's Creed, and builds on both formulas both in traversing the environment and combat. Like in the batman arkham games, the combat is extremely simple with some extremely complex mechanics buried within it, that makes for an intriguing and addicting thing to get into. I know there are story missions, but there's just something about simply killing hundreds of uruks all day and all night that just loses me.

The game runs beautifully too, this is by far one of the most gorgeous games I've ever played. It makes Tomb Raider look like an old Xbox 360 game.

My only minor gripe is with Warner Bros and their blocking of posting content published by them on YouTube, but if you don't mess with that kind of thing, then that doesn't even cocern you. This isn't the most innovative game in the world, but it feels like it's own game. Despite it borrowing mechanics from other games, it borrows them the right way, taking what made them fun, and throwing some middle-earth spice in the pot.

This hands down one of my top games of this year, based on my first few hours of playing the game alone. You know this game is a masterpiece within the first hour of play.

For a game that i never even remotely considered buying until it showed up in my queue a few days ago, I'd say this was the most satisfying blind purchase of $70 (with the season pass) I've ever spent. Buy this game now. Saving up for another game? Who cares. Buy this anyways. There's a 75% chance this game will end up being better than whatever it is your saving up for. The best part is, you can tell this game wasn't intended to be as good as it is. It's ironic that we live in a world where overhyped games are just that, overhyped, while the ones that fly under the radar turn out to be some of the greatest games you'll ever play.

reviewText:
Disclosure: I hated this game when I first bought it. Made four attempts (three reinstalls) to play it over more than a year to finally finish the game, with the first three attempts not making much progress from the beginning of the game.

The trailers and reviews misled me to different expections of this game. I wanted it to be the epic console action game I thought it would be, but it never lived up to the reviews.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=433522104
Review: Beautiful graphics and cutscenes aside, the game has progressive missions/objectives that tell the compelling prequel story to Lord of the Rings, specifically the forging of the rings of power and the one ring.

The game is entirely combat based, and the combat is fluid and entertaining as long as it's paced out, and this was the key to my finally finishing the game.

I went into this game wanting to be Aragon or Legolas, cleaving my way through every mission. While that worked initially, fights became tedious quickly when I came across areas marked as Strongholds. Alarms can be raised in strongholds which results in seemingly endless waves of orcs. A simple single objective mission with the goal right in front of you can end up with you fighting orcs until your thumbs become sore. And the same combat which had been fun would become a chore and turn off.

That's when I readjusted my expectations. Until one unlocks most of the powerful abilities, the game is for most part a stealth game. Sneak around, go to the objective and kill a few orcs. I actually like stealth games, and this game has a system where you can exploit the weaknesses of orc captains so stealth play is not all that dull or one dimensional.

Final Words: The DLCs merely extend gameplay, with nothing new story wise, but the main game easily provides 20-30hrs of content with a story worth playing for fans of the LOTR movies.

reviewText: I recommend this game if you like open worlds, slaughtering orcs by the dozens like some sort of crazed demon, if you like creating your own personal army of mind slaves hidden in the ranks of your enemy's army sent to destroy you-then get this game. The DLCs for it add a nice amount of content, too. I didn't like the Bright Lord DLC as much as I enjoyed the Lord of the Hunt DLC. Mainly because the Bright Lord sort of limited my abilities in combat, so it was less varied. I imagine it was done to keep in line with the fact that you were playing as newly powered up Celebrimbor and not his man-shadow creature hybrid he became years later in the main game, but after experiencing the thrill of freedom that the Lord of the Hunt showed me (seriously-check that DLC out. the combat, the enemies, the missions, the new area-I loved ALL of it) kind of spoiled me and made me sort of resent the limitations imposed by the Bright Lord. Still, all around a fantastic game!\nThe nemesis system is my favorite part. Not even the combat (reminds me of a murderous Batman combat system) compares to how much I love the nemesis system. Fighting leaders in the enemy armies and enslaving their minds or just gathering information from them and killing them so that one of my mind slaves ranked lower than my fresh victim can take his place-it's amazing. If you get into a scuffle and have to retreat, they'll remember you and be less scared in the future. Get murdered by some random shmoe? Well, now he's a Captain and is more powerful. Each time that someone kills you they get stronger and less scared of you. Some of the stronger leaders require a strict tactical approach to defeat. Mid-late game it becomes incredibly difficult to take out some of the top tiered bosses. They usually have bodyguards who are a rank or 2 lower than them and also leaders with special abilities. Killing or converting the bodyguards before taking on the main guy becomes a must, because there's no way you want to take all of them on at once in their stronghold surrounded by an enormous amount of reinforcements. The nemesis system alone adds a ton of replayability to the game and I'd like see it used in games in the future somehow.\nTo sum it all up, even if you're not a fan of the Lord of the Rings (in any of its many forms or variations), this is a great game with the combat and nemesis system alone making it worth checking out.

reviewText:
Synopsis: Middle Earth is set in the lands of Modor set  between the Hobbit and LOTR telling the story of a man who has been cursed into the wraith world seeking the revenge for him and his familys death at the hands of Sauron's army.

Yea!
-Gorgous graphics
-Fluid and responisive comabt that is a blast to play
-Nemesis system is awesome

Meh!
-Average story
-Once you unlock a good deal of upgrades the game becomes way too easy
-Final two missions are major letdowns
-The amount of hidden collectables is at just the right amount

Bleh!
-Campaign is very short at about 15 hours
-Enemy AI is extremely stupid, but this may be a intentional as Orcs are suppose to be dumb
- Quciktime events involving moving the marker to the circle seemed very unresponsive for me

Lowdown:


The combat follows that of Batman/Assassins Creed series, but at a more responsive state. You will not need to finish animations to get in that counter or dive out of the way of danger. It is a blast to play, countlessly beheading your enemies. While busting headfirst into the fray can be fun, you can quickly become overrun by a ton of Orcs, which could lead to death. But do not worry after a few levels you will be extremely powerful and rarely see death. So the best way to take care of your enemies is to pick em off via your bow from a distance or to stealth kill them. Stealth is extremely easy to accomplish, as you can  pretty much pass right in front of enemies from a short distance away without too much detection. This could be intentional due to Orcs being pretty dimwitted though by the developer.

The highlight of the game is its Nemesis system., where foes that kill you will rise in power and level up to captains in Sauron's army. These captains will also taunt you every time they meet you recalling past moments of your battles in quick one liners.  There hasn't been a moment in gaming in a while that I was so satisfied to have killed a captain that had been endlessly harrassing me for ages. With a ton of enemy captains out there in the army with random strengths and weaknesses you could just spend hours hunting just them down. they even eventually will get replaced by new ones for your endless slaughtering fun.

While I enjoyed the game there was just a few minor issues I had. One was the quicktime event where you have to position the left stick into a circle and press a button. I seemed to fail about 50% of these due to the fact that it seemed the icon moved to slow and by the time I got there I had no time to react. Upping the aiming sensitivity  seemed to help a bit, but still missed quite a few. And lastly the final two mission were extreme let downs, as they were nothing more then easy beat downs and quicktime events.

Verdict: While the game has a few short comings, it is a blast to play and easly worth a purchase. The season pass is still debatable at this point if it will be worth it

reviewText:
WHAT A GAME! Imagine for a moment a combination between Batman Arkham City and Assassin's Creed, combining the absolute best elements of both games, set in a delightfully unexplored period of Middle-Earth's Third Age, and with a persistent system of enemy progression and rivalry on top of everything.

That's this game. It looks amazing, it plays beautifully and fluidly, it will grab and hold you and keep you playing and make you curse that one snivelling orcish shrakh that keeps killing you and getting promoted. The music is terriffic and the whole thing makes great use of its lore and mythology.

That's my favourite part by far. If you haven't read the Lord of the Rings books, or even if you HAVE but didn't bother with the extensive Appendices (or the amazing Silmarillion), this is probably the first time you will hear of Celebrimbor, Annatar, Fëanor or Gondor's unapologetic use of slave labor. This is probably how you will learn who Morgoth was (as in The Balrog of ...") and what the hell happened in Númenor
date: or how the Rings of Power were created. This game takes people who only know the movie events
recommended: and helps them delve deeper into Arda's extensive history and setting. It is invaluable in that regard
hoursPlayed: because so little popular media explores these aspects.\n\n10/10"

reviewText:
Middle Earth Shadow Of Mordor is an AWESOME game let me tell you why.

Pros:
1. Optimization - my GT 755m 2GB GDDR5, I7 4700MQ, & 8GB memory can run it on tweaked ultra with 20fps, or 30+ on medium/tweaked high 1600 X 900 resolution. For a middle class laptop that's pretty AWESOME!

2. Graphics - Even on low this game looks AMAZING, however I highly recomend NOT trying out ultra textures on a 2GB VRAM card as you may get slowdowns, freezes, crashes etc. I was lucky when I tried out high textures seems to go fine with my 2GB card.

3. Nemesis System - This literally is the best feature I HAVE EVER SEEN. Unless you beheaded a captain I found many captains coming back for my blood many of which succeeded in getting it. One captain and I went back and forth at least 7 times before finally getting him.

4. Gameplay - Story is very engaging and a lot of fun, you kill lots of Orcs like who doesn't love that, & unnatural powers that allow you to make a mess of Orcs and Mordor.

Cons:
My only nitpick is this game would be darned near perfect if we could play as an Orc and do political backstabbing and control large bunches of Orcs to do your bidding.

Conclusion - If you want to play a fun game based in Lord Of The Rings Lore that is bloody, but yet engaging at the same time pick it up at first oppurtunity.

Overall Rating - 9.5/10

reviewText: I want to start out by saying I have been playing Lord of the Ring's Action RPGs for a long time. This make all of them look terrible. This game ia amazing. The combat is fluid and as you unlock abilities becomes epic. Dealing with Orc captains and the like is fun as their attributes and weapons seem to be randomly generated. You may even help a no-name orc rise in the ranks by being killed by him. So the game is truly wide open in that repsect.  There are tons of things to do and there are always new missions added as the orcs progress through their promotions. They are power hungry and attack each other all the time. They also join each other to bolster their forces. Though be prepared to kill a boss two or three times..lol though after each time you vanqush them they become much more ugly.. If you enjoyed Assassin's Creed and Batman Arkham series pick this one up. Better combat than Batman IMO......and it's a fresh bit of Middle Earth history that has not been elaborated on.The story and acting are great and fresh. A gem this one here...

reviewText: Sleeper hit of 2014, I was really happy to see this game receive the praise and attention it deserved.  I am a big fan of the Tolkien IP and I was nervous this game was going to be another attempt to cash in on loyal fans purse strings.  I made an apprehensive day one purchase and could not have been more surprised by the quality and fun this game provided.  Shadow of Mordor is a mash up of Assassins Creed stealth approaches to enemies, with a lethal style of Batman combo combat.  One feature that I did not read in many reviews that I really enjoyed was going on revenge missions when an Orc captain killed one of your STEAM friends who were also playing the game.  I always made any orc who killed a fellow Ranger public enemy #1.  Of course as mentioned in every review the Nemesis system was a lot of fun and made my play-thru feel personal and special.  I am looking forward to seeing what WB and other developers do with it in future titles.

reviewText:
I really had a great time with the game.
I feel that they successfully nailed the atmosphere and feeling from Tolkien's books.

For some reason, the in-game save file time and the Steam playtime don't match (63 vs 55), but since I forgot the game running a couple times while I went to watch some Mentalist and stuff I guess it doesn't really matter much.

I'd describe the game as a mix between Batman and AssCreed in its game-play, with some QTE thrown in for good measure and a certain degree of freedom in how to approach the goals to complete missions.
I liked the sense of freedom given by the increasing unlock of abilities and runes for the weapons, which made the task of fighting a really pleasing part of the game thanks to how much more powerful the player can become overtime, going from having to flee if a group of orcs gang-up on you to fighting groups of captains and their bodyguards doable and fun.
Fighting is where the game reminded me of Batman, with combos, counterattacks and throwing knives, executions or special attacks once the counter has reached a certain point. The AssCreed vibes come from the parkour abilities and the stealth part of the game.

The game isn't really long. I spent 63 hours with it mostly because I kept playing side-missions instead of progressing the story initially and then going around killing orcs and playing in the power feuds part of the game, trying to gain more power to unlock skills, to get runes and to build my own army of orcs. This meant that I spent a big part of the game going around killing and getting killed for no other reason than my own fun, to get revenge for my deaths or the deaths of other players, to ruin the orcs gatherings etc... and I consider that a big plus for the game, since open ended kinda games tend to bore me after a while.

Aside from being a fun game, Mordor is also a very good looking game, both in the in-game graphics as well as the cinematic parts. I felt a certain lack of AA though, but I'll say that the... gritty and sharp look of the game was enjoyable more than distracting.
Music is another nice aspect of the game as well as the whole audio direction in the game. I loved how the name of a Commander would be chanted once he showed up and the Italian VA for the game was really good, with both nice voices and good acting.

QTEs are mostly the only sore part of the game for me. More than once I died because I was pushing the stick in the wrong direction initially as I miscalculated the point where it would pop up and the QTEs made the last 2 fights feel quite anti-climatic, though everything else more than made up for it.

All in all a fantastic experience.

reviewText: Middle Earth Shadow of Mordor is the new game based on Lord of the Rings series but will you want to play this ? In Middle Earth Shadow of Modor we play as Talion. One day Talion and his family is killed by the black hand to summon the wraith but gets himself fused with Celebrimbor who is suffering amnesia. So him and Talion try to find out who is Celebrimbor and to avenge the death of Talion's family. So how is this game ? This game is a fantastic game and everyone who needs to play through this game at least once. The game is like Assasins Creed and Batman Arham games fused together to create this. You can freely roam around the map and do what you like. Theres tons of stuff to do and lots of stuff to see. The game also looks really good maxed out. The gameplay is smooth and is really satisfying. Stealth is also really fun. The game is never too easy but never unfair and is a blast to play through. The game's story is fantastic and you get attached to the charecters and you do want to make it to the end which is not good. Yeah the ending to this game was dissapoiting and is sequel/dlc bait. The game also has bugs. Sometimes when jumping and grabbing onto the ledge my charecter wouldnt let go no matter what i did. The game is one of the best games i played in a while and i definetly reccomend getting this game and playing through it once. I give Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor a 9/10

reviewText:
Amazing yet repetitive game. Solid combat gameplay, amazing stealth and original captains and warchiefs mechanics. A flawless bug free game.

But it comes to a point that it is always the same thing over and over again. Find captains, slay or dominate and so on. Also after you get the hang of it and get all the core habilities, the game gets too easy and pointless. I finished the main storyline and that's it for me. I don't feel motivated to complete the game secondary tasks and quests. I won't even touch the DLCs.

Completing the story and playing around with this mechanic was enough and a nice experience overall. It took me around 20 hours.

Recommended.

reviewText:
It looks great, it runs great, it plays great...check this one out !

If you take the Batman Arkham series, throw it in a blender with the Assasins Creed series, squeeze all the best bits of them both (Third person, open world, climb over any building or obstacle, detective mode/eagle vision, free-flow combat and lots of exploration),then add a new mechanic that makes it unique...The Nemesis system, Middle-Earth Shadow of Mordor is what you will get.
Every time an enemy kills you or flees from you, they will be promoted to captain and you will encounter them again. These encounters happeen at the most epic times usually when you are making headway in another fight against another captain leaving you with three choices:
1 Run...♥♥♥♥ that, the combat is way too awesome to run away.
2 Take on two captains at once, sometimes more will show up too, the longer it takes you finish them.
3 If you die in a fight with more than one captain, they both get promoted.
Combat is awesome in this game, and coming from a massive fan of Batman & Assasins Creed, I would have to say this is probably even better.

It looks great, it runs great, it plays great...check this one out !

Highly reccomend this game to fans of Batman Arkham, Assasins Creed and Lord Of The Rings.

Check out my first impressions videos if you would like to see more:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rbQ7T-BuStY

Additionaly if you're into the LotR-verse, you can learn quite a lot about geography, species and other Middle-Earth things. Nonetheless it isn't 100% lore-friendly.

reviewText:
A very well made game.  I just finished it with about 35 hours into the game to get 100% completion.  I literally got lost in the game world for hours on end not doing any quests or missions, just fooling around in the open world Nemesis system.

You could complete the game much quicker, but you would be missing out on much it has to offer.

The voicework was top-notch and the soundtrack was very good as well.

Combat is very much like the Batman Arkham games.  Very fluid and smooth.  SImple to pick up but your skills and unlockable abilities give it depth the more you play and the animations are some of the best Ive ever seen!

Overall, the game is not perfect.  The game is a little easy most of the time and others its brutally difficult but this is mostly dependant on the players actions.  The story was a little short and simple, but it works and sets up for a sequel.  Also, there were two instances where I got stuck on an object and had to quick travel to get out of it.  The game ran flawlessly other than that on my modest PC on low/medium settings.  Zero crashes, graphical glitches and I played the game from day one.

9/10  highly recommended, bring on the DLC content now.

reviewText: Shadow of Mordor feels similar to the Assassins Creed and Batman games in the way that it plays. I enjoyed this more than both of those games however, mostly due to the excellent fluid sword combat. The Orc hierarchy system, in which Orcs who kill you rise through the ranks becoming increasingly powerful, is also unique and interesting. The world at first felt somewhat sparse, but plenty going on once you start exploring. Be warned, the game has a steep learning curve at times, but you can find a way to progress without too much difficult if you think laterally. For example, whilst I never really got stuck, I did encounter a particular Orc Captain who was practically invincible. Luckily none of the actual War Chiefs were quite so tough, so it didn't prevent me from progressing to the second greener setting in the game. Overall it's a fun experience with an okay story, pleasing graphics and presentation, that you will certainly enjoy if you are looking for an open world game of this type.

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor is a 3rd person Action-Adventure game from Monolith Productions, previously known for the excellent F.E.A.R. and the underrated Tron 2.0. In Shadow of Mordor, you play as Talion, a Ranger of Gondor stationed at the Black Gate.

For those looking for comparable games, one of the easiest comparisons would be the Arkham series also published by WB. The combat sticks closely to that model, using a combination of strikes, parries and dodges to help you get the edge on your enemies. Those that have played all the Arkham games may find the combat to be too easy due to their familiarity, however there is the option to turn off button indicators which can make things a little more difficult. Another close comparison would be the Assassin's Creed games, which the overall map stucture and parkour system borrows heavily from. Shadow of Mordor manages to blend a lot of the good aspects from these two game series to create an enjoyable new adventure.

The main innovation of Shadow of Mordor, and one we will most definitely be seeing in other game series in the future, is the Nemesis system. The majority of side missions in the game involves attacks on Uruk, and the subsequest consequences on their social structure. Regular Uruk are ruled by captains, who are ruled by chiefs. Every enemy captain you encounter is unique, with their own name, strenghts and weakness. They will remember their encounters with you, will remind you of any times they have defeated you in battle, and may even return from defeat to fight you another time. These can lead to some fun conflicts with Uruks who just can't stop coming back for more, each time showing new scars from previous battles. If a Uruk manages to defeat you, they increase in power and become more difficult to defeat the next time.

The story is very enjoyable, especially for a licensed game. The developers did themselves a favor by mostly using characters and a time period not explored in previous work. They were free to thell their own story, which they did well. In addition, the events in this game tie in nicely to all of the other Lord of the Rings material. You will get more background on how certain events before the films happened, and you will also see some set up for things that you do witness in the movies and books.

The graphics in Shadow of Mordor are remarkable. While I began the game with computer hardware that was beginning to show its age, the game scaled well so I could still have a usuable framerate while enjoying some of what the graphics had to offer. Upon upgrading my computer about halfway through my time with the game, I was treated to some amazing visuals and incredibly detailed characters. The landscape of Mordor is a little more varied than I was expecting after reading the books and watching the movies, but I am grateful that it wasn't all desolate wasteland.

The controls don't stray far from the usual 3rd person action formula. I found them very responsive, and never did I feel like it was difficult to pull off a button combination. This game could use a few less QTEs, but sometimes it is the only way to show off a particular set piece.

The music and voice acting is top notch. Fantasy voice work can get corny at times, but this game never felt that way.

Overall, I completely recommend Shadow of Mordor, not only for fans of Lord of the Rings, but for everyone. While the gameplay does borrow heavily from the Arkham and Assassin's Creed franchises, it uses the best from each. Shadow of Mordor also adds a new innovation to the genre, the Nemesis system, which is sure to show up in other franchises in the future. The story is enjoyable, the combat is smooth, and the graphics are great. Play this game.

Score: A

reviewText:
TL:DR- 9/10, It is worth the price, reasonable replayability, fun to play.


Positives:
Nemesis System- A fun and innovative addition that makes an above average game, great. Basically it is the political system of Uruks killing Uruks (Or killing you) to rise the ranks. If you let a lowly soldier finish you off they will rise in rank and power as the climb to the top.
Graphics- The game isn't meant to be the prettiest thing you have ever seen but it does look good.
Music- Fitting music to the soundscape, never found myself dreading the same theme in over 25+ hours of gameplay.
Gameplay- Alot of hack and slash action coupled with Quicktime based combat. It is fun enough to go out on the map and just kill random Uruks for fun.
Negatives:
Missions can become repetitive if you aim to complete them all.
Some map issues- Got caught in the environment a couple of times and fell through the map once, just minor annoyances.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Overview
---

According to the game, I'm 12% through the game. This game is filled with Assassin's Creed-like parkour, Batman Arkham Asylum/City/Origins-like combat, and it's more entertaining than ever. It's a hack and slash with amazing elements that you will most likely not find in any other game. Not only is this a Lord of the Rings game, which is a selling point for most fans, but it's combat is fluid and systems in the game is faultless.

I believe that this game will never get boring. The endless nemesis system is awesome, as many new captains come in, kill/hunt with each other, working their way up to legendary captains, which is their ultimate goal. Along the way, not only do orcs get attacked by your character, killing them after their fruitful efforts to reach the top, but also competing orcs. If an orc gets to a high enough power level, he will try to move up in rank...but some of the times that doesn't work, resulting in the loss of their lives and making the winner a target for the player.

You can get upgrades for your weapons in game, and also upgrades for your character and wraith abilities. You do missions to gather a currency to purchase more health, shots for your bow and arrow, and slots for your weapons. You have three weapons in the game, which all play crucial parts; the sword, the bow, and the broken sword, which functions as a dagger. The sword is for most melee combat, the bow is for taking out ranged troops and grunt ground troops, and the sword is for stealth kills.

Also, if you have friends who play the game, when you progress through the storyline, you unlock Vendetta waypoints. if you go to one of these, you have a chance to murder your friend's nemesis, which is the 'Uruk' that killed them most. This feature is awesome.

Pros and Cons
---

Pros-
-Great graphics, even on low
-Fantastic combat, gory and different every time, also challenging depending on your advantage in stealth
-Brilliant mechanics

Cons-
-The storyline's don't really line up. In the game, it takes place in between the end of the Hobbit book and before the Lord of the Rings trilogy. However, the enemies you encounter in the game are called Uruks, short for Uruk-Hai, which is Saruman's creation. This is before Saruman has begun working for Sauron, therein these 'Uruks' shouldn't be in the game.

I hope you appreciated my review, and I hope you buy the game. Add me if you do so I can avenge you from your nemesis! :)

EDIT:

Upon completing the game, I just wanted to warn you. The final battle isn't exactly a battle...You just press buttons to block attacks. But the rest of the game is great, there's two different maps you can travel around, adding to the adventure.

Graphics: 9/10 Beautiful scenery, gore, and orcs.

Gameplay: 8.5/10 Engaging Combat, Interesting Systems, Disappointing Last Boss Fight.

Controls: 9/10 Good Controls, easier with a keyboard and mouse than a controller. Keyboard Recommended

reviewText:
Killing Orcs Has Never Been So Fun!
I have to admit I come into this game knowing nothing about the The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit series. So the universe and the lores behind the movies or the novels mean nothing to me. I have to say, when I bought this game I did not buy it for the story, I just wanted a fun action game with tons of content and very addictive gameplay. I am happy to confirm I got what I wanted and it was more than overdose.

The first thing I want to address is that this game was made by Monolith Studio who also made the popular WWE series. It is strongly portrayed in the game by the way characters walk, tackle and performing actions which is really cool as it work perfectly well in a game where the world is dominated by the Orcs. When a warchief is making an entrance you get all the lesser orcs chanting out their name making them look badass and you get the sense of satisfaction by cutting off their head at the end and claiming that epic rune.

The game plays very smooth. It combines features from The Batman and Assassins Creed series but improves on the formula by having a deeper and better combat system, better stealth approach and wide array of interesting skills at your disposal. At certain point of the game I was actually really weak and was unable to defeat even an orc captain and was really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off about the game. However, as I dig deeper into the combat system and gained a few more levels I was able to finally defeat that nemesis that claimed my head countless of times. Speaking about revenge, the game introduced a very unique system called the 'Nemesis' system in which as player and time passes and evolves, the ranks within the orc army will also change. You soon learn that enemy AI behave extremely smart by roaming from place to place, killing superior orcs to gain power, dominate fellow orcs to earn an army and even ambush you when you were fighting other orcs. There will always be one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that always kill you becoming stronger each time and eventually raise in power to become a warchief. Furthermore, this system makes the AI memorise you so that the next time they meet you they come prepared with bodyguards as well as better equipments.

The game was also very intense from time to time with some battles lasting way longer than 10mins as waves of orcs swarming in I find my self unable to escape or rather, the manliness inside me tells me to face them head on and after killing near hundres of orcs and gained a few powerful runes it results in a very satisfying warm little fuzzy feeling inside.

After 20 or so hours into the game, the epicness is really showing as the world  totally opened up to you and you pretty much gained most of the abilities helping you to dominate the orcs in any situation. You can ride a caragor into battle and you can even ride a Graug to siege an entire orc fortress which was absolutely mind blowing. On top of this the game graphics looks absolutely beautfiful with very detailed graphics options. However, to have the graphics setting set to ultra high you will need a high - end pc to play it.

When I was using a Razer blade with GTX 765m I can play on high setting with about 40-50 fps. With a Alienware m18x dual GTX 560m I get about similar results and with my desktop with R9 290X I can play on ultra with 60fps no problem. So it is fair to say that this game is well optimised. To top it all off, the game comes with a photo mode helping you to capture every moments of glory and it has many features that you can play around with to capture some really beautiful eye candy.

Final verdict 10/10
I believe that this game is my game of the year 2014, as 2014 hasn't been a great year for gaming I think that shadow of Mordor really do stand out from the rest and it is packed with tons of content as well as delivering a satisfying experience to fans of the series or action game lovers alike.

tl;dr
+Fun combat mechanics
+Satisfying orc slaying mayhem
+interesting set of skills / passives
+blend stealth with action really well
+Gorgeous Graphics
+Tons of content
+Addictive and challenging
-skins offer no new voices (Every skin uses Talion's voice)
-Season pass doesn't offer much content

P.S. I have played about 30hours some were played in offline mode because I had no internet for a few days so the record on steam is wrong. within the 30hrs of game time I completed all the main missions, side quests (except killing all orcs), found all collectibles and learned all the skills as well as the passives.

reviewText:
Combat Pros: Whether you choose stealth or the walking mayhem approach You always feel like a powerful combatant. Arkham esque. Brutally violent. Every execution could be it's own Slayer album cover.

Combat Cons: After several hours of playing it can become a bit dull and repeatative.
----
Story Pros: It's brief and unobtrusive. Often in games that let you choose your playstyle the story parts have your character doing things that you've avoided doing for hours of gameplay. (in farcry 3 I played very stealthy and yet in every cut scene this kid was running around screaming his head off like an idiot)

Story Cons: The story is generic and kind of flat. Which isn't to say it's bad but some people may be expecting a lotro/hobbit epic adventure and it's not really that.
----
Why should I not just wait until this game is $10 on steam sale?: Quite simply, the world they created is stunning. The Nemesis system is by far one of the single most interesting mechanics added to the Assassins Credd/Batman games since they added boats to the Assassins Creed series. I completed the game in just over the minimum completion time which is not a feat by any means but what is impressive is that after I did that I spent the next 5 hours watching how the nemesis system played out. Sometimes I would kill my own guys to create a power vaccum just to see who took over. It's truly fascinating. Sometimes you'll find a weird little Orc that you just have to back in their power play because they're such a weird dude. When one guy kills you it beccomes a personal vendetta. Unlike quick time events I hope the Nemesis gets picked up by every game maker because it just helps give the player a vested interest in the world they occupy.

reviewText: I would describe this as a cross between the Batman games and Assassin's Creed, with a bit of interesting new stuff thrown in.  First, it looks beautiful, the graphics are a joy to behold.  The combat is fun, similar to the Batman games.  As you progress, you pick up enough new abilities, that slicing through a horde of Uruks just never gets old.The Assassin's Creed reference I mentioned is how your character moves though the areas.  There is a lot of climbing and perching above your prey and attacking from above, which, like the combat, never seems to get old.\nBut what really makes this game shine is the Nemesis system.  You really feel like these are real Uruks you are killing, all with different weaknesses and strengths and widely varied appearances.  You can join in on a power struggle between Orc captains and influence who wins.  As the captains and warchiefs gain power, they get promoted and move up in ranking.  Also, if some random orc kills you, he automatically gets promoted to captain, and has a name and gains a little armor to alter his appearance.  You can then kill him for a vendetta.  It is a very engaging system and honestly, I had a great time just trying to kill the captains and wreak havoc among their leadership.  It's great fun!

reviewText: Not sure what I thought of this game coming into it, seemed a little barebones and the Assassins Creed style objectives structure seemed like it was going to be filler, which it was, but what I did like the look of was the Nemesis system. Without that layer of personalisation to a players experience with the game, this title would've been completely mediocre and totally lacking in substance. I gotta say, I completely walked away from the story segments of the game just to ♥♥♥♥ around with the Nemesis system and it was alot of fun, the story itself was extremely lacking. By the time I came back to the story missions I'd maxed out my abilities for the most part, only came back to the story to unlock abilities like branding which was a whole new level of fun! In short, it's just fun to play the game, sure the combat may be simple but it's for show and if you combo your abilities like a ♥♥♥♥ing boss, you look like a badass and naturally send Uruks running in all direction. If you really want a challenge, handicap yourself by not taking health upgrades and such, some captains and warchiefs will one shot you, given the right traits. Overall, decent game, but what it brought to the table with the Nemesis system is some serious potential to influence greater AI systems and objectives in future titles.

reviewText:
This game...
Oh my God.
Hory ♥♥♥♥♥.
It is the most epic thang evah,
Who doesn't want to teleport into 5 orcs and kill them all with a wraith in amazing graphics and brutal deaths?
It is an insane game, though the story is 10 - 15 hours, there is a lot of other stuff to do, brand all the Warchiefs/Captains etc.
Besides that there are multiple challenges to complete, such as hold a bridge from constant waves of enemies for 3 minutes without letting a torch bearer through. With a 550 Mirian reward; such challenges really make you push for those 2500 upgrades, which I have one of. You would think that getting those upgrades would make the game too easy, in a way it does, but it makes it so much more epic. Before you were worried about those spear and shield guys, and those dual-wielders right? Not anymore, activate the Sword of Urfael and brand them all instantly and have them turn on the Captain and other orcs (who then get rekt).
While it makes it easier with those upgrades it also gives you a much larger set of options to complete certain tasks and missions. No longer do you have to sneak about and kill EVERY archer before you go in, for fear of getting shot. Go around and brand a few then charge in and brand everyone with the ability, making it a 15v1 on the Captain :P

This game is amazing, after so few hours I still have a lot to do and cannot wait for the DLC's where you can play as Celebrimbor and the extra missions.

reviewText:
I normally don't write reviews, as normally people have already said what needs to be said about games. That is probably the case with this game as well, but I enjoyed this game enough for me to put my 2 cents in.

I didn't think I would like this game. In fact, when I first seen that this game was another LOTR game, I was turned off instantly. I can only think of one other good LOTR game (personal opinion of course) as games that pull from this IP or any movie / book IP always seem to fall short on quality. This game is a huge exception.

Watching the trailer I got excited. It really seemed like a solid mix of Batman / Assassin's Creed, and I love both of those games- at the same time it looked like a rip off. How could this game be mechanically better than either of those games? While not necessarily mechanically better than either, it is different enough from both and what they do offer as far as combat mechanics is satisfying and feels great.

Stealth elements are not as fleshed out as assassin's creed, so don't get hyped over stealth mechanics. They are not bad, but the meat of the gameplay comes from the solid combat system which is where this game truly shines. When you enter combat, combos are smooth and flashy, and the system succeeds at making you feel like a true badass.

That last point is probably where this game really hits the nail on the head for me. No other game lately has made me feel so unstoppable- so powerful and badass. I can go into fighting a hoard of Orcs right in the middle of a stronghold and have a blast just battling waves of enemies. It has yet to get old! The combat is something I enjoy with a passion. That being said, while earlier in the game it can be more difficult than later on, I do wish there were ways to increase the overall difficulty.

The core of the game revolves around fighting Captains and Warchiefs which have different stats and abilities. The game gives you tools which can make fighting strong captains and warchiefs easier, but most of the time you can do the same combo to take them out. Sometimes they can block your initial stun, but then you just role over them and hit them from behind with your stun and continue your combo. Sometimes they can block your stun and block your roll over them. Then you have to start thinking outside the box, especially if they have the Combat Master buff. The truth is, once you unlock more abilities and skills, combat becomes more of a slaughter than a battle or challenge. I wish that there were stronger Captains / Warchiefs that were so strong that you HAVE to use their fears or other mechanics against them.

Overall I would say that this game (FOR ME) is a no brainer. I would buy it again- in fact, I will probably get the season pass just so I can enjoy the upcoming DLC. There are not many games I go back too- especially in this day and age where I have 100 games to play and only time for a hand full of them. This game however, I will be finding any excuse I can find to play more of it. I have already beat the story mode, and I am now having a blast going through self made scenarios or goals that I make. Do I feel like killing every Captain / Warchief on the map? How about mind controlling all of them? How about I go get revenge on a captain who happened to get a cheap kill on me earlier? The story is really yours to craft, and that's probably one of the biggest highlights of this game. The Shadow of Mordor sandbox has all the tools you need to make your own fun.

My last point will be regarding what the game calls the Nemesis System. This is probably one of the cooler aspects of the sandbox and truly brings a lot to the table. It adds a lot of personality to the Orcs, and gives every Orc / Captain / Warchief a little uniqueness and personality. Captains will remember you and mention past encounters you may have had. Orcs don't always look different, but there are certainly many varieties of Orc to keep it mostly random, and each have their own quirks that makes them one of a kind. It's something that I really appreciate, and one of the reasons I wish the game was harder. I hardly got a rival" or an Orc that was too hard for me to beat. I would say there was only one Orc in particular through my entire playthrough that killed me twice
date: but that was before I knew you could upgrade your max health!\n\nOverall this game was completely worth it. I had a great time playing it
recommended: and I recommend it for those of you who enjoy the Lord of the Rings setting
hoursPlayed: and a good action game. The only true improvements I could think of is adding difficulty options
voteText: mod support
helpfulPercent: and more customization
votesHelpful: but what we do have is excellent. I think many would agree."

reviewText:
If you are even slightly into Lord Of The Rings, then this is the game for you. After completing the main campaign (which is brilliant in itself, a really damn good story), I can safely say that I will continue to put my time into the side missions and other activities in Mordor.

Extremely fun gameplay.
Stealth elements.
'Batman-Like' combat, which is a very good thing.
...and lots and lots of gore.

The only slight issue with the game is the amount of QTE's, but that isn't a massive issue when the actual combat is as fluid and fun as it is.

One of the best releases in a long time.

9.5/10

It plays something like Assassin's Creed _ meets Batman: Arkham ____
But it has a bunch of it's own mechanics; so it seems fresh and new,
Even as the hero walks around looking like he just stepped out of Ezio's shadow.
However, unlike Ezio, this hero can use stealth. Also he is much, much more brutal.
Controls really well with controller, havent tried Kb&M though.

The story is OK so far, but nothing to write home about; however there's plenty of Middle Earth lore, which is very cool.
EDIT: The story gets much better about half way through, when you learn of the Wraith.
Anyway, i think the free-roaming orc-murdering and poking at the power-struggles will have me playing this game for a while and keeping it installed for a longer.

I can see myself putting many hours into this, and might actually get the season pass.

Also i feel i should mention it, There's not been a single bug, or crash. Which is kind of rare for PC games lately.

reviewText:
The gameplay is pretty much a straight clone of the Batman Arkham games, which isn't a bad thing since the Arkham games have an excellent combat system. The Nemesis system adds a welcome twist to the familiar formula, though. Plus there's a little bit of Assassin's Creed thrown in for good measure. You could definitely rip off worse games if you wanted to.

The story is well-acted but doesn't make a whole lot of sense. There are a few really great characters though and the story was genuniely funny at times. Unfortunately it just sort of ends out of nowhere. I walked away going, That was it?"

If you enjoyed Arkham Asylum/City and want to play a similar game set in the Lord of the Rings universe
date: Shadow of Mordor should satisfy you. Just don't expect much else. That's pretty much all there is here."

reviewText:
TL:DR- 9/10, It is worth the price, reasonable replayability, fun to play.


Positives:
Nemesis System- A fun and innovative addition that makes an above average game, great. Basically it is the political system of Uruks killing Uruks (Or killing you) to rise the ranks. If you let a lowly soldier finish you off they will rise in rank and power as the climb to the top.
Graphics- The game isn't meant to be the prettiest thing you have ever seen but it does look good.
Music- Fitting music to the soundscape, never found myself dreading the same theme in over 25+ hours of gameplay.
Gameplay- Alot of hack and slash action coupled with Quicktime based combat. It is fun enough to go out on the map and just kill random Uruks for fun.
Negatives:
Missions can become repetitive if you aim to complete them all.
Some map issues- Got caught in the environment a couple of times and fell through the map once, just minor annoyances.

reviewText: I love this game. Love it. But after a while playing it, it quickly became repetitive. I love the parkour, and the combat, and the story and the characters, but the main questline is so short, and after that there is just too much to do. Having a lot of content is great, but I don't want to do the same 3 or 4 things over and over again. I probably won't get much farther past 40% completion of this game. I'm not going to downvote this game because of this issue, but it's definitely not worth $50, nor even the $45 I paid for the premium edition when it was on sale. Sure, play this game if you have the money to spare and you honestly won't feel guilty, but otherwise think very carefully about whether you want to play the same content over and over.\n\nTL;DR Not enough story or variety. Think very hard about purchasing.

reviewText: I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys assasins creed, Batman, and the lord of the rings lore. As this great game combines them all and, in my opinion, does it very well. I only have a couple of downsides to it, one of them is that a few times I went for a stealth kill from the top of a building, roof etc. and I managed to get stuck in a wall and had to restart the game, but hopefully that will get ironed out. Another thing is that, although it is a brilliant game, if you don't like quicktime events don't buy it. As a lot of the main bosses and mini bosses etc. end on a quicktime event. The good things about it though is the fluidness of the non quicktime fights, as the attacks flow without pause and the special abilities that you unlock make the fights even more enjoyable, the graphics are amazing and the overall emersion is great fun. Good and bad things aside though, I cannot stress how much fun I have had playing through it! Great game, worth every penny!

reviewText:
Pros:
+Good graphics (runs pretty good as well)
+Nice scenery
+Fun combat
+Awesome animations
+Fun mounted combat
+Lots of sidequests and other stuff to do besides main quest
+Decent main quest
+All bosses etc are unique, giving the game better replay value
+Badass cape physics
+Great soundtrack
+Fun talent and leveling up system
+Large open world

Cons:
-Some visual bugs like rainbow textures (no gamebreaking bugs, a restart usually does it)
-Repetive enviorments (same ruins everywhere, same animals etc) Lack of unique things to discover
-Super easy boss fights (Finished them all on my first try), in fact so easy that warchief/captain fights are harder than the actual bosses
-Short main quest
-Boring/forgettable characters
-Only two unique zones, which really rustles my OCD, either it should be 1 or 3+
-Annoying Orc voices, every other Orc sounds the same


Overall:
I rate this game 8.5/10! It's amazing and although I bought it on full price, I wouldn't recommend doing so unless you have money to spend. It's still an amazing game and I haven't had this much fun in almost a year!

reviewText:
Goddammit Mordor, why did you kill my save file? Why can't I save manually to DIFFERENT SAVE SLOTS? argh
Gameplay:
That said, this game is quite good. Fighting feels similar to the Batman games, and the nemesis system really adds to it. Character is quite mobile, and an interesting balance is struck between stealth, ranged and melee attack. You are not a tank, though fighting well means you can avoid a lot of damage. Challenges and opportunities are generally good.

Visuals:
The graphics are pretty good, though some areas have had a lot more attention paid to them than others. Character models and skins are great, particularly the numerous orc types. Art design is generally good.


Audio:
Fine, not particularly memorable. Again, the orcs stand out with their conversations, taunts and other voice acting.

Overall:
Provided the loss of save games is fixed, or you work around it somehow, I recommend this game. As it stands today, I'd give it a recommendation with that important caveat.

reviewText: I would recommend this game but would say that you shouldn't expect too much out of it. I bought this game with really high hopes, hearing how great the combat system, and the nemesis system were, and had a blast for the first few hours or so. About halfway through the game really started to drag on for me. I like to try to do everything before the main quest, so I kept trying to kill all of the chieftains and warlords, and you can't. It's horribly frustrating to keep trying to kill everything off, and then logging off and coming back on just to have everyone be replaced and you no longer have intel on them. And the combat is so easy it's boring. You can just crouch and suddenly you're invisible and can do whatever you want, and if anyone does see you, you just pull out your sword and kill them in a few quick hits. The character just feels too over powered for the world, other than caragors. Caragors were the bane of my existence in this game, and I would rather fight 3 warlords at the same time than deal with a single caragor. Worth it if you can get it cheap, but I wouldn't pay full price.

reviewText:
Enjoyable, very satisfying third person combat in a setting with lore that's well handled, with abilities that make sense in context.

The closest comparison i can give for this game is that it is a Tolkein version of the latter Far Cry games, even moreso than it resembles the Arkham series games from which it takes most of its combat dynamics.

The nemesis system is very fun and as much as i hated dieing multiple times at the hands of my own personalised nemesis, it really drew me in.

That said, beyond the open world fun and nemesis system, if you're aiming for 100% completeness as I did, this really is a game that runs out of tricks towards the end (an end no less where if you end up completely skilled up, you can do away with the challenge. As for the DLC, the Lord of the Hunt has been a bit of a let down. I hope the Bright Lord content makes up for that.

reviewText:
Well first things first, this game does and doesn't live up to all the hype it recieved. Let me explain while I find the gameplay fun and engaging others my not, it plays alot like the Assassin's Creed and newer Batman games combat wise, the music is excellent imo as well. The nemesis system is in-depth but not as in-depth as they lead us to believe in trailers and whatnot. Even though it still makes for interesting stories and gameplay, and speaking of stories this has one of the shortest I've seen in awhile. It's a pretty good bet that if you've played Assassin's Creed or Batman games and beaten them, if you just do the storyline and don't go running around like I did you could probably beat this in 8-10 hours. The game says its a large open world but don't believe it. Its two maps divided up into areas that you can freely roam in though you don't get access to the second map untill roughly the half-way point of the game. Overall still a fun game but I'd suggest renting it for console first before buying.

Overall Score- 7/10
Music- 8/10
Combat- 8/10
Storyline 9/10 (while short is still excellent imo)

reviewText:
Fantastic gameplay, pretty solid combat system and super fun stealth options. Basically it's an Assassin's Creed - type game, but with 200 times more brutal combat, a story based off actual Tolkien lore that has awesome snippets on past and future events. if you are a lore buff this game has it all...

The political / power struggle element makes the game super different, giving you freedom to play as you alike, either solo or with semi useless allies that are there more for cannon fodder and distraction than anything else.

I would give the game 9/10, it's really worth the 50 bucks, I just hope they release interesting DLCs in the future because its such a great release, would hate to shelve it after 50 odd hours of play for the main story.

reviewText:
This game...
Oh my God.
Hory ♥♥♥♥♥.
It is the most epic thang evah,
Who doesn't want to teleport into 5 orcs and kill them all with a wraith in amazing graphics and brutal deaths?
It is an insane game, though the story is 10 - 15 hours, there is a lot of other stuff to do, brand all the Warchiefs/Captains etc.
Besides that there are multiple challenges to complete, such as hold a bridge from constant waves of enemies for 3 minutes without letting a torch bearer through. With a 550 Mirian reward; such challenges really make you push for those 2500 upgrades, which I have one of. You would think that getting those upgrades would make the game too easy, in a way it does, but it makes it so much more epic. Before you were worried about those spear and shield guys, and those dual-wielders right? Not anymore, activate the Sword of Urfael and brand them all instantly and have them turn on the Captain and other orcs (who then get rekt).
While it makes it easier with those upgrades it also gives you a much larger set of options to complete certain tasks and missions. No longer do you have to sneak about and kill EVERY archer before you go in, for fear of getting shot. Go around and brand a few then charge in and brand everyone with the ability, making it a 15v1 on the Captain :P

This game is amazing, after so few hours I still have a lot to do and cannot wait for the DLC's where you can play as Celebrimbor and the extra missions.

reviewText: I would describe this as a cross between the Batman games and Assassin's Creed, with a bit of interesting new stuff thrown in.  First, it looks beautiful, the graphics are a joy to behold.  The combat is fun, similar to the Batman games.  As you progress, you pick up enough new abilities, that slicing through a horde of Uruks just never gets old.The Assassin's Creed reference I mentioned is how your character moves though the areas.  There is a lot of climbing and perching above your prey and attacking from above, which, like the combat, never seems to get old.\nBut what really makes this game shine is the Nemesis system.  You really feel like these are real Uruks you are killing, all with different weaknesses and strengths and widely varied appearances.  You can join in on a power struggle between Orc captains and influence who wins.  As the captains and warchiefs gain power, they get promoted and move up in ranking.  Also, if some random orc kills you, he automatically gets promoted to captain, and has a name and gains a little armor to alter his appearance.  You can then kill him for a vendetta.  It is a very engaging system and honestly, I had a great time just trying to kill the captains and wreak havoc among their leadership.  It's great fun!

reviewText: Not sure what I thought of this game coming into it, seemed a little barebones and the Assassins Creed style objectives structure seemed like it was going to be filler, which it was, but what I did like the look of was the Nemesis system. Without that layer of personalisation to a players experience with the game, this title would've been completely mediocre and totally lacking in substance. I gotta say, I completely walked away from the story segments of the game just to ♥♥♥♥ around with the Nemesis system and it was alot of fun, the story itself was extremely lacking. By the time I came back to the story missions I'd maxed out my abilities for the most part, only came back to the story to unlock abilities like branding which was a whole new level of fun! In short, it's just fun to play the game, sure the combat may be simple but it's for show and if you combo your abilities like a ♥♥♥♥ing boss, you look like a badass and naturally send Uruks running in all direction. If you really want a challenge, handicap yourself by not taking health upgrades and such, some captains and warchiefs will one shot you, given the right traits. Overall, decent game, but what it brought to the table with the Nemesis system is some serious potential to influence greater AI systems and objectives in future titles.
