reviewText:
I normally don't write reviews, as normally people have already said what needs to be said about games. That is probably the case with this game as well, but I enjoyed this game enough for me to put my 2 cents in.

I didn't think I would like this game. In fact, when I first seen that this game was another LOTR game, I was turned off instantly. I can only think of one other good LOTR game (personal opinion of course) as games that pull from this IP or any movie / book IP always seem to fall short on quality. This game is a huge exception.

Watching the trailer I got excited. It really seemed like a solid mix of Batman / Assassin's Creed, and I love both of those games- at the same time it looked like a rip off. How could this game be mechanically better than either of those games? While not necessarily mechanically better than either, it is different enough from both and what they do offer as far as combat mechanics is satisfying and feels great.

Stealth elements are not as fleshed out as assassin's creed, so don't get hyped over stealth mechanics. They are not bad, but the meat of the gameplay comes from the solid combat system which is where this game truly shines. When you enter combat, combos are smooth and flashy, and the system succeeds at making you feel like a true badass.

That last point is probably where this game really hits the nail on the head for me. No other game lately has made me feel so unstoppable- so powerful and badass. I can go into fighting a hoard of Orcs right in the middle of a stronghold and have a blast just battling waves of enemies. It has yet to get old! The combat is something I enjoy with a passion. That being said, while earlier in the game it can be more difficult than later on, I do wish there were ways to increase the overall difficulty.

The core of the game revolves around fighting Captains and Warchiefs which have different stats and abilities. The game gives you tools which can make fighting strong captains and warchiefs easier, but most of the time you can do the same combo to take them out. Sometimes they can block your initial stun, but then you just role over them and hit them from behind with your stun and continue your combo. Sometimes they can block your stun and block your roll over them. Then you have to start thinking outside the box, especially if they have the Combat Master buff. The truth is, once you unlock more abilities and skills, combat becomes more of a slaughter than a battle or challenge. I wish that there were stronger Captains / Warchiefs that were so strong that you HAVE to use their fears or other mechanics against them.

Overall I would say that this game (FOR ME) is a no brainer. I would buy it again- in fact, I will probably get the season pass just so I can enjoy the upcoming DLC. There are not many games I go back too- especially in this day and age where I have 100 games to play and only time for a hand full of them. This game however, I will be finding any excuse I can find to play more of it. I have already beat the story mode, and I am now having a blast going through self made scenarios or goals that I make. Do I feel like killing every Captain / Warchief on the map? How about mind controlling all of them? How about I go get revenge on a captain who happened to get a cheap kill on me earlier? The story is really yours to craft, and that's probably one of the biggest highlights of this game. The Shadow of Mordor sandbox has all the tools you need to make your own fun.

My last point will be regarding what the game calls the Nemesis System. This is probably one of the cooler aspects of the sandbox and truly brings a lot to the table. It adds a lot of personality to the Orcs, and gives every Orc / Captain / Warchief a little uniqueness and personality. Captains will remember you and mention past encounters you may have had. Orcs don't always look different, but there are certainly many varieties of Orc to keep it mostly random, and each have their own quirks that makes them one of a kind. It's something that I really appreciate, and one of the reasons I wish the game was harder. I hardly got a rival" or an Orc that was too hard for me to beat. I would say there was only one Orc in particular through my entire playthrough that killed me twice
date: but that was before I knew you could upgrade your max health!\n\nOverall this game was completely worth it. I had a great time playing it
recommended: and I recommend it for those of you who enjoy the Lord of the Rings setting
hoursPlayed: and a good action game. The only true improvements I could think of is adding difficulty options
voteText: mod support
helpfulPercent: and more customization
votesHelpful: but what we do have is excellent. I think many would agree."

reviewText:
Just going to forewarn you, if you don't like games that you constantly die in, then this might not be the game for you. BUT THATS PAST THE POINT.

Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a beautiful game full of immense stories and side missions, absolutely outstanding graphics, (might I add that the game is  THIRTY FOUR GIGABYTES!!!! The nemesis system is my personal favorite feature of the game. It combines frustration with extreme joy whenever you either lose to a really terrible enemy which was by accident or just lost, which is really frustrating, OR whenever an enemy you really despise gets beaten in a duel BY the enemy that you just lost to. You can pretty much climb ANYTHING between a pillar and 100 foot mountain. I have been saved by scaling rocks and such countless times, thats not including the caragor, the caragor makes it so if you're sprinting then well you can climb anything...

Whats really frustrating is that there is no difficulty settings so you are stuck playing on 1 set setting. Hence my forewarning. This makes you either die a lot or makes the game a fun challenge and you die a lot which is a good mixture. With Arkham Origins, its really disappointing since the enemys are so easy to defeat but with the Shadow of Mordor, either you counter right or you die.

I honestly don't see a reason to dislike the Shadow of Mordor. Although I would love to see difficulty settings implemented, I still recommend this game :)

reviewText:
The playable protagonist is exceptionally boring, motivated only by revenge and a voice in his head (Spoiler: an Elven lord in wraith form). As an undead bent on revenge, his lacking emotion and missing humanity are probably fitting but make it quite difficult for the player to form a relationship.

The friendly NPCs are either obnoxious or forgettably dull - sometimes both. Characters have one goal, feature one or two emotions at maximum making it impossible for a player to care for them.

The story needed to take place between The Hobbit™ and The Lord Of The Rings™, being completely overshadowed by both, giving the title an ironical, yet unmeant, twist.

The game-play is repetitive as approx. 80% of time your are fighting, 16% running around Mordor, with a 3% loading and cut screens.

So why do I recommend the game?

Well, the fighting is sublime, the combat is satisfying. It looks gorgeous. Decapitating an Orc (or Uruk-hai™ :-p) never gets old in this game. Commands are responsive, as a player you don't feel cheated by the mechanics. Upgrades are meaningful, the collectable runes count as loot and give grinding a purpose.

But that's not it:
It features the best enemies I ever fought in a video-game.

Orc Captains have more personality than most of the friendly NPCs combined, let alone the schizophrenic" undead protagonist.
They have weaknesses
recommended: a motivation and they do what Orcs do best: they like to fight each other as much as they like to fight you. They remember your actions and taunt your for them
hoursPlayed: they might get stronger
voteText: or killed by their competitors if you don't interfere and each of these things can be used to your advantage if you take the right steps.\n\nThe voice acting is state of the art
helpfulPercent: the cut-scenes are not pre-rendered
votesHelpful: still very engaging
votesTotal:
giving you an individual touch each game you start and each Captain you butcher on your way to revenge.

So in conclusion:
This game is the best Orc-Butchering Simulator I ever played. If you want to unwind with butchering hordes of Orcs and their commanders this game is the best on the market in my opinion but if you care for anything else than Orc-Butchering you will find the game sadly lacking."

reviewText:
Overview
---

According to the game, I'm 12% through the game. This game is filled with Assassin's Creed-like parkour, Batman Arkham Asylum/City/Origins-like combat, and it's more entertaining than ever. It's a hack and slash with amazing elements that you will most likely not find in any other game. Not only is this a Lord of the Rings game, which is a selling point for most fans, but it's combat is fluid and systems in the game is faultless.

I believe that this game will never get boring. The endless nemesis system is awesome, as many new captains come in, kill/hunt with each other, working their way up to legendary captains, which is their ultimate goal. Along the way, not only do orcs get attacked by your character, killing them after their fruitful efforts to reach the top, but also competing orcs. If an orc gets to a high enough power level, he will try to move up in rank...but some of the times that doesn't work, resulting in the loss of their lives and making the winner a target for the player.

You can get upgrades for your weapons in game, and also upgrades for your character and wraith abilities. You do missions to gather a currency to purchase more health, shots for your bow and arrow, and slots for your weapons. You have three weapons in the game, which all play crucial parts; the sword, the bow, and the broken sword, which functions as a dagger. The sword is for most melee combat, the bow is for taking out ranged troops and grunt ground troops, and the sword is for stealth kills.

Also, if you have friends who play the game, when you progress through the storyline, you unlock Vendetta waypoints. if you go to one of these, you have a chance to murder your friend's nemesis, which is the 'Uruk' that killed them most. This feature is awesome.

Pros and Cons
---

Pros-
-Great graphics, even on low
-Fantastic combat, gory and different every time, also challenging depending on your advantage in stealth
-Brilliant mechanics

Cons-
-The storyline's don't really line up. In the game, it takes place in between the end of the Hobbit book and before the Lord of the Rings trilogy. However, the enemies you encounter in the game are called Uruks, short for Uruk-Hai, which is Saruman's creation. This is before Saruman has begun working for Sauron, therein these 'Uruks' shouldn't be in the game.

I hope you appreciated my review, and I hope you buy the game. Add me if you do so I can avenge you from your nemesis! :)

EDIT:

Upon completing the game, I just wanted to warn you. The final battle isn't exactly a battle...You just press buttons to block attacks. But the rest of the game is great, there's two different maps you can travel around, adding to the adventure.

Graphics: 9/10 Beautiful scenery, gore, and orcs.

Gameplay: 8.5/10 Engaging Combat, Interesting Systems, Disappointing Last Boss Fight.

Controls: 9/10 Good Controls, easier with a keyboard and mouse than a controller. Keyboard Recommended

reviewText:
Killing Orcs Has Never Been So Fun!
I have to admit I come into this game knowing nothing about the The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit series. So the universe and the lores behind the movies or the novels mean nothing to me. I have to say, when I bought this game I did not buy it for the story, I just wanted a fun action game with tons of content and very addictive gameplay. I am happy to confirm I got what I wanted and it was more than overdose.

The first thing I want to address is that this game was made by Monolith Studio who also made the popular WWE series. It is strongly portrayed in the game by the way characters walk, tackle and performing actions which is really cool as it work perfectly well in a game where the world is dominated by the Orcs. When a warchief is making an entrance you get all the lesser orcs chanting out their name making them look badass and you get the sense of satisfaction by cutting off their head at the end and claiming that epic rune.

The game plays very smooth. It combines features from The Batman and Assassins Creed series but improves on the formula by having a deeper and better combat system, better stealth approach and wide array of interesting skills at your disposal. At certain point of the game I was actually really weak and was unable to defeat even an orc captain and was really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off about the game. However, as I dig deeper into the combat system and gained a few more levels I was able to finally defeat that nemesis that claimed my head countless of times. Speaking about revenge, the game introduced a very unique system called the 'Nemesis' system in which as player and time passes and evolves, the ranks within the orc army will also change. You soon learn that enemy AI behave extremely smart by roaming from place to place, killing superior orcs to gain power, dominate fellow orcs to earn an army and even ambush you when you were fighting other orcs. There will always be one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that always kill you becoming stronger each time and eventually raise in power to become a warchief. Furthermore, this system makes the AI memorise you so that the next time they meet you they come prepared with bodyguards as well as better equipments.

The game was also very intense from time to time with some battles lasting way longer than 10mins as waves of orcs swarming in I find my self unable to escape or rather, the manliness inside me tells me to face them head on and after killing near hundres of orcs and gained a few powerful runes it results in a very satisfying warm little fuzzy feeling inside.

After 20 or so hours into the game, the epicness is really showing as the world  totally opened up to you and you pretty much gained most of the abilities helping you to dominate the orcs in any situation. You can ride a caragor into battle and you can even ride a Graug to siege an entire orc fortress which was absolutely mind blowing. On top of this the game graphics looks absolutely beautfiful with very detailed graphics options. However, to have the graphics setting set to ultra high you will need a high - end pc to play it.

When I was using a Razer blade with GTX 765m I can play on high setting with about 40-50 fps. With a Alienware m18x dual GTX 560m I get about similar results and with my desktop with R9 290X I can play on ultra with 60fps no problem. So it is fair to say that this game is well optimised. To top it all off, the game comes with a photo mode helping you to capture every moments of glory and it has many features that you can play around with to capture some really beautiful eye candy.

Final verdict 10/10
I believe that this game is my game of the year 2014, as 2014 hasn't been a great year for gaming I think that shadow of Mordor really do stand out from the rest and it is packed with tons of content as well as delivering a satisfying experience to fans of the series or action game lovers alike.

tl;dr
+Fun combat mechanics
+Satisfying orc slaying mayhem
+interesting set of skills / passives
+blend stealth with action really well
+Gorgeous Graphics
+Tons of content
+Addictive and challenging
-skins offer no new voices (Every skin uses Talion's voice)
-Season pass doesn't offer much content

P.S. I have played about 30hours some were played in offline mode because I had no internet for a few days so the record on steam is wrong. within the 30hrs of game time I completed all the main missions, side quests (except killing all orcs), found all collectibles and learned all the skills as well as the passives.

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor is a rather shallow envisioning of Tolkien's Middle Earth, albeit with some high moments. The plot surrounding the game's central characters, Talion and Celebrimbor, is lackluster and heavily disjointed at best, providing very little incentive to be invested in the narrative. The lack of character development of the protagonists make the story rather boring and predictable, though the voice acting is admissible. Moreover, the game lacks a good representation of races in Middle Earth as very few Dwarves or Elves appear. Your journey through Middle Earth will be filled with Uruks and Men and rather abrubt too, as the main narrative is extremely short.

Most of the playthrough will be spent via the Nemesis system and in combat, slaying Uruks by the thousands (literally). It is here where the game is, in my opinion, somewhat intriguing; that is, at least, at first. The combat is very similar to that of the Batman Arkham games, with some added twists. Overall, the system is very polished, simple, and addicting. However, after mastering the combat, even with the added upgrades via the skill points, the combat became stale, monotonous, and almost tedious to get through. This is confounded by the fact that your enemies, including captains, harder bosses, and hordes of Uruks are trivially easy to beat. (I died a total of 2 times in my 20 hour playthrough!) The absence of challenge was really a disappointment.

Unfortunately, the Nemesis system too stays with the overarching theme of Shadow of Mordor. At first, the system was relatively stimulating, as I would hunt down a captain or bend him to my will. Sadly, the whole goal of the system was missed, since it very clearly lacks depth. Sure, a captain would utter something that I had done to him in the past or would bear a burn mark from our last encounter. However, that's all the Uruk would do. He did not change tactics or present any new challenge, except maybe another dolefully easy body guard. The one sentence muttered at the beginning of our encounter was the extent and end of the interaction. If expanded on further, the system could have been much better and been worthy of praise.

As for graphical fidelity, the game is very nice looking. There are some rocks and structures that have very bad, ugly looking textures though, but isn't a big deal. The game is very well optimized too. Using a mouse and keyboard, I had very few problems except that the in game camera would turn at different speeds, seemingly at random times (not when I was using the bow) and be in an odd angle during some enclosures. There was the occasional getting stuck on certain objects while moving as well.

Overall, I thought Shadow of Mordor was an OK game, and think others may enjoy it more. In my opinion, I would only recommend buying this game when it is on sale.

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor Is the Lord of the Rings game you've been waiting for. Nice open world for you to explore, collectibles, challenges, side missions, upgrades and a nice skill tree.
The Combat is really responsive just like in the Batman Arkham Series but with Gore and Decapitations.
The Nemesis System is where things get really interesting. Fight or Help Uruk Hai Captains to weaken Sauron's army, by killing them or making them stronger for your command.
Once you get a hang of it you can do a lot of cool things to change the way you can face your enemies.
One of the best games of 2014 in my opinion. I strongly recommend people to give it a shot.

Pros
+ Graphics
+ Combat
+ Lore
+ Enemy Progression (Nemesis System) and Ratbag

Cons
- Story could've been better

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor:
Graphics - On a decent computer it looks amazing, the scenery, the texture details the lighting, everything is really top class.
Character detail and animations -  are fantastic, the physx hair and cape sway around in the breeze, the characters mouth movements sync up really well with the characters voice, not just in the cinematic cut scenes but the in game talking when you pick up a specific item etc. The looks on the orcs faces when you about to stab your sword into their face, the look of their friends is also really well done, you know, the look of horror when you brutally stab them all over the place. The animations for combat is flawless as well, the different types of kill possibilites for not only basic attacks but for executions and dagger kills as well.
Voice acting + cinematics - really amazing job for every character, the stand outs for me was the guy the does for voice for Talion the main character I thought was absolutely fantastic, beautifully fits the character and also all the orc voices are amazing. Every captain has a different personality which affects how they fight in some cases. Cinematics obviously are gonna be great, I suppose its kind of expected in this time of technology, but Shadow of Mordor has more cutscene cinematics then pretty much all other games that I've played. There is basically one for each step of the main story which includes about 20 parts so. Yea really great job on the voice acting and cutscene cinematics.
Immersion - So for me one of the greatest things about this game was the immersion, I guess games that come out now are gonna be more and more immersive because the graphics become more and more realistic but this game especially. It really gives you the drive to keep playing and to not only finish the story but complete 100% of the games content as well. The story for me was really quite good, the dialog that the characters had really made sense, it was logical which in some games is hard to find. And what I mean by that is some games have the character make really stupid decisions like not wanted to have help or not completely killing a person and its just to drag on to the story, similar to horror movies when its very dark and there is obviously someone hiding in the dark room with a knife but the idiot walks in anyway and gets mauled to pieces, when in reality, you would probably run out of the ♥♥♥♥ing house drive away get on a plane and ♥♥♥♥ing move to an entirely different location. Another immersive part of the game was the collectables part of the game, usually in games they make you pick up little items to extend the game a little bit. Shadow of Mordor gives you a logical reason and rewards for getting this items, they give you backstory of the item you just picked up or dialog between the Calabrimbor and Talion discussing what they found. There is also a bunch of rescue quests which involve you going to free human slaves from the orcs. Each time you accept the new rescue quest it tells you what the slaves did in order to be tied up and tortured and then that story affects the bonus part of the quest. For example if a bunch of slaves tried to poison the orcs 'grog' which is basically their alcohol, you have the bonus quest of finishing the job and poisoning the grog.
My rating + should you buy the game - So my rating for the game is going to be a 10/10, I stayed up for 38 hours and I played the game for 37 of those hours and I enjoyed every minute of it. I was waiting for this game for a long time and it really delivered more then I expected. I think they did an amazing job and I'm really looking forward to what DLC's they're going to bring out.
Now about buying the game for youself, I highly recommend doing it. It's an open world game with so many possibilites on how you would like to play the game. The captains and warchiefs are all different and you can choose which ones you want to control and which ones you want to kill, you can create your own unique army of orcs which is a really cool idea in my opinion. So definitely go out and get it, seriously one of the best, if not the best game ive ever played.

reviewText:
GOTY 2014. That's how awesome it is. Do i need to say more?? And it's a ton of fun to blow away the entire head of an uruk and just leave the body behind. Always gives a feeling of everything paying of. But really what makes this game so friggin awesome and fun is basically the nemesis system. A few dozen uruk's just fighting for power within the system and then way more people trying to get higher up in this military hierarcy. So the best tip any player can give to a new player is the easiest tip ever but that might sound dumb and stupid at first but... dont die. Just dont die and it will go just fine.
And did i mention how beatutiful mordor is when you're not slaying dozens and even more dozens of uruk's. If you can run the game on ultra,do. It makes it look so nice and badass.
and it's a nice break from killing uruk's.
Still i gotta complain on some few minor things.
First of all is the story. Even though the story is nice and well presented(i do think monolith did a nice job at giving us a good story) it's just,too short. It's only 20 missions. But then there's the nemesis system which makes up for that cause you probably spend way more time on the nemesis system then on the story at first.(nemesis system ftw)
Another thing that i just have to say and this one is probably a bit personal but still,the game is way too easy. The captains don't have a lot of variety really so i just found myself doing the same approach on nearly every single captain. Love the game or hate the game. me myself i love it.
The duo combat(and by that i mean switching between sword and bow,aka talion's sword urfael and celebrimbor's bow azkar which is very useful in most battles. If you have read this far,picture yourself this scenario. You are in a stronghold(fort) and you got,let's say,40+ uruk's coming right at you. You know you got no chance with sword only. and then u see a grog barrel in the middle of the uruk's. Well what do you do now? I'd say blow the grog barrel up and you probably will only have between 5-15 enemies left.
Conclusion: Middle Earth Shadow of Mordor is the best LotR game to date. Even if i do hope for a sequel,it probably wont come any.
The combat is great,the open world is good but could be larger,the story could be longer but it's a nice story for a good game,the rune system is brilliant,the nemesis system is unique and basically AWESOME and at last, the voice acting is friggin awesome. This game gets a solid 10 even tho it lacks on some things but its a good game. Basically one of the many must play games of 2014.

reviewText:
Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is one of those games that looked pretty good on paper, in trailers etc and you wanted to try it out but felt a little iffy because recent releases have all been, for the most part,  basic corporate stamp-o-matic titles with little creativity in them.

SoM almost seems to be like this as well at first; the opening environments are bleak and only broken up by the inevitable valleys, cliffs and assorted rocks of a rather depressing landscape. That said, the gameplay itself is what makes SoM a great game. I won't lie and say it is incredibly varied, as the main focus of the game (and the basic goal for just about every mission in it) is to kill things. Oh, there is variety on HOW, precisely you go about it, but essentially you kill things... lots of things.

Lets break this down as I don't seem to be getting very far in explaining why this game is worth getting...

-The movement and combat-
Talion, the character you play as, moves fairly well but can often stick on the environment's various jagged corners at the worst possible time, sometimes causing him to stop dead when you might prefer him to keep moving away from a large Uruk with a meat cleaver bigger than he is bearing down on you. This is a tiny, petty annoyance, but it has cropped up once or twice (not too often, just enough to be noted) and is one of the few issues I have with either the movement or combat system.

Movement as a whole is very remise of any of the Assassins Creed games, with almost identical parkour movement, jumps and climbing. This is a good thing, as if Assassins Creed did anything well, it was the parkour which allowed players to screw around on buildings as much as they liked. Combine this with Talion's very stabby-stabby nature towards anything orc-ish and you get some very climby-jumpy-stealthy-killy fun moments.

Stealth itself is quite well done, though I would suggest that all of the Orcs find another opticians as they all appear to have eyesight that stops somewhere along the 20-yard mark unless they have previously spotted you and you moved further away from them. This aside, the stealth works very well, with various distraction, glomp-of-death and AOE (area of effect = read as explosions") abilities that can make Talion a one man guerilla unit against the whole of Sauron's Uruk forces... sounds pretty cool eh? :D Inevitably

reviewText:
*This review will be lengthy, so please, if you want a simple review, scroll to the bottom.*
This review will include the following:
- Open World
- Graphics
- Nemesis System
- Combat
- Stealth
- Movement
- Campaign (No Spoilers)
- Runes and Upgrades
- Characters

Open World: The open world of Shadow of Mordor is very well made and detailed. Stealth spots are easily seen and fit well in the environment. There is a fast travel system to towers you've been to. There are two different areas. One area is near the Black Gate, which is where you start, the other area has a lot of grass and beautiful scenery. Both areas, however, are absolutely beautiful.

Graphics: With my R9 280X, this game was a candy store to my eyes. This GPU is not required, but it runs the game on Ultra at 60 FPS. Even on lower settings, the game is visually stunning. I cannot express my profound love for the scenery and detail that is worked into this game. There are so many different factors that contribute to the graphic fidelity of this game that I can't list them here. Long story short, this game is gorgeous. Period.

Nemesis System: Besides my gushing over the graphics of the game, the Nemesis System is my favorite part of this game. This feature basically gives you an almost endless replayability. The main enemy faction, the Uruks, have a heirarchy of captains that increase in rank until they become warchiefs. The lower captains USUALLY are easier to kill and find, and won't drop very good rewards. There are some changes in this statement where the lower captains spawn with REALLY good qualities that counter your fighting style so perfectly, that you have to reevaluate your every attack. Some are immune to range or stealth. Some can't be scared off by a specific creature. It varies greatly from captain to captain, but they all can be quite formidable. When you kill a captain, that's it right? Wrong. Every time you kill a captain, a new one will take it's place, whether it's an already known, lower captain that wants to advance, or if it's a new guy that hasn't been seen before. Captains must be discovered individually, along with warchiefs. Warchiefs aren't necessarily super strong, they just are higher up. I personally had trouble with one captain that was in the second tier, and I killed a warchief in the first five minutes of being in his stronghold. If a captain kills you, or any Uruk for that matter, they will be promoted, or fight for a higher spot in the heirarchy. When you come back, they remember you and will  mostly mock you. Names are random and names depict what their unique personality is like. Some sing, some are slow witted, so on and so forth.

Combat: I wish it was more than what I'm about to say. It honestly isn't very new or innovative. It's, click to attack, click to counter attack, tap f to execute, that type of stuff. Very much like Batman.

Stealth: The stealth isn't really challenging. The Uruks are slow to detect, and have a bad case of tunnel vision. Hiding spots can be used to stalk Uruks. Cages with Caragors inside can be broken to release the hounds out. That type of stuff. It is, nonetheless, fun to play stealthily.

Movement: Fast, and very fluent. The animation of clothes and weapons and all of the movable objects around you are so well done. Talion is very fleet, Caragors are VERY fast, and everything is satisfying to say the least.

Campaign: The campaign is a good length, and is an interesting story. It is VERY worth it in my opinion, and it leaves you wanting more.

Runes and Upgrades: The runes and upgrades are in depth, and detailed. They add a very interesting twist to the normal skills of a ranger, besides the wraith thing. All of your weapons could be extremely powerful, and give you bonuses for doing specific actions.

Characters: All of the characters are well voiced and are well represented. They are interesting and varied, and will spark a fascinating intrest to talk to a character through their mission regularly. You'll soon find yourself playing the missions to talk to the characters. At least I did that.

Here is my overall impression of Shadow of Mordor. The game is fun. Just outright fun to play. The movements and animations are pleasing. The nemesis system is just fantastic, and adds endless replayability and variation in enemies. Combat could have been better, but ended up being pleasurable. The characters and the campaign are both very well done and very engrossing. The open world is stunning and vivid with details and action to partake in. Overall, the game is a must buy. This type of quality with LOTR themed game? Come on, it's a no brainer. Any information I excluded in my summary here, consult the novel above this.

reviewText:
A well put together Assassin's Creed-a-like with Batman: Arkham ____'s combat system set in middle earth.

The presentation, graphics, controls, etc are all well done. It's a really well made game.

If you don't like Assassin's Creed gameplay you probably won't like it. Like those games, I can't decide if I'm having fun while playing it or if it just does a really good job at letting me tick boxes and check lists (GOT ALL THE COLLECTABLES, AW YEAH). Either way, I 100%ed it so I must have been having some fun.

The story was an interesting take on Middle Earth and I liked the story it told, but I feel like they may have taken a bit of creative liberty with the Tolkien license...

One of the main highlights of the game is the Nemesis system, which I'm sure you've already read about if you're interested in this game. It's very well done and leads to some interesting battles. Playing around with it allows you to sort of create monsters/nemesis, and it's very fun. Nothing like encountering a guy early who is immune to range attacks, melee attacks, and stealth attacks, but is only weak to fire. Randomized orc leaders means you have to develop new strategies often, which keeps the gameplay very interesting.

Overall, a good game though. Worth the play, for sure.

reviewText:
It's a game built almost entirely out of parts from the Assassin's Creed and Batman Arkham games, but with one or two parts of its own. It's something slightly less than the sum of its parts, but that's mostly because the new parts it brings to the table are great, but by the time you actually get to use them properly, the game is half to 2/3rds over already.

The story and characters are garbage that don't go anywhere, the environments are dull and samey, and most of the parts the game steals from Assassin's Creed aren't quite as polished as they are in that series. The combat stuff from the Arkham series is fine, and there's enough of a twist on it to make it something interesting, a feat that Arkham Origins failed to pull off. But the new stuff is where the actual gold is, and it's barely uncovered until far, far too late.

Took me 22 hours to finish, but a lot of that was wasted time. I'd recommend powering through the story missions as fast as possible until you get the branding ability, which I didn't do but wish I had. The trouble is by the time you get that, and especially once you can get branded warchiefs, the game is mostly over, and you barely get a chance to play with these systems and abilities.

I'd definitely recommend playing it, but don't set your expectations too high. Wait for a sale, or at least until you can get it cheap somewhere like that Brazilian online game store, like I did.

reviewText: I would describe this as a cross between the Batman games and Assassin's Creed, with a bit of interesting new stuff thrown in.  First, it looks beautiful, the graphics are a joy to behold.  The combat is fun, similar to the Batman games.  As you progress, you pick up enough new abilities, that slicing through a horde of Uruks just never gets old.The Assassin's Creed reference I mentioned is how your character moves though the areas.  There is a lot of climbing and perching above your prey and attacking from above, which, like the combat, never seems to get old.\nBut what really makes this game shine is the Nemesis system.  You really feel like these are real Uruks you are killing, all with different weaknesses and strengths and widely varied appearances.  You can join in on a power struggle between Orc captains and influence who wins.  As the captains and warchiefs gain power, they get promoted and move up in ranking.  Also, if some random orc kills you, he automatically gets promoted to captain, and has a name and gains a little armor to alter his appearance.  You can then kill him for a vendetta.  It is a very engaging system and honestly, I had a great time just trying to kill the captains and wreak havoc among their leadership.  It's great fun!

reviewText:
Top Tip:
This game has an odd learning curve.  Initially it will feel fluid, natural, and simple.  You will quickly become weak and outclassed.  The trick is to do ALL the white missions you possibly can before doing anything else.  Use your points to buy rune slots and health upgrades.  And make sure to learn to block attacks using right click when prompted.

Pros:
-Graphics are very good.  There is also an HD texture pack but I couldn't get it to work.
-Combat is fun, much better than in Assassin's creed.  There is a lot of talent and skill and even strategy that goes into taking out your opponents.
-Being able to brand" (hypnotize) Uruks
recommended:
and war chiefs over to your side is really awesome.
-PC controls work REALLY well.  I commend the developers for figuring it out.  Your pinky will get a little tired of holding shift but their is no reason to break out a controller for this game.
-Save system is totally automatic and competent.  Most of the missions won't last longer than 5-20 minutes so their isn't a need to save while in progress.

Cons:
-Music is too heavy to have playing in the background while you are hacking away at Uruks for hours.  Luckily you can easily silence it
-IMO the story was really boring and I couldn't care less.  I enjoyed the LOTR movies and the Hobbit is one of my favorite books.  However
hoursPlayed: I'm not a big LOTR good.\n-The DLC that just came out makes you feel like you didn't get a full game.  Especially considering that their is no online play and the game isn't very long.  The story isn't very immersive either
voteText: so it doesn't have a ton of re-playability.\n\nOverall this game is fun and that's what really counts.  If you see a future version on sale with DLC included it will be a great value."

reviewText: If you are a fan of Batman Arkham Asylum/City, and the Assassin's Creed franchise, you'll feel right at home with Shadow of Mordor. The combat is very similar to the free flowing combat of Batman. (controller) X is attack, y is counter, a is dodge/vault over enemy and b is stun. RT+x = ground finisher. The stealth/sneak system reminds me of Assassin's Creed/Splinter Cell. Bushes to hid in, can climb any building, silent kills. Combine this with a unique nemesis system to keep it from getting stale too quick and we got a possible Game of the Year. I have dumped 12 hours into the game at this point and have only progressed through 6 or 7 main story missions. I have been having too much fun assassinated captains and chiefs and doing side missions to progress the story. High replayability. Definitely recommend.

reviewText:
Let me tell you how this game works in stages.

Stage 1: You start off a little unsure about what you are doing and go into fights carefully, but you die a lot.
Stage 2: After slaying your first few Warcheifs you become a little more cunning, planning different ways to kill those pesky orks.
Stage 3: By this point you have become a little to engrossed in what you do and find yourself charging head on into battle without even thinking.
Stage 4: You become an ork slaying badass and feel like nothing can stop you, that is until you die and feel a deep rage inside you.
Stage 5: Woah, by this point you are beyond any turning back. You want to finish the game, you want to earn every achievement, you want to kill every Uruk and Ork you see. The power you feel is uncontrollably EPIC!
Stage 6: You start to help you enemy rank up in the Nemesis system, allowing him to kill you again and again so that he becomes ever more powerful. You even do the same with his bodyguards, only to kill them all in a battle that feels all too easy.
Stage 6: You feel annoyed that there is no challenge the game can give to you, you roam Mordor, searching endlessly for a foe worthy or your blade....but no ork is brave enough to stand against your might.
Stage 7: Epic DLC is released and you go chop up some more orks.
Stage 8: Now you are the Master, you are unbeatable, no ork nor living thing will stand in your way. You are the Grave Walker and you will have your vengeance.
Stage 9: At this point...you throw your controller out the window dress in bubble wrap armour, pick up your cardboard sword and run about hitting random objects, awaiting the next DLC.


10/10 would bang an ork again.

reviewText:
Can't stop playing. The best Middle-Earth \ Lord of the Rings themed game out there so far.
Nemesis system adds very unique aspect into gameplay. Uruk captains and warchiefs are generated every time you kill them or when they are fighting each other to advance in ranks and take over place of their leaders. Each has his own personality, weakneses, strengths. It adds tons of replayability. Not to mention you can dominate uruk minds and send them to fight each other, thus you can build an army of your own uruks. I branded an uruk captain and made him a bodyguard of a warchief by sending mine to kill his bodyguard in duel, then I sent him to betray warchief. And there is more to Nemesis system, it is but a glimpse of this deeply elaborated system.
The combat system is very decent.
The story is very fitting and lore-wise, even if it is short, the quality of main missions is very high. There is much to do without story, even after completing it, you can continue to take out uruk captains/warchiefs and explore collecting artifcats, runes.
The world map is big enough to explore hours and hours. I believe Monolith will add new regions of Mordor beside Udûn and Sea of Núrnen once a DLC comes out (hoping to visit Plateau of Gorgoroth and Morgul Vale someday).
And there is this feel and immersion. The feel you are in Mordor and Middle-Earth.

reviewText:
If you enjoy chopping off Cockney orcs' heads after they've given a speech about how they are going to kill you and wear your skin, this is the game for you.

Being one who loves nearly anything Lord of the Rings, I was biased toward wanting to like this game. When I first saw gameplay for Shadow of Mordor, I was excited and concerned at the same time, both intrigued by the nemesis system and worried it was another copy and paste Assassin's Creed-type that would be too easy and do nothing new or interesting, thankfully I was wrong.

The fighting system is finely tuned and very similar (not in a bad way) to the Batman Arkham games. There are elements of Assassin's Creed in there as well with the climbing mechanics. However, with those facts in mind the game still feels fresh, not a derivative copy-cat. This is in large part due to the fantastic nemesis system. Your own narrative can play out as you can kill orc captains, leave them to sort out their squabbles themselves or give a gentle nudge (or a not so gentle nudge) to who you want to succeed in any given power struggle. If an orc kills you, he will increase in rank and power and recognise you next time you come in contact, quickly getting over his disbelief to try wear your skin again. It is by far the strongest part of the game, so much fun can be had just going around causing havoc among the orc ranks (which is what I did for hours) and I did not notice any repetition in orc names or voice tracks in my whole playthrough, serious props to the developers there. It is a shame that the system isn't more integral to the story, though it does become more important later in the game.

I have heard some calling the game too easy but this can be improved through player and gameplay choices. You can unlock every power/health/damage upgrade etc., but you don't have to. Things certainly get easier as you unlock more powers but new and more difficult enemy types come along later too, so there's a balance. Combat prompts should be turned off to reduce screen clutter and make things more challenging, forcing you to actually pay attention to what is going on around you and who is attacking you. With some minor tweaks like this, I didn't find the game too easy or too hard, more of a nice in between level and I suspect that many saying the game is too easy still have the combat prompts on.

I enjoyed the story (I won't spoil anything) but it has its weak points, both in character development and pacing as well as some very lackluster and underwhelming boss fights. It does enough to push the game along and there is plenty of one ring to rule them all"

reviewText:
A great start to a future franchise in my opinion. While not prefect and is heavily influenced by other open world games it feels fresh with the nemesis system. If they can manage to do it bigger and better in the sequel it will be an instant buy for me.

Be prepared to come across Orcs you are sure you killed for them to only come back to taunt you later on. The more you fail the stronger they get. I had this one Orc who was a captain of the black gate and that SOB just wouldn't stay dead until our climactic showdown at the end of the game. That Orc was the last boss for me, he made it feel so personal!

My only negative is that it gets far to easy to win late game due to how overpowered the main character becomes, something I hope they address in the sequel.

If you enjoy fun open world games grab this, if it's on sale definitely buy it.

reviewText:
A well put together Assassin's Creed-a-like with Batman: Arkham ____'s combat system set in middle earth.

The presentation, graphics, controls, etc are all well done. It's a really well made game.

If you don't like Assassin's Creed gameplay you probably won't like it. Like those games, I can't decide if I'm having fun while playing it or if it just does a really good job at letting me tick boxes and check lists (GOT ALL THE COLLECTABLES, AW YEAH). Either way, I 100%ed it so I must have been having some fun.

The story was an interesting take on Middle Earth and I liked the story it told, but I feel like they may have taken a bit of creative liberty with the Tolkien license...

One of the main highlights of the game is the Nemesis system, which I'm sure you've already read about if you're interested in this game. It's very well done and leads to some interesting battles. Playing around with it allows you to sort of create monsters/nemesis, and it's very fun. Nothing like encountering a guy early who is immune to range attacks, melee attacks, and stealth attacks, but is only weak to fire. Randomized orc leaders means you have to develop new strategies often, which keeps the gameplay very interesting.

Overall, a good game though. Worth the play, for sure.

reviewText:
It's a game built almost entirely out of parts from the Assassin's Creed and Batman Arkham games, but with one or two parts of its own. It's something slightly less than the sum of its parts, but that's mostly because the new parts it brings to the table are great, but by the time you actually get to use them properly, the game is half to 2/3rds over already.

The story and characters are garbage that don't go anywhere, the environments are dull and samey, and most of the parts the game steals from Assassin's Creed aren't quite as polished as they are in that series. The combat stuff from the Arkham series is fine, and there's enough of a twist on it to make it something interesting, a feat that Arkham Origins failed to pull off. But the new stuff is where the actual gold is, and it's barely uncovered until far, far too late.

Took me 22 hours to finish, but a lot of that was wasted time. I'd recommend powering through the story missions as fast as possible until you get the branding ability, which I didn't do but wish I had. The trouble is by the time you get that, and especially once you can get branded warchiefs, the game is mostly over, and you barely get a chance to play with these systems and abilities.

I'd definitely recommend playing it, but don't set your expectations too high. Wait for a sale, or at least until you can get it cheap somewhere like that Brazilian online game store, like I did.

reviewText:
I have only played this game for a few hours but I feel very strongly that it will be setting the standards for these types of games, as well as any open sandbox style games for at least the next generation of games.

This game basically blends the climbing and movement of Assassins Creed and the combat of the Batman Arkham games, and it does so beautifully.  It is a perfect blend of action, story, and stealth.

Also the Nemisis system is incredible and will be used in future video games for sure.  It's just such a fresh idea, you basically learn about your enemies while you play.  This was implemented somewhat in Batman Arkham City with the interrgoating the riddler goons, but Nemsis is so much more, not only do you learn more about your opponents, but also if an opponent surivies a fight, he will remember you.  Which is pretty incredible.

All in all I would probably give this game a perfect score, but for now, I won't score since I don't enough time in yet.

Bottom line, if you loved the Batman games and Assassin's Creed do yourself a favor and pick this game up, you will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
Im not a fan of repetitive games most of the time, but just like FC3, i cant get enough of killing things in this game. It must be the cinematic way that you can kill things that draws me in most. Its not easy to master, but its easy to play if you are halfway competent in games.(which thankfully i am at least halfway...)

Graphics are great, the way things die are awesome, find secrets, the orc boss system is pretty fantastic as well. I also like that the bosses progress when they kill you and become your nemesis, which promptly pisses me off and makes me want to go out and get my revenge. My pc is pretty monster but in other games ive has slowdowns where in this game, seemingly no matter whats on screen, it stays pretty fluid, set on mostly high and some ultra settings. (this is also the first game that vsync has helped instead of hurt for me, got rid of screen tearing).

Overall i havent gotten bored yet, my game states 21.2 hrs of gameplay but realisticly its only 10 hrs(left it on overnight by accident) but still have only touched 2 main quest stories(to open up some skills) and levelled to enough power to get the second tier of skills opened(not opened by main questline stories)

I could envision myself running around this game, continually killing and ♥♥♥♥♥ing killed, jumping up buildings and over enemies and blockign and ....well you get the idea.

its sunday 27th of april and i bought this yesterday during a half price sale for 25.49, which included the season pass.

if your reading this before monday, and have even a slight interest in this, i say its a no brainer at 25 bucks.

reviewText:
Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor    Reviewed in pros-and-cons format

Pros:
Combat works well
Nemesis system is unique
Captains and Warchiefs are unique and very enjoyable to kill
Stealth, ranged and melee combat options work well together
Perks and abilities are very well done
Various strongholds are well-designed and based off of game's mechanics
Voice acting is very well done
Enemy variety
Animation is smooth and beautiful
Cons:
Story is bland
Combat is made rather simple and easy with button prompts
Can get repetitive
Stealth and ranged are very simplistic
Open world can feel empty
Late-game is very easy
Overall:
Shadow of Mordor has a lot of good ideas. While some aspects could be better and the game is very obviously inspired by AC and Batman, it has a unique flair that makes it stand out

8.5/10; worth the money

reviewText:
GOTY 2014. That's how awesome it is. Do i need to say more?? And it's a ton of fun to blow away the entire head of an uruk and just leave the body behind. Always gives a feeling of everything paying of. But really what makes this game so friggin awesome and fun is basically the nemesis system. A few dozen uruk's just fighting for power within the system and then way more people trying to get higher up in this military hierarcy. So the best tip any player can give to a new player is the easiest tip ever but that might sound dumb and stupid at first but... dont die. Just dont die and it will go just fine.
And did i mention how beatutiful mordor is when you're not slaying dozens and even more dozens of uruk's. If you can run the game on ultra,do. It makes it look so nice and badass.
and it's a nice break from killing uruk's.
Still i gotta complain on some few minor things.
First of all is the story. Even though the story is nice and well presented(i do think monolith did a nice job at giving us a good story) it's just,too short. It's only 20 missions. But then there's the nemesis system which makes up for that cause you probably spend way more time on the nemesis system then on the story at first.(nemesis system ftw)
Another thing that i just have to say and this one is probably a bit personal but still,the game is way too easy. The captains don't have a lot of variety really so i just found myself doing the same approach on nearly every single captain. Love the game or hate the game. me myself i love it.
The duo combat(and by that i mean switching between sword and bow,aka talion's sword urfael and celebrimbor's bow azkar which is very useful in most battles. If you have read this far,picture yourself this scenario. You are in a stronghold(fort) and you got,let's say,40+ uruk's coming right at you. You know you got no chance with sword only. and then u see a grog barrel in the middle of the uruk's. Well what do you do now? I'd say blow the grog barrel up and you probably will only have between 5-15 enemies left.
Conclusion: Middle Earth Shadow of Mordor is the best LotR game to date. Even if i do hope for a sequel,it probably wont come any.
The combat is great,the open world is good but could be larger,the story could be longer but it's a nice story for a good game,the rune system is brilliant,the nemesis system is unique and basically AWESOME and at last, the voice acting is friggin awesome. This game gets a solid 10 even tho it lacks on some things but its a good game. Basically one of the many must play games of 2014.

reviewText:
I just finished the main campaign in this game, and started touching on the DLC missions, but this review will focus on the basegame. There's a reason this game received the GOTY award from multiple reviewers and journalists.

It brought a couple of unique features to a genre that was sorely needing something fresh.
1. The unique AI engine that made enemies remember you, power up to battle you again if they lost previously or if they won boast in your face as they attempt to best you again. Each enemy had unique properties and rarely would a direct approach help you much. Especially in the beginning.
2. The weapons were basic and simplistic, but offered a lot more and had a deeper narrative if you knew where to look.
3. The environments were lovely with some interesting characteristics and many hints at the books and movies.
4. The art direction, specifically with the Uruks and their armor, weapons and scowls were just superb. That green skin textures used in game made them look real. I was in awe when I first saw it.
5. The playstyle, with a unique concequence to death and to leveling up. The stealth mechanic worked nicely, but added some difficulty ot the game as well.

The storyline is not amazing, or new or unique. But it is a very proper LOTR lore. And they made proper use of the characters. In the end, what more can we ask for?

The only real negative point comes in the learning curve. If it's your first time playing it, there's a lot of detail going on and a lot of reading to understand everything. However the tips and tutorials are properly documented and are helpful all the way to the end.

I would absolutely recommend this game.

reviewText:
My memory of 30+ hours in Mordor is an endless blur of pretty executions of orcs.

It was fun, but I'm kind of relieved I've finished.


tldr;

If I could leave both a YES and NO recomendation I would. Here's why:

Batman + Assassins creed? Sorry... No. It's not. (That's not really a compliment).

Let's get straight to what this game really is : Shadow of Mordor is essentially two giant battle arenas. Every single mission is about killing orcs/uruks and captains. The variation on missions is simply to kill orcs/uruks/captains using different power ups you earned. Forget the story, it's nicely presented but its not much more than a background texture. Here's a bit of story to rest your fingers, but NOW GO KILL SOME MORE ORCS!

The comparissons with AC and Batman are valid in that SoM has borrowed a lot (and I mean A LOT) of gameplay elements to the point it is fairly shameless. If I were a dev on AC I'd be like Hey bro
date: get your own ideas. FFS!" But what they took are strong elements that made those games work (like Batman's fighting and AC's character controls).\n\nSo here's the thing
recommended: the fighting in SoM is good fun and very satisfying - and it keeps getting more satisfying as you level up. The nemesis system is very good (the uruks look great and have huge variation). In short it's an addictive very well produced fighting game. It doesn't have much soul but it's very good at what it does.\n\nIf your want more than an endless battle fest

reviewText:
Finally we have a LoTR game worthy of many hours of our time! Shadow of Mordor brings free roaming adventure and game changing new features together to make one amazing game. One of those games where you get lost in its mechanics and find yourself putting the story on the back burner. For me that's a good sign of a game with good longevity.
Nemesis system is great, combat is satisfying and gory to boot. Story is there but I find myself making my own story to enhance the main one. RPG elements are there. I especially like how the weapons upgrade with ruins you collect off of war chiefs or other notable enemies. Graphics are great. There is not much tediousness that comes with the open world genre. You can fast travel pretty readily conveniently. But this is one of those worlds where I prefer to get lost in and take that short cut threw the woods.
Even if you are not a fan of Lord of the Rings check this game out. It is an amazing game on its own.
If you are a die hard Tolkeinite the lore should not be that blasphemous to you either.

reviewText:
First off, should you get it? It depends I suppose.

> Do you like Lord of the Rings? I hadn't touched a book, nor saw a movie. But I liked it ( I do know some lore though )
> Do you like a lot of side missions to build up to help you in the main story? If yes, this is for you. ( If no, don't have to do them entirely )
>Do you like hack n slashing, with amazing and brutal kills, sleek killstreaks and wraith powers to dominate in battle? If yes to anyone these, this is for you!
>Do you like the ability to manipulate the story with your actions, to make it easier or harder? If yes, this is for you!
>Do you like plot twists, with dramatic music filled with horns and thundering drums? If yes, you guessed it, this is for you!
>Do you like picking flowers for health, and when you feel a little fruity? Then yes, this is for you.

I find this to be a great game to play, very fun, and fullfilling. However, you do see repetitiveness in some fights, in manner of kill animations, and some are just of one style. However, the equal set of diversity of these moves, and that you can change your style to evoke other animations, make that null for an issue. At least for a while.

Also, if you've ever played a Batman Arkham game, then familiarity will flow through your fingers. Though the effects will obviously differ, and somethings our protagonist can just do that Batboy cannot, you do have a sense of similarity. It  is actually somewhat easier in this than an Arkham game. But can be much harder as well.

In the end, I really do believe this is a good game to get. Small amount of main story missions, ( 20 ) but you will be too tempted with so much else that you will only get one or two done between every 30 side missions. Give or take a few... :D
And continueous playability as long as you don't mind manipulation of the Uruk ranks without any story influence. ( I stopped since completion of story, because albiet fun, it got boring. ) Still recommend, just take the story slow.

reviewText: Despite underutilised characters and voice actors, and a story that reeks of terrible fan fiction, Shadow of Mordor is a solid (albeit on the smaller side) open-world experience. It's a great mix of Assassin's Creed parkour and discovery, and Arkham combat. The real meat and enjoyment of Mordor comes from the Nemesis system, a refreshing new gameplay hook that adds near-infinite replayability to the free roam (though you'll need to get through a good portion of the story to unlock every mechanic of it), which enables memorable encounters and rivalries with the multitude of randomly generated Orc characters.\n\nThe biggest draw back of Shadow of Mordor (in my opinion): no difficulty options, and as such a solid player will bypass some of the most fun aspects of the Nemesis system (which incorporates your defeats). By the endgame and at 100% content completion, you may still be left wanting more, but the lack of difficulty at that point may be a deal-breaker to the otherwise great free-roaming under the Nemesis system.

reviewerDisplayName: Not Here for Fortune or Fame
reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor is a pretty decent stealth/action game. It plays a lot like Assassin's Creed, with a focus on parkour and wall-climbing with QTE-ridden hand-to-hand combat mechanics but the various upgradable skills and runes give it it's own flavour in terms of gameplay.

The much-toted Nemesis System is pretty solid, too. While it occasionally spits out fairly unremarkable opponents, it's also provided me with some very entertaining rivals. There's something about turning the cannon fodder enemy that happened to snipe you as you were making a clean getaway and turning him into an unstoppable leader that provides a very unique thrill. Unfortunately, I did notice an unfortunate tendency for my rivals to die horrifically shortly after I brainwashed them into joining me (RIP, Dush the Caragor-Slayer, whose post-duel fanfare was cut tragically short by a giant rock monster), and frustratingly while enemy Orcs can respawn under the right conditions there's no such luck for allied ones.

There's a fairly decent campaign and a large number of optional quests, too, though some are definitely better than others. The slave rebellion missions in particular play out nearly identical to each other, which is very jarring since the Legend" quests usually have a unique gimmick or two to make them stand out. There's also a few dozen relics to hunt down and elven symbols etched into walls that provide a neat little diversion as well.

I did have some performance issues at times-- I had a recurring crash on launch that required me to restart my computer every few sessions in order to fix it
date: and the framerate does tank a bit during particularly busy sections. Shadow of Mordor is also fairly buggy at times-- I had several dozen instances where orcs randomly flew into the air
recommended: the ziplines had a tendency to make me clip into the scenery (forcing a reset) or fall out of the world entirely
hoursPlayed: and on two seperate instances the game crashed immediately after a lengthy quest forcing me to redo it.\n\nBut while Shadow of Mordor is definitely rough around the edges at times

reviewText:
A well put together Assassin's Creed-a-like with Batman: Arkham ____'s combat system set in middle earth.

The presentation, graphics, controls, etc are all well done. It's a really well made game.

If you don't like Assassin's Creed gameplay you probably won't like it. Like those games, I can't decide if I'm having fun while playing it or if it just does a really good job at letting me tick boxes and check lists (GOT ALL THE COLLECTABLES, AW YEAH). Either way, I 100%ed it so I must have been having some fun.

The story was an interesting take on Middle Earth and I liked the story it told, but I feel like they may have taken a bit of creative liberty with the Tolkien license...

One of the main highlights of the game is the Nemesis system, which I'm sure you've already read about if you're interested in this game. It's very well done and leads to some interesting battles. Playing around with it allows you to sort of create monsters/nemesis, and it's very fun. Nothing like encountering a guy early who is immune to range attacks, melee attacks, and stealth attacks, but is only weak to fire. Randomized orc leaders means you have to develop new strategies often, which keeps the gameplay very interesting.

Overall, a good game though. Worth the play, for sure.

reviewText:
It's a game built almost entirely out of parts from the Assassin's Creed and Batman Arkham games, but with one or two parts of its own. It's something slightly less than the sum of its parts, but that's mostly because the new parts it brings to the table are great, but by the time you actually get to use them properly, the game is half to 2/3rds over already.

The story and characters are garbage that don't go anywhere, the environments are dull and samey, and most of the parts the game steals from Assassin's Creed aren't quite as polished as they are in that series. The combat stuff from the Arkham series is fine, and there's enough of a twist on it to make it something interesting, a feat that Arkham Origins failed to pull off. But the new stuff is where the actual gold is, and it's barely uncovered until far, far too late.

Took me 22 hours to finish, but a lot of that was wasted time. I'd recommend powering through the story missions as fast as possible until you get the branding ability, which I didn't do but wish I had. The trouble is by the time you get that, and especially once you can get branded warchiefs, the game is mostly over, and you barely get a chance to play with these systems and abilities.

I'd definitely recommend playing it, but don't set your expectations too high. Wait for a sale, or at least until you can get it cheap somewhere like that Brazilian online game store, like I did.

reviewText:
Finally we have a LoTR game worthy of many hours of our time! Shadow of Mordor brings free roaming adventure and game changing new features together to make one amazing game. One of those games where you get lost in its mechanics and find yourself putting the story on the back burner. For me that's a good sign of a game with good longevity.
Nemesis system is great, combat is satisfying and gory to boot. Story is there but I find myself making my own story to enhance the main one. RPG elements are there. I especially like how the weapons upgrade with ruins you collect off of war chiefs or other notable enemies. Graphics are great. There is not much tediousness that comes with the open world genre. You can fast travel pretty readily conveniently. But this is one of those worlds where I prefer to get lost in and take that short cut threw the woods.
Even if you are not a fan of Lord of the Rings check this game out. It is an amazing game on its own.
If you are a die hard Tolkeinite the lore should not be that blasphemous to you either.

column22:
lets talk about the story. First of all I would have to say that Tolkien purists may do well to steer clear of the game (as many do the movies). The game takes many liberties with the Tolkien universe that might not be as appreciated. While I was able to follow the story easily enough I found in most cases I could not engage emotionally with the primary protagonist(s). Talion and his (trusty?) wraith sidekick family flashbacks served little more purpose than to push the story a long. I found that I cared more for some of the secondary characters than I did the primary...yeah. Overall the story takes a slightly different approach to the battle against Sauron and his minions than what we are all used to seeing. It is a refreshing viewpoint to see and could set the stage for even more aggressive "based on" Middle-earth lore.

Just one more before bed...
Another failing point in the story is its brevity. We are treated to some very cool ideas and concepts that if further explored could've provide some solid content. This wasn't necessarily an overall negative for my experience

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor can be best described as Assassin's Creed meets Middle Earth. The story is okay, the real gem of the game are the orcs.

You see, you can play the game like Assassin's Creed and go after the baddies however you want: or you can find a random orc, help him about to be the strongest of orcs by fighting duels for him and killing his enemies until the point where he is the strongest orc in the land-- then you kill him for a high level upgrade for your weapon. Rinse and Repeat.

I find the orcs much more fun than our protaganist as they each have their own personalities and there is nothing like dying to some nameless orc who now is popular after your death and studying him until you find out he is afraid of bees and then putting a beehive under his bed as the ultimate revenge.

For $20 expect about 30-40 hours of solid game play, or about $0.50/hour.

reviewText:
I just finished the main campaign in this game, and started touching on the DLC missions, but this review will focus on the basegame. There's a reason this game received the GOTY award from multiple reviewers and journalists.

It brought a couple of unique features to a genre that was sorely needing something fresh.
1. The unique AI engine that made enemies remember you, power up to battle you again if they lost previously or if they won boast in your face as they attempt to best you again. Each enemy had unique properties and rarely would a direct approach help you much. Especially in the beginning.
2. The weapons were basic and simplistic, but offered a lot more and had a deeper narrative if you knew where to look.
3. The environments were lovely with some interesting characteristics and many hints at the books and movies.
4. The art direction, specifically with the Uruks and their armor, weapons and scowls were just superb. That green skin textures used in game made them look real. I was in awe when I first saw it.
5. The playstyle, with a unique concequence to death and to leveling up. The stealth mechanic worked nicely, but added some difficulty ot the game as well.

The storyline is not amazing, or new or unique. But it is a very proper LOTR lore. And they made proper use of the characters. In the end, what more can we ask for?

The only real negative point comes in the learning curve. If it's your first time playing it, there's a lot of detail going on and a lot of reading to understand everything. However the tips and tutorials are properly documented and are helpful all the way to the end.

I would absolutely recommend this game.

reviewText: This is one of the most fun open world games I have played. Last year I was spoiled with a ton of good new games which included Dragon Age Inquisition, Lords of the Fallen, and The Evil WIthin, but I just keep coming back to Shadows. If you found yourself just roaming around fighting guys in the open world of the Arkham games then this is for you. I have barely even touched the story yet since just roaming around and interacting with the nemesis system is so much fun. There is all kinds of emergent gameplay to be had here and every play session is like a random story creator. The combat is flashy and fun, and has more depth than one would think when starting out. Learning captain's and warchief's strengths and weaknesses adds a neat strategic spin on the brutal fighting. There is nothing quite like knowing a captain is afraid of caragors (awesome potential chaos causers and mounts) and then riding one into battle and seeing his panic. It does seem to borrow from a few other great games, but it adds its own spin to things. You will find yourself fighting crazy amounts of enemies at once which really puts your skills to the test. Walking into a fortified stronghold after upgrading your skills a bit and starting a fight with a giant horde of orcs never gets old. I found myself ignoring the orcs that signal others on purpose and then just seeing how long I could last against 50+ of them. It is great for long or short play sessions. Even when I only have 15 or 20 minutes to spare I can find something fun to do. There are also upgrades to your character's abilities and weapons as well as collectables to be found. I can not recommend this enough.

A thinking persons hack and slash.

Once you learn the different moves/actions you might want to remap a couple of keys, but it can be played with a mouse/keyboard effectively.

i almost forgot to mention: the graphics are amazing, as is the voice acting.And the Nemesis system is awesome as well.

reviewText:
Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor    Reviewed in pros-and-cons format

Pros:
Combat works well
Nemesis system is unique
Captains and Warchiefs are unique and very enjoyable to kill
Stealth, ranged and melee combat options work well together
Perks and abilities are very well done
Various strongholds are well-designed and based off of game's mechanics
Voice acting is very well done
Enemy variety
Animation is smooth and beautiful
Cons:
Story is bland
Combat is made rather simple and easy with button prompts
Can get repetitive
Stealth and ranged are very simplistic
Open world can feel empty
Late-game is very easy
Overall:
Shadow of Mordor has a lot of good ideas. While some aspects could be better and the game is very obviously inspired by AC and Batman, it has a unique flair that makes it stand out

8.5/10; worth the money

reviewText:
Im not a fan of repetitive games most of the time, but just like FC3, i cant get enough of killing things in this game. It must be the cinematic way that you can kill things that draws me in most. Its not easy to master, but its easy to play if you are halfway competent in games.(which thankfully i am at least halfway...)

Graphics are great, the way things die are awesome, find secrets, the orc boss system is pretty fantastic as well. I also like that the bosses progress when they kill you and become your nemesis, which promptly pisses me off and makes me want to go out and get my revenge. My pc is pretty monster but in other games ive has slowdowns where in this game, seemingly no matter whats on screen, it stays pretty fluid, set on mostly high and some ultra settings. (this is also the first game that vsync has helped instead of hurt for me, got rid of screen tearing).

I could envision myself running around this game, continually killing and ♥♥♥♥♥ing killed, jumping up buildings and over enemies and blockign and ....well you get the idea.

its sunday 27th of april and i bought this yesterday during a half price sale for 25.49, which included the season pass.

if your reading this before monday, and have even a slight interest in this, i say its a no brainer at 25 bucks.

reviewText:
Middle Earth™: Shadow of Mordor™ is a third-person action-adventure game developed by Monolith Studions (known for such works as the F.E.A.R. and Condemned franchises) and published by Warner Bros. Interactive. The game's story takes place in Tolkien's 'Lord of the Rings' universe while gameplay takes inspiration from the Batman Arkham titles as well as some elements from the Assassin's Creed franchise, and at the same time, featuring an all new mechanic called the 'Nemesis

Pros:
Good graphics, animation quality, special effects and over-all art style
Great use of the 'Lord of the Rings' franchise and material
Excellent voice acting and over-all sound design that adds to the atmosphere and immersion of the game
Relatively large map with several side missions and collectibles
Combat gameplay is fun and satisfying making good use of the Arkham/Assassin's Creed gameplay

Cons:
Story is a bit weak and some of the characters were not particularly memorable
Gameplay is not as challenging as I would have expected from an action-adventure game
Orc Captains / Warchiefs level cap at 20
The final boss was boring and too easy, not challenging at all.

reviewText:
Could be called a Batman Arkham City Reskin due to it's many similarities with the game including: The combat system, Elf vision/Detective vision, the upgrade system and the interrogation of enemies being the main elements carried over between the two games.

However, despite some striking resemblances and i'm well aware that both games are published by Warner Bros, Shadow of Mordor is a compelling, stand alone game that actually improves on some of the elements found present in arkham city especially with the political hierarchy of the orcs as a new implement.

The combat system was the highlight of the game for me as i've always loved the arkham series' combat system and it remained fluid and satisfying whenever you pull of long combos.

The game has plenty to do and you don't feel forced to pursue the main quest as you can just freeroam and do as you please which makes Shadow of Mordor all the more immersive. The ending was quite dissapointing unfortunately especially with the final boss but the journey to the ending most definitely makes up for it.
