reviewText:
Rumor grew of a Shadow in the East...whispers of a great game in the land of Mordor.

Even to a newcomer, Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is comfortably familiar. It is not a sequel, but it feels like one. Most who play this game will have seen the Lord of the Rings films, or read the books, or played either the Assassin's Creed series or the Batman Arkham series. Shadow of Mordor is greatly influenced by these popular sources. From its gameplay, to its story, to its visual style and soundtrack, this game makes you feel like you're returning to a land that you love. It is, however, this same familiarity that cuts into its longevity.

The big innovation that Shadow of Mordor brings to the table is its Nemesis system. Much praise has been heaped upon it. In my view, it works very well in an open world game but it is not without its weaknesses. For example, it is enthralling to cross blades with orc captains when each one feels unique from the others. Yet it also seems impossible for a pseudo-randomly generated boss to match that of a static, hand crafted boss like you'd find in other games. The Nemesis system has quantity on its side and is more true to life but tends not to be as memorable or as fun to fight as those bosses you find in games like Dark Souls or Shadow of the Colossus. To its credit, Shadow of Mordor also has a handful of standard boss  fights throughout its main missions. Unfortunately, the final one is a major letdown in the form of a short series of quick time events.

Tolkien's Middle-earth is immensely rich in history. Shadow of Mordor's story utilizes that history mostly for the game's setting, and then makes up the actual plot as its own alternative history. As someone who has seen all the movies but never read the books, I was very pleased that the story was both new to me and still connected to the epic tale we all love. With the exceptions of Gollum, Sauron and a couple brief cameos that I won't spoil, the cast is composed of characters not seen in the films. Not until writing this did I look up to see how close the game sticks to lore and it seems the consensus is that it largely doesn't. Yet this doesn't bother me and, if anything, I wish the game had had more story and was less gameplay centric. This was definitely written more for fans of the movies than for scholars of the Silmarillion.

Artistically this game takes most of its cues from the original movie trilogy. Orcs, Elves, Dwarves and Men look and sound as they do in the films. I see that as a good quality. The voice acting is very well done, particularly for video game standards (though those have been rising in recent years). The soundtrack is mostly befitting of the orcs. The heavy percussion, deep horns, cellos and warlike chants can actually become too imposing at times, making me wish for a brief respite.

Environmental design I found to be somewhat weak, though it was obviously catered more to gameplay than visual spectacle. Some of that is hard to escape with the first half of the game taking place in the barren, rocky wastes of Udûn. The second half's setting along the Sea of Núrnen is more lush and interesting to look at. Both areas, however, feel relatively small. This is less an artistry complaint and more a wish for greater real estate in which to battle the orcs and beasts of Mordor. The game is never able to imitate the movies' epic, sweeping vistas.

At around 30 hours for 100% completion of the main game, Shadow of Mordor is not as long as many similar games out there. Yet in the waning hours I still found myself growing bored. Many of the side quests and a few of the primary missions I could have done without. In particular, the 24 Outcast quests are painfully repetitive and have no business being so numerous other than to pad out play time. It doesn't help that, aside from The Bright Lord DLC, I found this game to be considerably easier than I anticipated.

I would list both major DLCs, Lord of the Hunt and The Bright Lord, as disappointing as well. Neither introduces any new areas to explore nor deepens the story in any appreciable way. I will say that the final battle of The Bright Lord is like the end boss we never got in the main campaign. Even still, I wouldn't recommend either outside of the Game of the Year bundle. For some, Shadow of Mordor's familiarity will hurt it sooner than it will for others. For me, it never bred contempt but it did darken an otherwise compelling game.

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor is one of those rare games based on previously established, popular IP that happens to be really really good. And it seems, lately, that the publisher contracting developers of these games happens to be Warner Brothers. Shadow of Mordor, the Arkham games, and the recent Mad Max have all proven themselves to be stellar amazing games. And, as some people may notice, there is also a trend across the Arkham games, Shadow of Mordor, and Mad Max, the open world and free flow combat. Some poeple may say the trend is a bit much and is being done over and over again, but as long as the environments and stories and superb, I don't see the problem. In fact, I love open world action adventure games, they're just so much fun to explore.

That said, here's my take on Shadow of Mordor, which kind of plays around with the Lord of the Rings mythology and the origins of the rings. Amazing. I really loved this game. It wasn't just the plot, which wasn't the most epic, but the idea of a gravewalker, a man who had died but was revived by a wraith. Talion is that man, who, involuntarily, is joined with an elf, Celebrimbor. After watching his family die and being slewn himself, Talion is cursed and stuck in Mordor, and tasks himself of getting revenge against the Black Hand of Sauron. You're start in the valley of Udun, the area north-west of Mount Doom in the very north-west corner of Mordor, where you meet outcasts and former Ranger Hirgorn. Eventually, you learn about the ranking system with the orcs and uruks, meaning you have to kill a number of captains and warchiefs before even attempting to fight The Hammer, one of your targets. The story progresses along rather quickly but you can consume so much time doing various side missions and collecting artifacts.

Then there's the nemesis system, the heart and soul of Shadow of Mordor. The nemesis system is, undoubtedly, the most fun I've had in recent gaming. At some point in the story, you learn how to brand the enemies, even captains and warchiefs, and pit them against each other, let them rise through the ranks, ultimately building your own army. It's pretty great.

Graphics wise, this game is stunning. At points in Udun, it's grim, forboding, dark, and it seems like there's a great evil lurking everywhere. Really, it's just you hiding in the shadows, waiting for the next kill, or going all out with the free flow combat and combat finishers. The executions are glorious as well. In the southern area, the Sea of Nurnen, is lush and gorgeous with flowing green grass and trees. It didn't even really occur to me how big Mordor is until I looked on an actual map to see where the sea is as I'd never really read any of Tolkein's works beyond The Hobbit and the LoTR trilogy. So when I saw where Mount Doom is in relation to the whole of Mordor, I was actually rather shocked. I would have loved to see Mordor in its entirety, which would be a massive task, not to mention how much bigger the open world would be when compared to how small the world in Shadow of Mordor is. If the in game measurement of feet is accurate, then the whole game is about 1 square mile, maybe a bit more. Still, the game probably benefits from the small size compared to Mad Max where everything is so spread out, but at least you have a car taking you to places there.

Anyway, Shadow of Mordor might have messed around with the lore, but it's a great game and a great experience.

9.3/10

reviewText:
Where do I even start? This game won me over, when I didn't really expect too much of it. I had heard several different opinions about it, and wasn't sure whether I'd enjoy it.I bought it when it was on sale, and just finished it. And I enjoyed it a LOT.
Let's go through it:

Story:
The story is not very deep, and neither is it Tolkien-level writing. It actually messes with the lore of Sauron, the One Ring, and Celebrimbor quite a lot. But STILL, I did enjoy it. It isn't all that deep, but it's dark, tragic and makes you care about the main protagonists.
Please note that I am a big Tolkien-fan, and while I realize that this is a bit lore-breaking, I still enjoyed the game and the story a lot.

Graphics:
The game looks great. The first zone is rather dull, which fits Mordor. The second zone is nicer. And I disagree with those reviewers who said it is wrong, or doesn't look right. This is a zone which had a lake, and that, together with the volcanic ashes of Mt. Doom, made for quite fertile soil. This is actually according to lore.

Gameplay:
If you like AC and Batman, you'll get a handle of the mechanics quickly. Attacks, jumps, dodging, blocking etc. You have to adjust to different enemies. Sometimes, a tactical retreat to heal and reattack is helpful. I think I did about three times by the hands of an orc, and twice by some creature (Caragor).
There are some fun moves you can do, especially the shadow strike, which isn't only a powerful one-shot move, it also helps to get around camps full of orcs.

The fun REALLY starts once you get the ability to brand orcs so they fight FOR you. You can tactically brand an area full of orcs before you go for a stronger one or start a mission there to improve your chances.

Yes, you CAN go for a certain build (stealth, archery, swordfight, mounted fight), BUT the missions will force you to use different playstyles at some point. So even if you don't go for archery too much, the game eventually requires you to use it for a while. Also, with the story quests and all the side-stuff I did, I got to the point where I unlocked almost all abilities in the skill tree anyway, and opened up most rune slots etc, so all play-styles where useable and I had special abilities for each of them.
And finishing those hunting quests with the dwarf in the second zone opened up some abilities and how to use them that felt pretty epic. =)

At first, you wanna be careful about picking your fights, but eventually, you can handle several big groups.
The final boss fight is often critizised, and I agree, it seems a bit underwhelming. Then again, how could you expect to actually hold your own against this enemy for too long? You go through a couple of sub-bosses shortly before this fight, and then you get one shot, and you use it.

Nemesis-system:
This is the most innovative system of the game. It shines even more if you die a lot and really start to hate certain mobs. I didn't die too often, but if an orc managed to kill me, I really REALLY was out for revenge.
It's a VERY cool idea IMO. Not only one of the coolest parts about SoM, but in general, just a great idea, just like the branding.

Content:
The story isn't TOO long... I hear you can finish that in about 10 hrs or less. There is a lot of side content which is NOT mandatory. It's the system you have in most open-world games... it CAN be grindy if you do all the rather repetitive side content, but you don't have to. I did the side-missions for a while in order to make my army of orcs stronger and level my orc leaders, but eventually stuck to story missions. I recommend a mix of both... do the story, but if you feel like it, do a bit of the side-content. Dont burn yourself out on doing too much of the side-stuff, but don't ignore it either, otherwise you'll most likely go through the game too quickly.

Music:
Even though it occasionally sounds pretty much like some MIDI-library, some of it sounds great, especially tracks with the choir.

Overall:
I didn't expect to enjoy this as much as I did. It has its flaws, surely, like the typical open world with tons of repetitive side content"

Batman meets Assassin's Creed combined with a bit of Game of Thrones all set in the world of Lord of the Rings.

reviewText:
Very good adventure game.
Yes, it's reusing lots of gameplay from Assassin's Creed but with a very nice twist thanks to the addition of Tolkien's world.
So, it's not a new type of game of anything but it's really polished.
Story is good, with loads of cutscenes, extra secondary missions, very nice new idea of the warchiefs and their bodyguards, nice world and graphics, good game.
And overall, even if you might be doing the same kind of missions all the time, some well thought random elements will need you to adapt. I really like how each captain of warchiefs had their own strenghts and weeknesses so you won't be able to do the same combat techniques.
Well thought mix of stealth and combat. The combat are so fluid too.
No really, I wonder why this game didn't make the top list.

reviewText:
This game is quality, real quality.

The graphics are beautiful, the characterisation is excellent (especially of the orc chieftains and even the grunts), the architecture of the orc strongholds and scenery in general is outstanding but these are actually second to the gameplay.

The fighting is its main strength and boy what a strength.  When you combine your ninja abilities with tailoring your planned attack against a nemesis or just a top dog on the to-do list, this is so good and I mean really good.  Especially when you get rumbled and have to make a sharp exit.

The only detracting factor for me was that I found the game a little easy when you're powered up and found most fun and excitement at lower levels.

That minor criticism aside this is still a 9/10

Well worth getting.

reviewText: Superb game, very fun.  Looks beautiful especially with the dynamic weather.  The story is good and the nemesis system works really well.  There is varied gameplay with side missions a plenty and if you feel like it, jut run around killing the Uruk-Hai.  There are skill tree's which you have to earn XP for to unlock to improve your moves and unlock extra ones to make the combat varied when you do get into a struggle against more than one captain.  There are also runes which you can equip on your weapons to improve various different stats.  The game is very well optimised unlike some games which have been released this year and works very well at 1440p with an AMD R9 290 gpu, achieving over 60 fps.  If you enjoy both the batman and assassins creed series of games you should enjoy this game as it mixes different elements of the two together very well.  All in all I would have to award this game as my game of the year for 2014.

reviewText:
[After 20 hours in the game] One of the best games I played the last months. Really impressive gameplay (great mix of Batman combat system and Assassin's Creed free-run). The only dissapointing part was that there was not a big boss battle in the end and some QTE (Quick Time Events) which I think they shouldn't be existing in the game.
I didn't experience any kind of bug after all that hours, which immediately gives the gamer a +1 for me. The control of the character was more than satisfying (people who play Batman or Assassin's Creed 1-2 will find really easy to get used to controls) and I love that there was a leadership ladder in the Orcs army and you could fight them. And I have to point out that it was the best combat system I have seen so far, you could do amazing things, you can fight plenty of enemies at the same time, but the mistakes cost you a lot. Beautiful story compined with an equal good soundtrack. Moreover it has a great optimization for pc, I runned this game with the HD pack with no fps drops at all and everything maxed out (1080p) +1 for not forgetting the pc gamers and just releasing console game with bad optimization for pc users.


8.5/10 with the perspective of just a gamer (I would really love to have a kickass boss battle in the end), 9.5/10 as a LOTR fan. :)

reviewText:
Middle Earth:Shadow of Mordor-Review

This game for me is Game Of The Year at the moment...

The Combat:
It is a brutal version of the Arkham games and with all the upgrades you feel like an Orc slayer. NOTE: This game is no cakewalk

The Nemisis System:
An Extremely clever system that makes the gameplay feel Personal...
If they kill you then they mention that they killed you before. e.g. Are your brains scrambled tark
date:
every time you face me you die."
The Orcs In my game will be completely different to the ones in yours. They may look the same or have the same names but they will all have different Strengths/Weaknesses.

The Graphics and optimisation
This is no port.It functions very well and with out difficulty (If your PC meets the specs)
The Graphics are also very suitable for the games style.

The Story:
The Story is pretty good and well voice acted by the amazing Troy Baker as Talion and Andy Serkis... to name a few. I don't want to spoil the story but all I will say is...The Ending leaves it open for a sequel.

Overall:
I really like this game and I think buying the season pass is worth it.
And you don't have to like the Tolkein books to like the game.
9.8/10
The game took me 34 hours to complete and the thing that takes it down 0.2 marks is that there are a fair few QTEs"

reviewText: Superb game, very fun.  Looks beautiful especially with the dynamic weather.  The story is good and the nemesis system works really well.  There is varied gameplay with side missions a plenty and if you feel like it, jut run around killing the Uruk-Hai.  There are skill tree's which you have to earn XP for to unlock to improve your moves and unlock extra ones to make the combat varied when you do get into a struggle against more than one captain.  There are also runes which you can equip on your weapons to improve various different stats.  The game is very well optimised unlike some games which have been released this year and works very well at 1440p with an AMD R9 290 gpu, achieving over 60 fps.  If you enjoy both the batman and assassins creed series of games you should enjoy this game as it mixes different elements of the two together very well.  All in all I would have to award this game as my game of the year for 2014.

reviewText:
(tl;dr Skip to the bottom for Pros + Cons)
Shadow of Mordor is the open world game we've been waiting for. It uses the Arkham games free flow system with the Assassin's Creed open world. Its a perfect mixture of the two that creates such an amazing game. The combat is very fluid and incrediebly responsive. The open world is large with many side missions and collectibles.

The crown jewel of this game is the Nemesis System. To put it in basic term, every Orc you face will remeber who you are. So if you get killed by an Orc, then when you go back for a rematch they'll remeber that they killed you and they'll remeber details of the battle. Its unbelievable how well this system works. Each Orc looks different and has their own strengths and weakensses that you can expliot by capturing other Orcs and compelling them to tell you about their captain.

The main story is very good. Troy Baker once again delivers an amazing experience by voicing the main character. Sadly we didn't see much of Nolan North even though he was supposed to be the main baddie. Side missions are fun and challenging. Each has a goal for you to do, like kill 10 Orcs with stealth while not alerting anyone. And each missions has a bonus option that will give you extra XP.

Now there are some bad parts of the game. The game is optimzied but it still has its hicups when fighting large amounts of enemies. Also, the cutscenes, even on Ultra, are very low quality. The boss battles are very easy, which is something that shocked me. The Warchief battles or even a nemesis battle can be pretty hard, but the 3 main boss battles were basic and somewhat boring.

Pros:
1. Amazing open world
2. Fluid Combat System
3. Great voice acting and story
4. The Nemesis System

Cons:
1. Low Quality Cutscenes
2. Bad Performance in some areas
3. Simple boss battles

All in all, this game is hands down one of the best I've seen this year. I cannot wait for the DLC to come out. I really hope this game gets a sequel, cause this is probably my favorite LOTR game ever. 8.5/10

reviewText:
Of all the LoTR games throughout the years, this one definitely tops them all.  From combat, to story, to skill mechanics, the game beats out all previous installments.  SoM does a great job putting you in the world of Middle Earth while also keeping you specifically out of the direct story line of the LoTR, breathing into it a fresh perspective on the game.

You play in 3rd person mode and wade through waves of Orcs as you seek to uncover the past behind your ghostly friend who constantly appears and shows you how to use your newly unlocked powers.  The world is divided into segments that you can fast travel between in order to complete various quests (divided into two types, story and level up).  Each quest unlocks new runes and skill points.

The game is gorgeous, its graphics are some of the best and the combat mechanics are smooth.  There's very little awkward disconnects in the movement, so you will rarely find yourself looking at fights and wondering how an orc swung his axe 2 feet off from where you are and still hit you.  That being said, the difficulty becomes broken once you're leveled your skills up to a certain point.  Skills like being able to counter by simply tapping the right mouse button when you see the icon means with a little practice you are mostly untouchable.  Add to this some very over powered combos that you can unlock and you're basically the bane of all orcs existence.  This is fun so long as you weren't hoping for a challenge throughout the entire game.  This also can add replay value if you just enjoy wading through enemies and seeing how ridiculous your combo can be.

Overall, the game is engaging and learning how to link together your skills in order to master the art of slaughtering orcs is fun.  If you always wished you could be plopped into the epic battles you see in the LoTR movies, this is as close as you're going to get.  If the developers balanced the skills and added a little more variety into the world, this game would be a shining beacon for all other games in the series to aspire to.  Definitely worth the money!

reviewText:
Shadow of Mordor is a ton of fun. To describe it as part Batman (combat and character upgrades) and part Assassin's Creed (world and mission structure) would be a disservice, as it manages to be better than the sum of its parts. The much-touted nemesis system is an achievement and adds a never before seen dynamic to the open world formula. It's the most dynamic open world game I've played as you can play the with nemesis system seemingly indefinitely, as you fight orc captains and disrupt the military structure of Sauron's army. Halfway through the game you gain the ability to brand enemies which puts them under your control, pitting your orcs against Sauron's. As someone that was skeptical of the marketing that always surrounds games like this, I was pleasantly surprised how well the nemesis actually works.

Orcs that were not killed by decapitation may come back from the dead more powerful seeking revenge (orcs are resilient, if nothing else). Orcs will kill you and level up, becoming captains themselves if they weren't one already. You will likely run into a captain or warchief that continuously bests you and develop a deep desire to get revenge, and when you finally do you will yell at your screen in satisfaction. The orc army will fight amongst itself and generate random events for you to disrupt the balance of power. It's all very, very cool. The amount of work that must've gone into it is staggering.

The story isn't anything special and mostly serves as a MacGuffin for you to interact with the nemesis system. It's serviceable, with excellent voice acting, but remains a fairly typical revenge story. I have no idea how it fits in with the LOTR canon but I'm sure it takes many liberties.

The graphics are nice but not groundbreaking. Mordor looks like Mordor and as such is mostly a brown wasteland. It's a pretty wasteland, but a wasteland nonetheless. There is a second map that is much more lush and green and is welcome change from the first map. I think the VRAM requirements they stated were highballed since I'm able to play with a mix of high and ultra settings on my 2GB GTX 670 at 60fps 95% of the time (textures on High, using adaptive vsync). Animations are top notch and make you feel like a total f-ing badass. The combat animations aren't as smooth as Batman since the combat is more forgiving as lets you counter mid-animation. This can cause some quick and unnatural movements that serve the gameplay more than the visuals.

Climbing is similar to Assassin's Creed but quicker and simpler since your character can jump longer distances and move much faster. Traversal is easy but sometimes the camera runs into problems or you will fight with the multi-purpose buttons (drop and stealth brand are bound to the same thing, as are stealth brutalize [a kill move] and distract).

The music and sound design is excellent especially in combat. The sound FX for executions and certain powers are awesome and make you feel that much more badass.

Overall I think Shadow of Mordor is an excellent game and I hope it does very well for WB and Monolith. I would love to see more games using the nemesis system. I think that from now on any open world game without it will seem stale in comparison.

TL;DR: I would highly recommend playing this game.

reviewText:
[After 20 hours in the game] One of the best games I played the last months. Really impressive gameplay (great mix of Batman combat system and Assassin's Creed free-run). The only dissapointing part was that there was not a big boss battle in the end and some QTE (Quick Time Events) which I think they shouldn't be existing in the game.
I didn't experience any kind of bug after all that hours, which immediately gives the gamer a +1 for me. The control of the character was more than satisfying (people who play Batman or Assassin's Creed 1-2 will find really easy to get used to controls) and I love that there was a leadership ladder in the Orcs army and you could fight them. And I have to point out that it was the best combat system I have seen so far, you could do amazing things, you can fight plenty of enemies at the same time, but the mistakes cost you a lot. Beautiful story compined with an equal good soundtrack. Moreover it has a great optimization for pc, I runned this game with the HD pack with no fps drops at all and everything maxed out (1080p) +1 for not forgetting the pc gamers and just releasing console game with bad optimization for pc users.


8.5/10 with the perspective of just a gamer (I would really love to have a kickass boss battle in the end), 9.5/10 as a LOTR fan. :)

reviewText:
This is my favorite game of all time.

Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a new addition to the Lord of the Rings universe.
I have had this game for a very long time now, and have beaten almost every single thing in the game.

I had a review of this game up prior to this review, but I deleted it to make a brand new one.

First of all, this is the best game I have ever played. Honestly.
I have played many games in the past, but this is my number 1. It has everything you want it to have plus more.

Other than the main story, there are many side quests and other things to do to keep you busy.
I only dunked 25 hours into this game so far, and I still have a few more things to do plus more DLC to download and finish.

If you are getting the game, please get the season pass. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
I finished the game in 25 hours, did all the survival challenges and hunts, collected all the stuff! And so on.
My overall experience was very glitch and bug free, though I did encounter some here and there.
The animations are extremely well done and beautiful to watch but after awhile, I had seen them all.
Combat is fluid and far better than the combat in the Batman games which are known for its wonderful combat.
That they are using code and animations from the Assassin's Creed series is blatantly obvious from the moment you start climbing, I even think I noticed some during combat. However, I don't care as the game is very enjoyable.

Graphically, it was quite pleasing to the eye and I am very impressed with how incredible the game looked and ran on my computer. (I played on the highest setting)

Now onto sound, which is more my thing:
The voice acting is extremely good, but don't expect actors from the movies to show up with a voice role, which annoyed me for one scene when you get to...familiarize yourself with an Istari, without giving too much away.
After awhile, I swear the same actor did all the Uruks and that annoyed me. I also began to hear the same voice being used for two different Captains amongst the Uruks. Overall though, the VO is top dollah, as they say.

The sound design work is familiar to the work done on the movies which was a relief. I heard many references that the sound designer did to keep it in the same field as the films which was sounds that you heard for instance during the reforging of the tower, and the wraith world (Frodo puts on the ring and he enters that domain.)
The sounds of the Caragor were great and a lot of detail went into making them interesting and overall believable. I think I hear a seal in there for them during their running animations.
The combat sound work was a little bit disappointing as there is no power behind the hits of the swords, however, for the executions, there's some great work in both sound design and mixing happening from the engine, to emphasize the brutality of the animation.
I enjoyed the various sounds for Talion's abilities that made you feel powerful and always in control, which is to me, the most important with good sound work.

Music:
They did not flat out copy or just slap on some Howard Shore and call it a day. There are some great original work in here channeling the spirit of Howard Shore but it goes way beyond that. I enjoyed that they combined musical stingers with the combat when you did well. I enjoyed the opening song the most, which I also think was the main theme of the game.
A chant in black speech saying the oh so familiar phrases: One ring to rule them -" etc.
I hope to hear the composer work in other games

reviewText:
Many games have graced the fantasy-rich plains and mountains of Middle-earth, but few have been good, let alone truly great. As a fan of Tolkien's painstakingly detailed universe, I've been set up for a lot of disappointments—but Shadow of Mordor is not one of them. It is a beautifully rendered, undeniably delightful cross between the exploration and discovery of Assassin's Creed and the well-balanced and fun fighting-style of the Batman: Arkham series, all set in one of Tolkien's most bleak and (attractively) desolate atmospheres: Mordor.

The creators took as much care as Tolkien himself to build a Mordor that is true to the author's original vision of it. The mountainous peaks are sharp crags, the roads are muddy trenches, the fortresses are ramshackle works of stones and wood, the forest (when you eventually reach it) is green with hills that roll like waves, the creatures are both grotesque and beautiful (and hostile, don't forget hostile), and the amount of history contained in the codex entries the player picks up is astounding without being overwhelming. The entire environment is spot on, from the Sea of Núrnen to the Black Gate itself.

On top of that, the beings that inhabit Mordor are just as perfectly portrayed. Mordor is filled with orcs and uruks, each one its own ugly, nasty individual with different traits and features. Some of them are afraid of the big, lion-esque mounts called caragors that the player rides. Others are enraged by them and grow stronger when they see one. Some fear fire, some like pain, some hate to be defeated, and some just seem utterly invincible to anything but a stealthy strike from above. Each orc is unique, with its own name and characteristics that change how the player interacts with them during a fight. As the game progresses, players start to remember the names of orcs they've encountered—even building up grudges against orcs that have consistently foiled their attempts to kill them.

And that's what makes Shadow of Mordor truly great. After all, the setting of a game isn't what makes it fun: the gameplay is. And in terms of gameplay, Shadow of Mordor is a knockout! On top of the smooth fighting system and the ability to tame the creatures of Mordor for some well-designed mounted combat, Shadow of Mordor features one of the most fantastic systems I've ever encountered in video games: the Nemesis System. That orc that took an opportune chance to stab you in the back while you were being mauled by a rampaging caragor? Now that he's killed you once, he'll remember you after he's promoted to a captain. Next time you see him he'll mock you. And then he'll kill you again. And again. And maybe even again. And then, when you finally get your revenge and kill him, if you don't decapitate him there's a chance he'll come back one more time (or five), just to ruin your day!

Altogether, Shadow of Mordor was a fantastic Middle-earth experience that made me feel like I really was stalking the dusty expanse of Mordor, hunting down not-so-innocent orcs and claiming vengeance on those who have wronged me. Shadow of Mordor's storyline is certainly not the highlight of the game, but it didn't need to be to thrill me and inspire a weekend long binge of quietly stalking orc captains and slaying the dangerous beasts of Mordor's plains. The well-made environment and the entertaining gameplay gave Shadow of Mordor more value than I ever could have imagined out of another Lord of the Rings game.

reviewText:
This game could possibly be the best open world single play RPG I have ever played.

I found the graphic of this game absolutely stunning. Majority of the game play graphic are even look better than the cut scenes. Don't get too scared from the system requirement, i think this game is actually very well optimised. I have a GTX 850M graphic card and INTEL I5 as processor and 4Gb of RAM. It runs on High graphic setting and i set the textures to Ultra . It runs around 55-60 FPS as I capped the FPS to 60 frames per second.

The combat system in this game aren't that good, as they are pretty much the same as the Batman series which made by WB games. I'm not saying that the combat systems it self is bad, it just seems bit weird on a game that related to the Lord of the Rings. Also the running, stealth, climbing system are looking like Assassin's Creed which is kinda weird as well.

Overall, as a Lord of Rings fan boy, this game just looks awesome to me and i would definitely rate 10/10.
Strongly recommended to all the Lord of Rings fans.

reviewText:
I finished the game in 25 hours, did all the survival challenges and hunts, collected all the stuff! And so on.
My overall experience was very glitch and bug free, though I did encounter some here and there.
The animations are extremely well done and beautiful to watch but after awhile, I had seen them all.
Combat is fluid and far better than the combat in the Batman games which are known for its wonderful combat.
That they are using code and animations from the Assassin's Creed series is blatantly obvious from the moment you start climbing, I even think I noticed some during combat. However, I don't care as the game is very enjoyable.

Graphically, it was quite pleasing to the eye and I am very impressed with how incredible the game looked and ran on my computer. (I played on the highest setting)

Now onto sound, which is more my thing:
The voice acting is extremely good, but don't expect actors from the movies to show up with a voice role, which annoyed me for one scene when you get to...familiarize yourself with an Istari, without giving too much away.
After awhile, I swear the same actor did all the Uruks and that annoyed me. I also began to hear the same voice being used for two different Captains amongst the Uruks. Overall though, the VO is top dollah, as they say.

The sound design work is familiar to the work done on the movies which was a relief. I heard many references that the sound designer did to keep it in the same field as the films which was sounds that you heard for instance during the reforging of the tower, and the wraith world (Frodo puts on the ring and he enters that domain.)
The sounds of the Caragor were great and a lot of detail went into making them interesting and overall believable. I think I hear a seal in there for them during their running animations.
The combat sound work was a little bit disappointing as there is no power behind the hits of the swords, however, for the executions, there's some great work in both sound design and mixing happening from the engine, to emphasize the brutality of the animation.
I enjoyed the various sounds for Talion's abilities that made you feel powerful and always in control, which is to me, the most important with good sound work.

Music:
They did not flat out copy or just slap on some Howard Shore and call it a day. There are some great original work in here channeling the spirit of Howard Shore but it goes way beyond that. I enjoyed that they combined musical stingers with the combat when you did well. I enjoyed the opening song the most, which I also think was the main theme of the game.
A chant in black speech saying the oh so familiar phrases: One ring to rule them -" etc.
I hope to hear the composer work in other games
date: because he quickly rose amongst my favorites
recommended:
just stop and take a listen.

reviewText:
You thought you had gone to murder Orks. Mwahahahaha!!!! As you grind through this game you will come to realize that the Dark Lord designed this game to give his Uruks a bit of fun and training......Indeed you will murder a LOT of Orks. rest assured that new ones will ALWAYS spawn to replace them. You will be suffering from RSI and will need to buy a new mouse and keyboard by game's end to replace the fistful of buttons you need to mash to get through this.

I think one point that needs to be made is the violence in this game is EXTREMELY graphic so keep it away from young people.

Problem is the 'intellectual' content of the game fits about an eight year old. The elaborate plot goes something like this:

Cut scene. Story. Blah. Blah. Blah. Now: KILL, KILL KILL KILL KILL KILL KILL KILL!!!!!!

Producation values are through the roof. Great animations. Solid controls. Recognizeable Tolkein lore that FITS.

But the game is both a chore and a GRIND and something of a bore since the whole thing is about CONTINUOUS combat with a few pseduo-stealth interludes.

The promised 'open world' is not there. The Lore never gets deep. the story never gets interesting. There is little exploration and no role playing.

This game could have been so much more, but it is no Witcher 3.

This is a game to take in short sessions as 'light entertainment' and kill an hour or two and a few hundred  orks or so. Recommended with reservations. A good buy on sale.

reviewText:
This is my favorite game of all time.

Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a new addition to the Lord of the Rings universe.
I have had this game for a very long time now, and have beaten almost every single thing in the game.

I had a review of this game up prior to this review, but I deleted it to make a brand new one.

First of all, this is the best game I have ever played. Honestly.
I have played many games in the past, but this is my number 1. It has everything you want it to have plus more.

Other than the main story, there are many side quests and other things to do to keep you busy.
I only dunked 25 hours into this game so far, and I still have a few more things to do plus more DLC to download and finish.

If you are getting the game, please get the season pass. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Shadow of mordor is Badass to say the least the nemesis system works perfectly making every encounter different.
This game has an enteresting story to tell and an emmensly fun open world to explore with badass orc strongholds filled with  little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, captains and sometimes even warchiefs. This game has in my opinion the best hand to hand combat system I have ever used taking Ideas like its instant parry from assassins creed and the combos from batman arkham franchise. It actually takes alot from the ac series like climbing and parkour, taking parts from batman arkham like the stealth and the bulk of the combat and it even takes from the new tomb raider with the collectables each thing telling its own story. This game was almost perfect and if they added these 5 things it could have been my favorite game of all time its already soo close.

1. give the plants different uses for example the blue one refills the stamina, the green heals you, the yellow makes your weapons deal more damage and red makes you faster. Also adding crafting with scavenged materials would be awesome

2. instead of having graugs and caragors use  different animals from the tolkien universe that are more popular like wargs and cave trolls

3. add dragons yes maybe alot to ask but you cannot deny the badass idea of it, a dragon in each part of the map how badass would that be like the ultimate boss battle

4. have ally camps like three camps per location one for elves, one for dwarves, and one for humans. Each camp would have a blacksmith shop where you could by upgrades for weapons and armor that are not mystical but made from leather and metal these upgrades would change your appearance. Also each camp would have a mission that would help the camp making it upgraded and ready to take mordor.

5. a third location, in this game there are 2 maps one the sea of nurnun and the other is uden but the third location would be really dark there would be volcanoes smoke fire incredbly op enemies a place drowned in evil this would be the last location you head to

the 5 things I have mentioned where things wanted added but where not needed to make this game great it is well worth the price and in a bit of time when more dlc is released it will be worth buying the premium edition. I give this game a 9/10

reviewText:
The gameplay mechanics aren't very original, keyboard/mouse controls can be wonky at times, and the story plays out like a mediocre fanfiction. So why would I recommend this game? Because it's a lot of fun.

Yes, the combat is a direct copy of Arkham City (Right down to uruks with intel glowing green like Riddler's henchmen), but plays equally fluidly, with some minor directional hiccups with keyboard controls. Hunting down captains and warchiefs is very similar to Assassin's Creed, but the killing blow is especially satisfying with an array of intense and brutal combative attacks to unlock. I do like the Nemesis System's design in allowing enemies in increase in power upon yours or a rival captain's defeat, or from them completing specific missions of their own. It makes for a good challenge and a greater necessity to survive any encounter. The side missions are typical of an open world game, but offer some great easter eggs relating to Tolkein's novels for fans.

Exploring Mordor is actually pretty exciting, thanks to the game's graphics. The game looks great, period. Every location is lush and meticulously detailed. Enemy strongholds are twisted and varied for passing through undetected. There are plenty of hidden locations throughout that host hidden collectibles and such, stretching the gameplay a little further.

The story, is decent, but nothing on par with Tolkein's own works. A typical revenge story with a cliffhanger ending leaving things open for a potential sequel. The cinematics however, are outstanding to watch, especially those related to the Wraith's past. Some familiar characters make appearances, and play small roles in the story, but offer nothing more, really.The voice acting is solid, but feature non of the original cast from Peter Jackson's films. However, Liam OBrien as Gollum was a great match for the character's voice in particular.

Overall, I enjoyed Shadow of Mordor much more than I had expected to, even after all the criticism my friends gave it when I initially showed interest. Personally, I think a game related to the LOTR stories being so ultra-violent is gratuitous, but god is it such a guilty pleasure cutting Uruks down one by one.

reviewText:
An orc commander had the chance to finish me off, he said I was not worthy of his blade.
Hunted him down after I picked up the pieces of my shattered pride and killed him... or so I thought.
Few days later, what was supposed to be an easy mission took on a turn for the worst as the commander ambushed me with his many men, the sense of shock I felt; I cannot describe. Somehow, I won the battle, and carried on.
He came back.
and again...
and again...
By the fifth time we met, I had no fear of him: only the desire that the game would let me chop his head off.. and so I did... and my nemesis was no more.

9/10 Batman game in LOtR universe.
People will ask you if you're playing Assasin's Creed... a lot.

+ Tactical boss fights and a Nemesis system
+ Interesting characters and superb cutscenes
+ Great animations, sound effects and graphics
+ Excellent soundtrack and atmosphere

- Can be repetitive
- Story could be more extensive
- Occasional camera angle problems
- Friendly fire can be frustrating in big fights

A game for those who enjoy a solid, responsive combat system and an interesting fantasy setting.

reviewText: A love it or hate it" deal.\n\nFirst of all
date: anyone who has had the remotest of experiences with Assassins Creed or the Batman Arkham series will know exactly whether they like this game or not. Shadow of Mordor is a unapologetic iterative title.\n\nYou can look at it from two ways however. Either you can condemn itnfor having no originality; In which case you'd be wrong
recommended:
as the Nemesis system is one of the most interesting and innovative things for a while in gaming.
Or you'll embrace the similarities and get on with it.
.....................

Sound: 9/10
Sound effects and voice acting is top notch across the board (except for the rather bland voice of the protagonist Talion)
Swords strikes sounds significantly meaty as you cleave through the latest poor ork to cross your path. Also the soundtrack is pretty great as well. Nothing spectacular
hoursPlayed:
but it's a solid hit none the less.

The real star of the show is the Orks. Too long have the Orks been relegated merely to second class infantry units which will fall in a few swings at most. Not so anymore.  You'll really believe these creatures are a real race when they talk. All of them are voice acted to a tee. Absolute 10/10 performance.

Graphics: A hard one to review. The specs the devs say you need to max this game out are hugely exaggerated. I managed to Max the game out (including the HD textures) and still easily keeping a solid 60fps. The 6-8gb they ask for 'Ultra' is complete nonsense.
That being said
voteText: the game looks great. Not mind blowing mind you
helpfulPercent: but still extremely nice. Backdrops are crisp and the Orks facial animations are all very well made considering the sheer variety.\n\nPlot: Easily the weakest part part of the game. Quite a generic story

votesTotal:
if they are going to do something with it and make a good story from it.


Final thoughts: If the devs had maybe pushed the boat out a little further and not gone the rout of just copying AC and the Arkyum games
votesFunny: this could have been something truly special. The nemesis system is a revolutionary way of increasing depth to an otherwise shallow plot and throughout the game you'll craft your own with the orks you face.\nNever the less

reviewText:
Video Review - http://youtu.be/M4fj_PdMMtw

Shadow of Mordor takes place at a time between the Hobbit and Lord of the rings. The game starts at the black gate of mordor which at the time is guarded by the rangers of gondor. You control Talion a ranger of gondor whose wife and child lives there too. Soon Saurons armies lead by the mysterious black hand attack and kill all at the black gate including Talion and his family. You the find yourself resurrected by a wraith. Not only are you now bound to the wraith but talion recieves wraith abilites and powers. The wraith has no memory of who he is only that the black hand may be the key to unlocking his memories and so talion and the wraith set forth into mordor on a mission of revenge and discovery. Who ever said that one does not simply walk into mordor? While the story and indeed the game is not canon the developers have made sure that the settings, characters and story align within canon.

Mordor itself at this point isn't the barren wasteland as in the lord of the rings films. It has buildings, plant life as well as all manners of creatures and beings living there. The game offers a unique look into mordors landscape yet I remain disappointed with the world design. Yes while its not the barren landscape from the lord of the rings films it's an underwhelming murky brown landscape. There are hints of green here and there as well as rain but the whole thing remains a very depressing sight. Which on some level is fine after all this is mordor but I would have liked to have seen a little wow factor in the landscape. There are two main maps in the game, the first is just boring and brown, the second however is much more green and lush but still not the landscape I sought.

You only need to play the game for a short time so see the glaringly obvious similarities in gameplay to another Warner brothers title that being Batman Arkham city. Everything from movement to combat is very batman-esc in fact I would go as far as to say that barring a few differences the game is essentially at it's core an arkham game in lord of the rings clothing. However in this case it is not a bad thing, no indeed the free running fluid movement of talion lends vey well to both setting and other aspects of gameplay, after all he is a wraith possessed ranger.

The open world nature of the game works well in mordor, having the ability to just wander and find bands of orcs to kill rarely gets old. On the main map the world is spilt into sections each of which are dark until you climb the spirit tower to unlock it, I know, I know very Assassins Creed. You can even jump off the towers like ezio, who knows maybe Talion is another ancestor of Desmonds. And no ubisoft that is not licence to make assassins creed even more stupid and ridiculous. To be honest the whole spirit towers thing feels silly and such a rip off I wouldn't even have bothered putting it in. Travelling the world can be done in many forms, you can fast travel to towers, run everywhere or even tame animals to ride like the fearsome caragour.

The combat in shadow of mordor is very solid. Similar to the Arkham games the combat is based on a combo system. As you attack and counter enemies attacks you'll increase your hit counter at certain points every 5 to 8 hits you'll be able to preform at combat execution which instantly kills an enemy. Should your enemies be knocked to the floor you can preform ground executions at any time regardless of your hit counter. As you progress in the game enemy variety will increase which will require you to switch tactics depending on what enemy your facing. Normal uruks are easy to kill, uruks with speaks are giant shields require a bit more thought.

You have three weapons at your disposal in combat, a sword, a dagger and a bow. The dagger is used for stealth kills and executions only so you'll be relying on your sword and bow for most of the talking. You only have one attack button for the sword, you can switch targets flawlessly in-between striking so combos are easy to come by. Should you get surrounded you have a counter button which counters most melee attacks bar those who have special attacks.

The bow on the other hand is an indispensable tool both in and out of close range combat. To use your bow you enter the ranger stance, as you take aim you can use focus to briefly slow down time allowing you gain more precision in your shots. Its very easy to get head-shots from the bow and charging your shot up ensures the target will go down. The bow is also useful for getting out of sticky situations, the environment around you can be used to help you in battle. You can use the bow to shoot a variety of objects in the environment from explosive barrels to the cage doors of hungry beasts.

While the combat is fun and fluid it's still not really enough to carry the game. Especially considering its simply an iteration of arkham cities combat. However Shadow of mordor has an ace up its sleeve and for me is the sole reason why the game is worth playing, the nemesis system. The uruks of mordor have a certain hierarchy, powerful war chiefs at the top and under them are the uruk captains. Barring a few set main story characters each war chief and captain is randomly generated with a unique name, personality and appearance. Each captain has strengths and weaknesses in battle so you must adapt your tactics to suit the captain.

Often in your meetings on the battlefield with the captains, they may run or you may need to retreat. Over time, repeated clashes between Talion and an Uruk Captain can become very personal. Uruk Captains can and will remember you from close encounters in battle. Should Talion die, the captian who killed you will gain in rank and power plus the next time you meet he's sure going to mention it. If your killed by a normal uruk they will be promoted to captain and gain all the unique stats that come with that.

I know from experience that a normal uruk can become your worst nightmare. All from a stray spear an uruk then managed to get to captain. After that he continually hunted me down and turned up at the worst possible moments usually when I was fighting other captains. In all he must have killed me around 9 times until I finally got my sweet revenge, there is no better feeling. Sometimes even killing a captain is not enough, Ratanak the prison master was one such foe, I killed him by shooting an arrow through his eye. Later in the game he showed up with half a metal face, yelling that the arrow lost him his eye and he wanted revenge. Instances like this pop up all the time in the game and its very, very cool. The whole system gets you personally involved with these characters, it makes you feel genuine hate at the captain that just plagues your existence. It also gives the impression of a living and changing world, if in a somewhat limited way.

The main story of the game, while not canon, is pretty good. The voice acting of the entire game is fantastic and all the characters particularly the orcs, wraith and gollum are very believable. It certainly does have a good Lord of the rings atmosphere to the whole affair and while the core mechanics are very similar to batman, it never feels like a cheap clone with a tolkien skin.

If you enjoyed games like the arkham series and too a lesser extent assassins creed, you'll be right at home with shadow of mordor. It is certainly a must for any LOTR fans as its certainly of the better games of the franchise. A good game with a few great aspects too it certainly not 'revolutionary' as some websites have claimed but all in all, a good outing for the franchise.

reviewText:
This game has given me faith as to the future of LOTR games.  The past ones (in my opinion) have been terrible, and this is finally a well deserved revival.

Shadow of Mordor makes use of the expansive world of Middle Earth, and maintains a strong and entertaining storyline, whilst not piggybacking off any of the books (or movies).

For comparison, Shadow of Mordor is a beautiful clash of Dark Souls, Assassin's Creed and Mortal Kombat.
Explained, SOM contains the tough bosses and minions, along with the fighting style of Dark Souls, the parkour and attack opportunities of Assassin's Creed and the brutality and gore of Mortal Kombat.

Some things which are extremely notable are as follows:

+ Amazing soundtrack
+ Movie-grade voiceacting
+ Graphics which are on par with Battlefield 4
+ Does NOT require a massive gaming rig to play
+ Days of gametime in which a sprawling story unique to the player develops

I honestly can't list all the positives.

I personally can say that the new $50 pricetag is a VERY good deal for a VERY good game.

reviewText: SummaryA darn good action game that borrows heavily from the Batman Arkham series but is all the better for it.\n\nReviewYou could be forgiven for calling this game Arkham: Middle Earth.  It has so much in common with Rocksteady's Batman games that you would swear that protagonist Talion is a distant relative of Bruce Wayne.  The combat controls are virtually identical, the map looks suspiciously similiar, orcs that you can interrogate for special information are marked in green like the Riddler's goons, and you can even enter the spirit world to find clues and spot enemies through walls, very much like Batman's detective vision"!  I don't say this as a criticism but only because the similarities are impossible to ignore.  But you know what?  It works.  This is a fun and compelling game

reviewText:
It has some elements of Skyrim, Assassin's Creed and Batman games.
It smartly borrows from mentioned games, blends it and tops it with Nemesis system as a cherry.
Yes, you can mash two buttons to fight but the fun comes with unclocking new skills and transforming combat into dance of death. But wait….your enemies can also gain power and be promoted to captains or even warchiefs - once I fought an uruk captain that had no weaknesses. How to kill it? You stun it and throw off the cliff…lol.
Last, but not least - you can mount a beast that is big as ten floor building :).
10/10

reviewText:
Hrm. First off, I'd like to mention that I'm very into Tolkien. And being so, it does skew my opinion of this game. But I'll make an attempt at an even-handed review.

Here goes...

I'm very on-the-fence about this game.

I've gone through many of the areas of the game, and to be honest, it all starts to look identical. Caragors, Orcs, crumbling tower ruins - all basically the same. I get that this is Mordor, but even with great graphics, animations, and production design - it gets very boring to look at. Even as the map opens up to the next one, it merely replaces the blackened ground with lush grasses, cliffs, and steppes - the ruins feel pretty much the same.

Much ado was given about the Nemesis System - but so far, all I've really seen is a revolving door of Orcs that, much like the scenery, starts to blur together into a long chain of interchangable Orcishness. I kill a few, they get replaced by others. They kill me, they get promoted. Sometimes they run away, or survive my antics, only to pop up later for the cycle to continue. Not exactly as revolutionary as it was made to sound. Even got to kill a few more than once. Which was a little weird.

The combat is very reminiscent of the Arkham Batman games, to the point where I found myself using many of the same tactics - and fought enemy types that were also cut-and-pasted from the Arkham series. I eventually started calling Talion Batmanigorn" because
recommended: I sort of felt like a sword-wielding Batman and not a Ranger of the North. I don't mind this type of combat

reviewText:
Initial Thoughts ~2 Hours
+Great combat, fun, thrilling, fast and violent. Easy to pull off great combos and moves.
+Incredibly large amount of unique enemies
+The captains/enemy hierarchy system is super interesting
+The runes system, while basic, seems very rewarding.
+Awesome stealth system, Wicked Executions.
+Loving the voice work, excellent tutorial, and great freedom afforded to the player right from the get go.
+Graphics are absolutely stellar

Disclaimer: While I am lucky enough to have an outrageously powerful computer to play this on, I suspect it would lose some of its phenomenal visual fidelity on lower end machines. That said, I have toyed with the settings and even on medium it looks pretty stellar. As long as you can pull a decent frame rate of at least 30fps, it should be more than competent.

I would 100% currently recommend this after 2 hours of play. Those that enjoy Assassins Creed, Batman Arkham Asylum, and Tomb Raider could find some great appeal here. Have fun.

EDIT* 7-8 Hours play time.
Still thoroughly enjoying playing this. I am having a blast playing with the Nemesis system (I think that's what it's called) Having tracker Uruks hunt me down and being in the middle of a massive battle and then out of nowhere a rival Orc shows up to also try and kill me, it's really super neat.

I have also been sent a screenshot from a friend of mine, he had avenged my death in his game somehow, had no idea that functionality existed, very cool. He killed a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Uruk that had killed me around 7 times after brutal battles.

EDIT* ~16 Hours Play Time
I have noticed I have been spending large amounts of time just roaming the landscape and interacting with the enemies ranks, manipulating them to my liking and toying with the enemies. Don't get me wrong, the story missions are fun and interested and well acted, but maaaaaaaan I love screwing with these Uruks. Being able to mount Caragors and Graugs is pretty excellent too.

I also have been pleasantly surprised by unexpected occurrences with animations. For example, standing above a Graug and raining arrows down on it, when it unexpectedly climbs the wall I was hiding atop of. Totally blew me away, same with the Caragors, they can reach places that I just didn't expect.

Either way,  I am in a second zone that is much more green and lush than the first, and I am just astonished by how great this game looks.

EDIT* ~25 Hours Play Time Completed 100%
After 100% completion, I can say that this was one of the most enjoyable experiences I have had with a game in a long long time. Thank you very much to the developer for such a detailed and fantastically fun game.

Final Thoughts:

Pros:
+Amazing Graphics
+Wicked fun combat
+Nemesis system is mind boggling and entertaining as all hell
+Open world was expansive and fun to live in and discover
+Great upgrades + abilities

Cons:
-Getting stuck on a wall or ledge is frustrating occasionally
-Quicktime events are nonsense (that said, I don't know the alternative for some of those moments)
-The missions where you have to free the slaves are too numerous and repetitive
-A broken achievement (you will obey) was a little frustrating.

Conclusion:
I fully recommend Shadows of Mordor as one of the most important and excellent games to play this year.

reviewText:
Great game.  It takes place between the Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit, with Sauron coming back to Mordor as the backdrop for the plot.  Enough Tolkien to immerse yourself in, without it completely destroying the lore to make a playable game.  Don't get me wrong, there will be several WTF moments where it appears to go directly (or indirectly) against the mythos of Middle Earth. Generally speaking, however, it is excellently done, and you can tell the creators had a love of Middle Earth.

As has been mentioned before, the gameplay is combination of Batman: Arkham Whatever and Assassin's Crap.  The fighting mechanics are lifted almost directly from Batman, and I consider that a good thing.  My only gripe is that the combat is a bit easy, and although you will die, towards the end of the game death will only occur if you're just not paying attention.  The final mission was a blast, although the final boss was a let down.  (When you can tackle 30+ orcs at a time, how do you make a 1:1 fight interesting?  I don't know, and neither did the developers).

The game takes awhile to complete if you aim for all the side missions.  I rarely felt bored or like I was wasting time when going after the side missions, and the main missions were well scripted, interesting, and thoroughly enjoyable.

If you're a Tolkien fan, you'll love this game.  If you're not a Tolkien fan, well...I don't know what's wrong with you.

reviewText:
The game gets alot of harsh undeserved words. However to me it is worth praise.

The developers have found the way to make this games story smooth, dark (a welcome addition to a lotr world) and wrapped it up nicely showing us for more to come. From the discussions I observed, the hate for the story, which is usually number 1 argument for people that dislike Shadow of Mordor, come from people that- 1. Have not played the game. 2. Are mindless trolls. 3. Are children. Without much spoil it is unique in this plot, that you the to be-deadman is revived as a vengeance thirsty ranger to partake an adventure with a wraith that has merged with you, and like your guide or your Virgil, that  ghost rival of Sauron, guides you through your  journey of Mordor.

The voice acting is top notch, and deserves a medal. Artifacts you find have listenable memories, Uruks chatter, sing, banter among each other, heck even on the loading screen you can hear pieces of dialogues take place.

The nemesis system, something new and unique. Your each enemy is made real with a personality, a name, appearance, motives, fears, strengths, and witty one-liners.

The combat system offers much choice in your style of rampaging massacres. Bow, dagger, sword, maybe riding on top of a caragor or a graug? Or a little of everything?

The power up in this game is up to you. You start weak.  Apart from some of the skills that unlock with the story as it goes, you the player can get nearly invinsible as you progress, depending on how many side missions you have done or how many uruks you have killed, and also depending on the runes you equip.

The good priced  season pass includes alot of extra content, making sure you find more than 50+ hours here.

Verdict- Something unique and refreshing, give it a try.

reviewText:
This game was a pleasent supprise to me, mainly beacuse i didnt expect anything amazing from it. Game was a blast.

Story-
The story is short but good, i was engaged the whole time and wanted to see what would happen next.

Models/Animations-
Character animations and modles are very well done when it comes to the orcs you fight. Every little detail to the face was animated and moveing giving the orcs emotion and sometimes making them down right creepy. The main character you play as could of had a better face model but since you play him with his back to you this doesnt realy matter. ;D

Combat/Movement-
The combat is much like the Batman game series. You can counter/stun when an enemy attacks, flip over enemies to bulky for the frontal approch, and there is a hit counter that can trigger instant kill moves on any enemy. Movement is also like Batman again but with some Asssassins Creed mixed in. Though climbing is faster in this game then in AC.

Abilities-
You start of with minimal abilities like you would expect, but slowly unlock and grow your arsenal to become a ghost god basicly. Some abilities are unlocked threw the story only and there are two different skill trees. Ranger which focuses more on the realistic way to fight and the Raith which uses your ghostly power to take down your enemies in horrificly gruesome ways.
You can also upgrade your weapons with Runes to give them specific effects or traits. Makes for interesting combinations.

Conclusion-
I very much enjoyed seeing the story behind the Rings of Power and who made them. Cant wait for the next game to see the story continue from the cliff drop ending.

Pros-
Good story
Graphics
Combat/Fighting
Enemy diversity
Animations

Cons-
Needs different locations
Somewhat small maps
Short Story

reviewText:
Assassins Creed + Arkham CIty + Far Cry = Shadow Of Mordor.

BOTTOM HAS SLIGHT SPOILERS SO BE AWARE

Pros
The wonderful stealth and agility and movement system of Assassins Creed with the perfect combat system of the Arkham games plus the outpost captures and healing plants and strategy of Far Cry. All wrapped in the gorgeous and unforgiving dangerous setting of Mordor. This game is truely gold and everyone who has ever played any of the three series of games i mentioned will have a blast with Shadow Of Mordor. I enjoyed the nemesis system which brought purpose and replayability to the game. The extremely violent combat gave me a rush, especially when taking over outposts and capturing warchiefs.

Cons
The shortcomings are limited but still need to be noted. at times it was hard to control Talion. A few times he wouldn't climb up unless i went down and back up again. The camera, though 90% on point, would sometimes make things hard to see in tight areas. But the main thing that annoyed me was the nemesis system getting in the way of itself and gameplay. Almost everytime i went to capture a warchief, there would be other captains that would see me and then the nemesis system would direct my screen away from Talion and to the captain for his quick speech saying he has seen me before. Though the system is great and above all other games' AI, it sometimes got in the way especially during intense battles where every move counts and the flow of the combat means everything, just to be thrown off by the nemesis system kicking in. It didnt ruin the game at all, but was annoying.

Verdict
The few problems i had didnt turn me off to the game. it remains to be one of my favorite, definitely my top pick for games released in 2014. i only found one small glitch that made a few of the walls bright neon colors but that was literally the only glitch and it was during free roam so it didnt hurt gameplay. Overall i give the game a 9/10 simply for being able to blend 3 game mechanics from 3 different games into one beautiful looking game with plenty of satisfying gameplay. its not a 10 just for the nemesis system getting in the way of itself. Also not a 10 for the reason ill explain in the spoiler section.





SPOILERS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!SPOILERS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
i felt the ending of the game was so build out through my 30 hour gameplay. the story of him avenging his family's death was so compelling, even if not unique. His friendship with the hunter and queen. all very well done but i feel like Mordor needed....well more Mordor. the world seemed a little bland and the story needed more scenes like when Talion and his minions stormed the gates, that was exciting and had such a Lord Of The Rings feel! one big team against another in an all out fight in an open field. I loved that part but it only lasted a few minutes. Also the end we so built up just to be a quick time event where you hit a few buttons and beat the dark lord!!! common!! Ive been wanting to fight him since i first watched LOTR!!!! i wanted a real awesome boss fight. the only real boss fight was in the cave with the hunter. but the ending did leave with sort of a cliff hanger, hopefully a second game will bring a more exciting setting, boss fights and epic moments of two teams just clashing in all out warfare!!! other than that, everything the game did, it did it right. it was fun and now i still have 63.5% left in the game even after the main story!. plenty of fun packed in, a real joy to play.

reviewText:
This is indeed a very well acomplished game.

If you like the open world style game of Assasyns creed and the likes, then this is the game for you. The mechanics are simple to learn, yet challenging. The Bosses system is fun and intuitive, combat is very well made, the story opens up some of the middle earth lore that you would not be able to know without the books.

If you are thinking of buying this game, i definitely advise you to do it, you won't be dissapointed. Getting the season pass is up to you, depending on how much time you have to play and how much you like the game, it is a decision that you should make after playing a few hours and see how you cope. I myself haven't purchased it, but as soon as my campaign finishes, i plan on getting the DLC content separately (there is still only one DLC for 6.99£, and season pass is at the moment for 19.90£)

reviewText:
This game is the best combination of Batman's Arkham series combat, and the expansive lore of Tolkien's Middle Earth. Add to that the Nemesis system and this game instantly becomes contender for GOTY 2014.

I recommend this to all fans of hack'n'slash genres, but it can be played by anyone, since the combat is fairly simplified and forgiving, unless you use Death Threat and try to take the target head-on.

I have had a blast playing this, and I am sure many others did the same. If you want to play a real action game, don't hesitate and buy this, totally worth the money.

PS: Getting the Season Pass makes life easier thanks to the Legendary Runes you get.

reviewText:
If you liked the Batman: Arkham series, and wanted to see what the combat could do in a fantasy setting, this is the game for you.

If you wanted to see a gorgeous rendition of JRR Tolkien's Mordor and surrounding lands, and be able to explore it better than any Assassin from Assassin's Creed, this is the game for you.

If you wanted a game in which the enemies have more than a basic AI to be slaughtered, with truly memorable encounters, this is the game for you.

If you want all three, go see a doctor first, because your heart may explode from the amount of awesome this games gives you.

reviewText:
Theres plenty of reviews on here talking about the highs and lows.  And they're all pretty spot on.  Mix between Arkham City and Assassin's Creed with a Middle Earth back drop.  That orc has been flogged.

I'm just going to mention the two things I liked the most becuase they really are worth mentioning.

First, the Vendetta system.  A system that allows you to take on an Uruk Captain that has killed another player or players. I avenged some Brazilian guy whos handle was something along the lines of ♥♥♥♥♥ Rocker.  Avenging ♥♥♥♥♥ Rocker's death made me feel really good about myself....  Viva la ♥♥♥♥♥ Rocker

Second, the enemy models.  Going into this game (besides some animal types) I knew I was going to be fighting pretty much nothing but Uruks (Orcs, gobs, etc).  So I expected to be seeing a ton of clones.  Seeing tons of the same model over and over again has always irritated the ♥♥♥♥ out of me in games (a blemesh on the other wise great Bioshock series).    So I prepared myself for an onslought of what might as well have been a clone army.  But to my surprise the character model variations (and the models themselves) in this game are fantastic.  I'm guessing the developers had a kind of mix and match system working on the fly for the enemy models becuase you harldy ever see the same looking Orc twice.  Some are fat, some skinny.  Some tall ones, short ones (insert ♥♥♥♥♥ joke here).  Bluish skinned, grey skinned, green skinned.  Giant yellow eyes, small beedy blue eyes.  And the more powerful Captains all look even more distinct with unique names, varying helmets, armour, different swords and crossbows etc etc. They even have different fighting personalities and the War Chiefs (the elite Captains) always have some parting words for you before they go.  I remember this specifically becuase one of them (right before I displaced his head from his torso) said something along the lines of, You enjoy the killing...  You're the same as us.  A murderer).  That stuck with me.  Never had something a random NPC said stick with me like that.  Anyway
date: fantastic variation system.  Every game that involves the slaughter of wholesale baddies should have one just like it.\n\nSo yeah.  Its a good game
hoursPlayed: January 15, 2015

reviewText:
No Spoilers

Where to begin, at first glance it looks like your average Assassins Clone with lord of the rings re-textures,
but once you get your hands on it, it feels different, fresh even, the combat is smooth, and if you make a mistake you get punished for it, you feel like this badass tearing through hords of Uruks, you feel un-killable, untill you meet acouple of captains that will put you in your place :).

alright, so i will admit, it is short, and if i really tried and didnt screw around i could 100% the game in  15hour from a blind playthrough, i  100% finished it in 21 hours, which is short, collected all the artifacts ect..

but the story is just a bonus, the nemisis system is where all the fun is at, killing or being killed impacts the world around you, having a captin come back from the dead because you didnt finish him off or because you didn't chop of his head is a thrill, minipulating uruks to fight other uruks is alot of fun. being hunted instead of the one hunting also throws you off, having a fight where 5-6 random captains can show up is intense, choosing if you run or fight, risk dieng and leveling up all those captains is a choice you have to make.

cons:
short main story
last boss fight could have been better
easy and early on you can become OP
couple of glitches, one that prevented me from getting an achievement.

pros:
hours apon hours of fun
havent got bored of it yet
fun story, with some great lore
chopping off heads :)
